SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name, for two sitting days after today for disallowance of Defence Determinations Nos 93 and 94 of 1986. Mr President, with some trepidation, I seek leave to make a very short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to describe this matter in detail except to say to Senator Haines in particular that it concerns the use of extensive retrospectivity of over two years in defence determinations. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has explained the background to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Nevertheless, because it denies Parliament the opportunity to examine legislation at the time in which it actually applies, the Committee views retrospectivity of beyond a few months as warranting its scrutiny. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard for the information of honourable senators and others my short descriptive statement, the Committee's brief correspondence and also the text of four guidelines which since 1968 the Committee has applied when scrutinising retrospectivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
RETROSPECTIVITY IN DEFENCE DETERMINATIONS

The Committee wrote to the Minister for Defence about Defence Determinations Nos. 75, 93, and 94 of 1986 because they contained significantly retrospective elements, going back as far as 1 September 1983 and 1 January 1984. In its 19th, and again in its 25th, Reports, in 1964 and 1968, the Committee, with the support of the Senate, formulated guidelines on how it would scrutinise retrospective instruments. While objecting to retrospectivity beyond a few months, the Committee has taken a very strong stand against retrospectivity exceeding 2 years where the payment of monies is concerned. The Committee requires exceptional circumstances to justify that.

Although I stress that, in these cases, the retrospectivity has not prejudiced any defence force personnel, it can prejudice the Parliament which is expected to approve of backdated expenditure in circumstances other than those prevailing at the time to which the expenditure relates. The Minister for Defence has written to the Committee pointing out that lengthy retrospectivity was needed here because Defence Determinations were based on precedent Public Service Board Determinations and human error resulted in applicable Public Service Board determinations being overlooked.

The Committee has no interest in apportioning and casting blame. Our concern is simply to ensure that retrospectivity in Determinations is kept to a reasonable minimum. Although administratively convenient and sometimes genuinely necessary to avoid hardship or unfairness, the unquestioned use of retrospectivity for administrative purposes can lead to a decline in standards of administrative efficiency and money management. The Minister has assured the Committee that he does not consider the system for producing Determinations to be fundamentally flawed. The Committee has some confidence that the Minister will monitor the situation through his senior advisers to ensure that legislative retrospectivity is minimised.
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
24 February 1987
The Hon. Kim Beazley, M.P.
Minister for Defence
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 19 February 1987 the Committee considered Defence Determinations Nos. 75, 93 and 94 of 1986. The Committee would appreciate your assistance in explaining the need for various periods of retrospectivity which arise under these Determinations.

In Determination No. 75 there are periods of retrospectivity going back as far as 1 September 1983. In his letter of 28 October 1986, the Minister Assisting, the Hon. John Brown, M.P., explained that the precedent Public Service Board Determinations dealing with the relevant allowances did not come to the attention of Defence staff until recently. As you will appreciate, the period of retrospectivity involved here exceeds 2 years and the explanation is very similar to that arising in connection with determination No. 72 about which the Committee wrote to you in 28 November 1986. In that letter the Committee queried whether oversights giving rise to the need for lengthy corrective retrospectivity arose from some defect in intra-departmental or inter-departmental systems and procedures. The Committee would be very grateful if you could also address that query in the context of this particular Determination.

In Determination No. 93, Mackay Allowance, similar to a precedent Public Service Board allowance made available in December 1984, is payable from 1 January 1984 until a posting ends or 31 December 1986 which ever is the earlier. Although the retrospectivity prejudices no one other than the Commonwealth, it could have applied for almost 3 years. Once again the potential retrospective application exceeds 2 years and the Explanatory Statement does not explain why this significant deviation from the norm was required. The Minister Assisting very kindly wrote to the Committee on 1 December 1986 partially explaining the background to Determination No. 93. However, the Committee remains somewhat uncertain as to the quality of administrative procedures and departmental liaison and the part these play in giving rise to the need for such extensive potential retrospectivity. The Committee would welcome your advice on this.

Finally, Determination No. 94, made retrospective to 1 January 1984, precludes payment of District Allowance to any member who becomes entitled to Mackay Allowance. The issue of the need for retrospectivity was addressed in the letter of 1 December 1986 from the Minister Assisting, who informed the Committee that the Department became aware of the Public Service Board Mackay Allowance in August 1985, but because ``retrospectivity beyond the normal was involved and because of other pressing drafting commitments and the small number of members entitled to the allowance (three members) the subject was accorded a low priority''. The Committee has noted this explanation.

However, the Committee would appreciate your clarification of two issues, firstly, whether the Mackay Allowance is the same or greater than the District Allowance it is replacing and secondly whether inter-departmental or intra-departmental systems and procedures are adequate to maintain an effective level of communications between the Public Service Board and the relevant areas of the Department of Defence to reduce, as far as possible, the need for retrospectivity.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Senator Cooney

In your letter of 24 February 1987 you seek an explanation of the need for various periods of retrospectivity which arise under Determinations Nos. 75, 93 and 94 of 1986. Your letter also seeks clarification of whether Mackay Allowance (Determination No. 93) is the same as or greater than the District Allowance (Determination No. 94) it is replacing, and whether inter-departmental or intra-departmental systems and procedures are adequate to maintain an effective level of communication between the Public Service Board (PSB) and the relevant areas of the Department of Defence to reduce, as far as possible, the need for retrospectivity. I regret the delay in responding.

I turn firstly to the retrospectivity which arises under Determination No. 75 of 1986. As you have commented, the explanation provided in the letter of 28 October 1986 from the Minister Assisting, the Hon. John Brown, MP, is very similar to that given in connection with Determination No. 72 of 1986. The answer to your present query is similar to that which I provided to you on Determination No. 72 of 1986 on the 24 February 1987; that is, that human error occurred within the Department at the time of checking the PSB determination and the oversight was not recognised until mid-1986.

Determinations Nos. 93 and 94 of 1986, covering Mackay and District Allowances also have a degree of retrospectivity and in this instance the PSB did fail to advise the Department of Defence of the creation of Mackay Allowance. The allowance was brought to the notice of the Department by the Deputy Regional Secretary, North Queensland in late August 1985.
As the Minister Assisting explained in his letter of 1 December 1986, further delay ensued in the preparation of Determinations Nos. 93 and 94 because:
a. it was necessary to consult with the PSB to clarify certain aspects of the eligibility criteria; and

b. limited drafting resources required that priorities be set and because of other pressing drafting commitments and the small numbers of members entitle to the allowance this matter was accorded a relatively low priority.

As a consequence of this and other similar incidents, the PSB was requested in November 1986 to standardize procedures for ensuring that all relevant Determinations are passed to my Department in a timely manner. The PSB has agreed and the inter-departmental liaison system is now considered adequate to minimise the possibility of a recurrence. We must accept that our requirement has to be recognised and acted upon by an organisation for which this is only a by-product of its activity.
In summary, given the unrelated and isolated nature of the occurrences, I consider that they are more attributable to human error than to fundamental flaws in the system.

I turn now to the question of whether Mackay Allowance is the same as or greater than the District Allowance which it replaces. Prior to 1 January 1984 a qualified member serving in Mackay was entitled to District Allowance under the provisions of Determination 0301; however, the entitlement to the allowance ceased on 31 December 1983. Since that time Mackay has not been an isolated district in respect of which District Allowance is payable. It follows therefore that, since 1 January 1984, a member would not normally have been entitled to both District Allowance under Determination 0301 and Mackay Allowance under Determination 0308 in respect of service in the Mackay locality.

The only situation where a member could be entitled to both allowances concurrently is where he or she is posted from the Mackay locality to an isolated district within the terms of Determination 0301, and the member's entitlement to Mackay Allowance continues for a period under the provisions of clause 14 of Determination 0308. However, clause 15 of Determination 0308 provides that Mackay Allowance shall continue to be payable in these circumstances only if it is greater than the District Allowance to which the member would become entitled in respect of the new posting locality.

Determination No. 94 inserts in Determination 0301 a corresponding provision which precludes payment of District Allowance where a member is entitled to Mackay Allowance but, as Mackay Allowance is only payable if it is the greater, the exclusion in Determination 0301 only operates if the rate of District Allowance that would otherwise be payable to a member is less than the rate of Mackay Allowance that is payable to the member.
Yours sincerely
KIM C. BEAZLEY
SENATE REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES COMMITTEE
TWENTY-FIFTH REPORT (Parliamentary Paper No. 188/1969, page 225)
(1) All regulations, of whatever character, having a retrospective operation will prima facie attract the attention of the Committee.
(2) Where the retrospectivity involved is in relation to payment of moneys the Committee will view the retrospectivity as requiring close scrutiny.

(3) The Committee regards retrospectivity beyond a few months as objectionable. It is recognised, for obvious practical reasons of an administrative character, that some retrospectivity is inevitable. The Committee believes that such retrospectivity should be of the shortest period practicable.

(4) Regulations involving retrospectivity in payment of moneys, if extending beyond two years, will be the subject of report to the Senate and unless quite exceptional circumstances are established to the Committee's satisfaction, will be the subject of a recommendation for disallowance.

Perhaps there is room for some better understanding of what the rules in fact are.

Senator Reid also asked me about the Bond university. The Bond university is, I suppose, an entrepreneurial response to perceived needs in particular areas of education. It is certainly being marketed as such. Whether it is successful in the market-place remains to be seen, and whether it is successful in providing high standards of accreditation also remains to be seen. But I certainly see it as a response to some perceived deficiencies in some areas of the education system in respect of which it has been sought to establish a competitive facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State. Following the Minister's visit to Darwin last weekend, is he able to indicate to the Senate steps being taken to ensure that a timely and effective response can be made to terrorist activity should it occur or be threatened in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question raised by Senator Robertson is, I think, one that is in the consciousness of most of us as we become more aware of the threat of terrorism, particularly that which is inspired by international factors rather than those which are domestic to Australia. The fact is that since 1970 in Australia there have been some 36 terrorist incidents in which people have sought to use violent terror in order to achieve political ends. Twenty-five of those incidents, though, have had to do with bombings or attempted bombings. In fact, it is the possible threat of bombings as a technique of terrorist activity to which this Government has directed many resources over the past couple of years. But it is not simply a question of directing resources and trying to anticipate the type of terrorist activity that might be undertaken. There also needs to be a firm political stance in relation to the threat of terrorist activity. In that regard, I would certainly reiterate what was said by my predecessor last October in relation to terrorism. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: A major element of Australia's response to incidents of terrorism is a policy of no concessions, other than tactical ones, to terrorist demands.

It is that firm intention of the Government not to give in to the political demands of terrorist that lies behind any particular technical or timely response by way of police or military action that we might mount.

In relation to the particular activity taking place in Darwin which Senator Robertson mentioned, the fact is that this week, for three or four days, a mock terrorist hijacking of a 707 aircraft is being staged there. In fact, we have made available a Boeing 707 aircraft which will have within it Commonwealth and State personnel who will play the roles of hostages and terrorists. This will require the activation of a crisis command centre and we will have to see and assess the performance of the Northern Territory Police, assisted by the Australian Federal Police and elements of the defence forces, in dealing with that particular incident. I believe that that particular training exercise, which will be one of testing the collaboration between those forces which have the first responsibility of response-namely, in this instance, the Northern Territory Police-and then the further elements of assistance from the AFP and the Special Air Service, will make it very apparent to those who might contemplate such hijacking of airliners in transit in Australia that the Government does have not only a very sound political response to terrorism but also a very well trained force capable of dealing with any such incident.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Was the Minister or any officer of his Department consulted about the proposal for the establishment of a casino on Christmas Island? Further, I ask the Minister to provide the Parliament with full details of his policy and findings relating to the environmental impact of the casino proposal.

—The Department of Territories referred the Christmas Island casino proposal to the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment for environmental assessment under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The developer, Mr Frank Woodmore of Perth, was designated as the proponent of the proposal. As required by the administrative procedures under the Act, the proponent supplied information on the proposal and its likely environmental effects to the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment. In the course of its assessment, the Department secured the proponent's agreement to a series of environmental protection undertakings. These addressed the potential impact of the proposal on the island's natural and socio-economic environment. On the basis of these undertakings and the Department's assessment, the Minister concluded that an environmental impact statement would not be required on the proposal. I understand that the environment protection undertakings agreed between the proponent and the Department have been incorporated in the draft agreement between the Commonwealth and Christmas Island Casino Resort Pty Ltd.

—My question is addressed to the Minister who represents the Treasurer and the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Minister seen a Press release issued yesterday by the Federal member for Maranoa and chairman of the National Party's fuel committee, Ian Cameron, proposing a range of subsidies and taxation expenditures in relation to fuel usage? What would be the effect on the deficit if those measures were implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a statement with Mr Cameron's name on it; I presume it is genuine. It says that Mr Cameron welcomes Esso's support of the abolition of the crude oil excise applied at wellhead, which is currently worth $1.3 billion to the Federal Government. That figure of $1.3 billion appears in the Budget Papers for 1986. Since then, because of the changes in world prices, the oil price has increased appreciably and I expect that the revenue would be running somewhat above the $1.3 billion. However, I have not yet had that checked out. I expect that the revenue would be of the order of $1.6 billion this year.

ANSWER.PARA: However, more importantly, Mr Cameron's proposal would have no effect at all on the retail price of petroleum products. It would simply entail a transfer from Commonwealth revenue of something like $800m to the Esso subsidiary that operates in Australia; that is, a wholly American company. The National Party is proposing the transfer of about $800m this year to a United States company. That is about the sort of economic loyalty that Australians have come to expect from the National Party over a number of years.

As to the other items that Mr Cameron identified, the abolition of fuel indexation would cost about $340m in a full year; the rebate of excise for all fuel used on farms, including distillate, which is already fully rebated, and the petrol that is used to go to town or the city or wherever, would cost $145m; and the abolition of sales tax on lubricants would cost $70m. The purpose of the reintroduction of the fuel freight subsidy is not specified precisely in Mr Cameron's statement but the restoration of the scheme that operated a few years ago would add at least $115m to outlays. In terms of lost revenue and reductions in outlays for this financial year, had Mr Cameron's scheme been in operation, the loss would have blown out the deficit by another $1.47 billion. If present oil prices are maintained, it would blow out the deficit by something close to $2 billion in the succeeding year because the excise from crude oil, at present oil prices, will be considerably higher in the next year than it is this year. I do not know what the official Opposition thinks of this National Party proposition to add to next year's prospective Budget deficit close to another $2 billion on top of the $14 billion or $16 billion that it already has in prospect.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: AGRICULTURAL PROTECTION

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the present protectionist mood in United States of America agriculture-lamb quotas, decreased access to sugar markets and subsidised grain sales-can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry tell the Senate whether the Government has considered urging the Bureau of Agricultural Economics to do a cost analysis on United States agricultural protection similar to the `red book' exercise that was so successfully carried out on the European Economic Community?

—The simple answer is that I do not know whether the BAE has any such exercise under way. I will inquire of Mr Kerin. My hunch is that the results of such an exercise would be much less dramatic than the BAE's review of the effect of agricultural protection in the EEC.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of research recently completed by Drs Beggs and Chapman of the Australian National University into trends in the incidence of industrial action in Australia? Are those trends indicative of the performance of this Government's industrial relations policy? How does the performance of the Australian Government's industrial relations policy compare with overseas experience?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the research referred to, a report of which was published in the Age a few days ago. The main finding relevant to the performance of this Government's industrial relations policy is that the country experienced a very sharp drop in days lost through strikes from the beginning of 1983 to the end of 1985. Dr Chapman was reported to have been reluctant to attribute the drop in strikes solely to the effect of the Government's prices and incomes accord but said that it would be implausible to argue that industrial relations policy changes since 1983 were irrelevant. That is certainly an understatement.

ANSWER.PARA: In the period from 1971 to 1983, Australia lost an average of 0.638 working days per worker. That figure fell to 0.262 in the period between 1983 and 1986. The research compared those figures with the average of 13 other Western countries. While the statistics are not precisely comparable, it was made very clear by Chapman and Beggs that that did not seriously distort the statistics. The average for the other 13 Western countries for the period 1971 to 1983 was 0.459-that is, about 30 per cent less than it was in Australia during the same period. However, for the period from 1983 to 1986, the figure was about 0.322-that is, about 30 per cent more than the equivalent figure for Australia. In the 12 or 13 years to 1983, Australia's record compared with that of these 13 other industrial countries was about 30 per cent worse, but since 1983 it has been about 30 per cent better. It is, of course, possible for it to be much better still, as the case of Sweden demonstrated, where in that same three-year period from 1983 to 1986 only 0.009 working days were lost per year. In other words, it was a figure so low that it could almost be ignored.

Before Senator Chaney again demonstrates his sympathy for the industrial relations policies and ambitions of the Bjelke-Petersen regime in Queensland, he ought to take some time reflecting on those figures and note that Sweden certainly did not achieve that negligible level of working time lost through industrial disputes by following the Petersen regime's formula for doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Senator Maguire noted the results of a survey by the Small Business Corporation of South Australia which has revealed an alarming increase in the number of personal bankruptcies in all States with rises of 60 per cent in Queensland, 50 per cent in South Australia and 49 per cent in Western Australia in the nine months to the end of March this year? Does the Minister agree that the main cause of this dramatic rise in the number of personal bankruptcies is the rocketing interest rates which have been deliberately foisted on the Australian people by the Hawke Government? Does he further agree that the situation is likely to worsen as people resort more and more to credit in an effort to maintain the living standards which are likely to be hit further by measures to be announced tomorrow night?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question clearly indicates that he does not understand the measures to be announced tomorrow night or their purpose. Their purpose is, of course, to cut back government expenditure with a view to achieving quicker and better reductions in interest rates. I am sorry that the honourable senator put that codicil on his question, which bears an extraordinary resemblance to a will.
—We will see whether you have any real will tomorrow, any real spirit. That will be an interesting test.
—He cannot think of any riposte.

—I am speechless. The report prepared by, I think, the Director of the Small Business Corporation of South Australia has been drawn to my attention. As I understand it, it relates principally to personal bankruptcies, not business failure. I think the honourable senator referred to personal bankruptcies in his question. The figures are high and that is so for a variety of reasons. The report of the survey conducted by the South Australian Small Business Corporation refers not just to interest rates as a suggested reason for the bankruptcies. Another very important reason is a downturn in demand which, apparently, has affected the level of personal bankruptcies quite considerably and has aggravated cash flow problems for a number of businesses.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government recognises the role which small businesses have to play. It is encouraging that the level of small business bankruptcies has not increased at anything like the same level as personal bankruptcies. We believe that the decisions made in the taxation area, which are designed to provide a more neutral environment for investment by small businesses and to ensure that funds are directed to their most efficient use, have been generally appreciated in the small business community and the full benefits will be appreciated by small business firms when the abolition of Division 7 tax and imputation are in operation. I am aware of the survey and I can only say that its results were probably not unanticipated in the present circumstances. However, a variety of factors are involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Government noted the report from New York, datelined Sunday, that four new Star Wars related tests have been proposed to the President of the United States of America despite the fact that they would violate the traditional interpretation of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty? What would be the implications of such a course of action in view of the recent bilateral discussions which held such great promise of a beginning of genuine disarmament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of Press reports to the effect that the United States Secretary of Defense has sent a report to President Reagan recommending that the United States adopt a broader interpretation of the anti-ballistic missile treaty in order to speed research on the strategic defence initiative program. The United States Government has not yet completed its review of policy on the interpretation of the ABM treaty. It decided earlier this year that before any decision is made a series of things should happen-there should be a Pentagon study on the testing requirements of the SDI program; examination of the legal aspects of the ABM treaty; consultation with allied governments; and consultation with Congress. A State Department spokesman said a few days ago-on 30 April-that the technical and legal reports would be completed `within about a month'.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has consistently made its views on this matter clear to the United States. For example, on 2 March the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, made it very clear to the United States special envoy, Ambassador Rowny, that the Australian Government was opposed to any broader interpretation of the ABM treaty and did not endorse the SDI program. Australia attaches great importance to the continued integrity of the ABM treaty. We would be concerned if either party to the treaty were to take unilateral action which diminished confidence in it.

We believe that the successful conclusion of agreements providing for radical reductions in strategic nuclear arsenals will be largely dependent on both sides being confident that the ABM treaty remains a reliable barrier to the pursuit of wide scale ballistic missile defences. It is particularly important at this juncture to give the Geneva arms control negotiations a secure framework within which to operate. Finally, we hope that the United States Administration will continue to consult closely with its allies, including ourselves, on how best to advance the common objective of radical reductions in strategic nuclear weapons, culminating in their complete elimination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence why the Hawke Government has failed this year to give any substantial publicity to the commemoration of the Battle of the Coral Sea which took place on 7 and 8 May 1942 between Japanese and United States naval forces with assistance from Australia. This battle was the start of the turnaround of the threat to Australia and in the past it has been treated as a major and important event commemorated by Coral Sea Week. Why was the visit to Brisbane of Admiral Lyons, of the United States Navy, kept so low key? Is not the commemoration of the Coral Sea Battle an opportunity to provide all Australians with a visible reminder of the value of our alliance with the United States? Finally, why is the Government deliberately playing down the continuing importance of that alliance?

—I do not accept that there is any foundation for the various comments that Senator Lewis has incorporated in his question, in particular the last point which is tendentious and not in accordance with the facts. It certainly is not accepted by the Government. As to whether the scale of the commemoration of the Battle of the Coral Sea is of the same order as in previous years, I am not in a position to make any comment about that at this stage. I will refer Senator Lewis's question, stripped of its ornamentation and rhetoric, to the Minister for Defence in order for him to make such comments as he feels are appropriate in the circumstances.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to his answer to a question last week from Senator Maguire referring to Queensland's high rate of unemployment. Has the Minister any further statistics which would lend support to his suggestion that the Queensland labour market is continuing to perform particularly badly? Are Queensland's economic statistics clear evidence that the push by the Premier of Queensland for the Federal Parliament should be firmly rejected by all thinking Australians?

—The answer to the last part of the question, I think from any reasonable person, would certainly have to be yes; we do not want the practices of the Petersen regime, with or without last night's Four Corners program, imposed upon the Federal Government. Last week I referred to the Queensland unemployment rate for the month of April being 10.2 per cent in non-seasonally adjusted terms, which is the highest unemployment rate of any State. When one looks at the number of unemployment beneficiaries in Queensland, one sees that it has a disproportionately high number of unemployment benefit recipients relative to its population. Indeed, even though the Victorian work force is 65 per cent larger than the work force of Queensland, Queensland actually has 17,000 more people receiving the unemployment benefit than does Victoria.
—How many?

—There are 17,000 more people receiving the unemployment benefit in Queensland than in Victoria, even though Victoria has a work force and a population which is 65 per cent higher than that of Queensland. April was the fourteenth consecutive month in which Queensland had a higher number of unemployment benefit recipients than Victoria. Again, in spite of Victoria having a population which is almost two-thirds higher than that of Queensland, for 14 months in succession there has been a lower number of unemployment benefit recipients in Victoria than in Queensland. The explanation or apologia for those facts used to be the allegation, of course, that lots of young people from the south were coming to Queensland, lying around in the sun, not trying to work, and drawing the unemployment benefit. That has been blown out of the water in the last 12 or 18 months by the simple fact that there has been a net migration out of Queensland by people in that prime young working age group from 15 to 24 years and up to 34 years. They have been voting with their feet. They have gone to places such as Victoria where they have a much better chance of getting a job than they have under the Petersen regime in Queensland.

—Did the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction note that yesterday the Prime Minister was reported as saying that the $124 a month average increase in housing loan repayments, as advised by the Real Estate Institute of Australia, was exaggerated? Did the Prime Minister provide any evidence to support his very doubtful comment? Did the Minister also note that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation reported that the number of its insured borrowers in arrears more than doubled during 1986 and, in fact, is double the number that has arisen ever since the HLIC was formed? Does the Minister consider this figure to be exaggerated also, or does she concede that the enormous current interest rates and diminishing family income policies of this Government are to blame for the position?
—Senator Archer has asked a number of questions about what the Prime Minister said yesterday in reply to a question on these matters. I refer Senator Archer to the Prime Minister's answer yesterday.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like the Minister to answer whether the Prime Minister provided any evidence on the matter. As I asked, did the Minister note the HLIC report? Does she concede that the figures over this period are as I cited? Does she concede that it is the Government's policies that have made this happen?
—I can only say that Senator Archer has asked what the Prime Minister said yesterday. I refer him to yesterday's Hansard, from which he can find out.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of claims by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association that the petroleum industry is the most heavily taxed group in Australia? Can the Minister comment on the Government's reaction to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen claims reported in the Press in the last two or three days from the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association to that effect. It is important that the record be set straight. It is not possible for a start to verify the APEA estimate that petroleum producers have paid $34 billion to Commonwealth and State governments over the past decade, as that includes company tax payments which, of course, are confidential. Published estimates of Commonwealth excise and royalty receipts would suggest a significantly lower estimate than that. However, I acknowledge that the petroleum industry has made a very substantial contribution to government revenues and economic activity over this period. It is important to recognise this and the industry's potential future contribution to the economy.

ANSWER.PARA: To set the record straight, it is also important to recognise that the industry has gained very substantial benefits in recent years, including changes in government policy, such as pricing arrangements on crude oil, and windfall gains in crude oil prices. We are endeavouring to give it another benefit in terms of reduced secondary taxation on exploration effort. But that raises the spectre of resource rent tax legislation and that perhaps is another story for another day.

TALK.START.PARA: —But what about the new oil taxes?

—I will come to that. I remind Senator Durack in the process that, despite all his fulminations and protestations in a widely unreported Press release a couple of days ago about the Government's embarrassment at having removed royalty before RRT was put in place, the Opposition along with the Australian Democrats voted for that in 1985. That again is just another marginal issue in this ongoing saga.

ANSWER.PARA: To come back to the main theme let me make the point about benefits that since 1975-76 oil prices to domestic producers have increased by a factor of between 10 and 15 times. Over this period, the gross value of petroleum production has amounted to about $40 billion of which about $28 billion has been paid as excise and royalty to the Commonwealth. While that tax take might appear to be relatively high, it should be appreciated that it is also, of course, a reflection of the highly profitable nature of some petroleum investments, particularly the Bass Strait project. This still represents a very substantial reward for the risk, effort and investment that has been made. I add that the Bass Strait field has been one of the best oil-producing regions in the world. Despite the crude oil tax and the company tax complained about by APEA, over the life of the project to date the field has provided Esso Australia Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd with something like a 40 per cent internal rate of return after taxes on funds invested. That is a phenomenal rate of return, as anyone economically or financially literate opposite should be able to appreciate.

The industry has also benefited recently from the effects of import parity pricing with $36m being the net gain since 1983-since we have been in office-on the swings and roundabouts of leads and lags in prices. It has also benefited from the fact that the Government maintained excise concessions in place long after the point where we said last year that we would review them. Some $90m attributable to that benefit has flowed to the companies since September last year. The industry arguments that Senator Durack mouths periodically, when he can understand them, that the top marginal tax rate of 91 per cent on old oil is too high-and that 91 per cent, of course, based on the current top excise rate of 80 per cent plus 12 1/2 per cent on royalty and 49 per cent company tax on the remainder-fail to recognise that those tax rates apply only to Bass Strait crude production, that lower tax rates apply to about half of Bass Strait oil production and all other petroleum production and that the 91 per cent rate would apply only to production that was itself extraordinarily profitable in that it is produced at no cost to the producers. There has been no evidence whatsoever produced to indicate that these tax rates are inhibiting any crude oil production.

Lest Senator Sanders, who is looking smug, should think that any of this is a reason in itself for not going ahead with the resource rent tax on the ground of excessive generosity to the industry, I make the point in passing that that conclusion does not follow from any of the material I have so far put on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hoist with your own petard.

—No, I think the industry hoists itself with its own petard with its attack on the resource rent tax because it has found itself in the extraordinary situation of having the Parliament reject it, notwithstanding the industry's fervent hope that it could get away with the rhetoric and find itself with an appropriate tax at the end of the day. That again is another debate we should not be having here.

ANSWER.PARA: The final thing I want to say is that excises on petroleum products have contributed about $14 1/2 billion since 1975-76. These taxes make a major contribution to government revenues and hence the financing of expenditures on such items as defence, social security, health, education, roads, water resources and so on. It is inconceivable that these taxes could be removed, as a number of people in the political spectrum out in the far flung fields of the far Right are arguing. That they could be taken off without impacting dramatically on all those areas of social expenditure is, of course, just nonsense. Finally, in this respect the Government provides generous concessions to farmers and miners for diesel used off-road, and Australian petrol prices, including those excises, do still at the end of the day remain comparatively among the lowest in the world.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VISIT TO AUSTRALIA BY MR JALANDONI

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and it concerns the current visit to Australia by a Mr Jalandoni, an international representative of the Philippines National Democratic Front, which I understand is closely affiliated with the Philippines Communist Party. Prior to issuing a visa, was the Government aware that Mr Jalandoni played a significant role in the recent Libyan Conference of the World Matabah Centre against Zionism, Racism and Imperialism and that the Far Eastern Economic Review of 26 March reported that the reason for Mr Jalandoni's visit to Australia was to open a disguised front office for the National Democratic Front? Is the Minister aware of the purpose of that particular office and, if not, will he investigate the matter and report to the Senate? Earlier in Question Time the Minister referred to another office being set up in Australia by the Libyan Matabah organisation. Can the Minister say whether Mr Jalandoni is involved in that and whether the Libyan People's Bureau is financing that office?

—I have some knowledge of the matters to which Senator Jessop refers but not enough to respond fully to the points that he has raised. I will seek further information and I hope to be in a position to reply tomorrow.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen a report in Saturday's Age that shadow Treasurer Jim Carlton had called for the Government to cut at least $4,000m from the Forward Estimates in the May expenditure statement? Can the Minister say whether the expenditure statement which will be brought down on Wednesday will meet the shadow Treasurer's expectations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to answer the very last part of the question because it asks me to tell the Senate what will be in the Treasurer's statement-if not in detail, at least in aggregate-and I am certainly not going to do that. I have seen the report in the Age of a day or two ago-last Saturday, I think-wherein, in between bucketing John Elliott and a few other people in the Liberal Party, Mr Carlton referred to what he thought should be done about government expenditure, and he said that $4 billion should come off the Forward Estimates. I would be very grateful to receive Mr Carlton's list of cuts totalling $4 billion or a description of the mechanism that he would use to cut $4 billion from the projected Budget deficit. All I have seen so far from Mr Carlton or from his leader is a specific $32m off government outlays accompanied by a whole grab-bag of proposals both to increase spending and to reduce revenue through an assortment of tax concessions. Principally, that would bring back the old tax shelters, the old tax rorts, over which John Howard presided for the entire time that he was Treasurer and which this Government has got rid of.

ANSWER.PARA: Abolition of the assets test alone, which has been Opposition policy for some years, would cost several hundred million dollars on present indications. So that proposition would add, in just one item, several hundred million dollars to outlays. Notably, the document produced by Professors Porter, Freebairn and Walsh last week, even though it is flawed, at least had the common sense and intellectual honesty to explicitly advocate the retention of an assets test. It is a pity that the Liberal Party did not have the common sense and honesty to do likewise.

On the revenue side, far from pointing to measures which would reduce the Budget deficit, the Opposition has a grab-bag of promises to bring back tax shelters and abolish the capital gains tax. That would entail losses to revenue gained not only specifically from the capital gains tax but under section 25 (1) and section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. When assessing the impact of the capital gains tax the revenue from all those sections should be added together minus only that small amount collected under section 25 (1) and section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act before that. If we abolished the fringe benefits tax-another article of faith of the Opposition-there would be a loss to revenue of $700m. If we brought back the free lunch, another $300m or $400m would be lost. If all those things were done-if the free lunch came back, the fringe benefits tax was abolished, the capital gains tax was abolished, negative gearing was reintroduced and so on-once the message had gone out that the Government had explicitly endorsed the use of these devices in order to erode the tax base, the tax base would erode at a very rapid rate and the ultimate loss to revenue, albeit in a very short time, would be very much greater than the $1.2 billion or so which I have detailed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUNDS FROM DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that Mr Bob Richardson of the Australian Council of Trade Unions receives funds from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations? If so, for what purpose; how much money does he receive, and for what period? Does his job involve making public statements supporting the Tasmanian logging industry and denouncing conservationist and Federal Government action? Does the Minister condone such actions by Mr Richardson? What does the Minister intend to do to rectify the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the question `Does Mr Richardson receive funds from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations?' is no, but it is a bit more complicated than that and I will go into it later. Implicit in the latter part of the question is an authoritarian attitude that anybody who does not agree with Senator Sanders should in some way be silenced by the Government if the Government can so silence that person. That is not an attitude I share; nor does the Government.

Payments made by the Department under the scheme will be in respect of this other person's period of appointment, and, as I said before, no payments have been made to Mr Richardson under this scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. The Minister will be aware that in the new Parliament House Ministers will be able to avoid Press and public attention when they arrive for work by driving into the secure underground car park and taking private lifts to their offices. Can the Minister assure the Senate and the public that after the move to the new building, the right to peaceful protest will be preserved by the provision of suitable and prominent areas similar to the lawns in front of the present Parliament House, where protests can be held and tent embassies set up?
—I have to advise Senator Zakharov that I have no information in respect of her question, so I will draw it to the attention of the Minister for Territories.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to the answer that he gave Senator Walters yesterday, and I now ask whether the Minister will categorically deny that no Royal Australian Air Force flights took place over the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests areas of Tasmania during the last three days.
—All the information that is available to me from the offices of the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment leads me to categorically deny it. I am happy to do that.
—Can the Special Minister of State advise the Senate of the contribution of the Australian Federal Police to the Federal Government's fight against organised crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for Senator Foreman's question because it gives me an opportunity to affirm that the Australian Federal Police is the Federal Government's primary law enforcement agency. Since August 1985, when we replaced the AFP's outdated charter, we have seen tremendous progress in the professionalism and, indeed, the achievements of that law enforcement agency. It will be recalled that at that time in August 1985 a new and more relevant charter of objectives and priorities was given to the Australian Federal Police, one which placed investigations into drug trafficking, organised crime and major fraud on the Commonwealth as the AFP's top priorities. I can say that that particularly setting of priorities is the envy of many other law enforcement agencies throughout Australia and has provided a framework within which the Commissioner and his police force have been able to channel the resources that are made available to them.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as those resources are concerned, the Government, even in the context of stringent budgetary considerations, has consistently supported the Australian Federal Police with those necessary resources. Our three-year commitment to strengthen the AFP, at a cost of $10m, has provided an additional 100 staff this year, bringing the increase in AFP staff since the Government came to office to 535, or 21 per cent. Seven million dollars has also been provided to enhance the AFP's computer capacity.

But it is one thing to provide the resources and to give a political charter; it is another to see the results. In fact, as members of the public and, of course, honourable senators will be aware, as far as major successful drug operations are concerned, Operation Lavender, which brought about the disruption of a major syndicate responsible for importing between five and seven tonnes of cannabis resin, of which approximately one tonne was recovered, was a very major breakthrough. Recently, Operation Oyster was very successful in bringing to light and dealing with importations of heroin totalling 11 kilograms which was smuggled in soccer balls by a syndicate which allegedly included a Customs officer.

I want to say that I am extremely delighted with this new charter and with the resources that we are putting into the AFP. There has been a most successful recruiting program which has allowed us to recruit people, young people in particular, of very good quality and calibre into the Australian Federal Police. It was my great pleasure recently, on 8 April, to attend my first passing out parade as Special Minister of State when 24 Australian Federal Police officers stepped out to join the ranks of that force. It gave me particular pleasure to present Constable Cathryn Bell of Sydney with the award of dux of the course. I think that the presentation of that particular award to that young lady indicates that the Australian Federal Police is also an equal opportunity employer, one which is able to attract people of great quality and calibre to join those people with the professional expertise that they have managed to acquire over the years, so that we have a force that is well able to deal with organised crime in Australia.
