DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous effects of Labor's high tax and high interest rate policy on home ownership by Australian families.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of great, enduring social concern because if one thing, above all else, determines the quality of life in this country it is the affordability of and access to housing for the average Australian. What I think is beyond doubt is that Australians are now reflecting through the opinion polls and elsewhere their total loss of confidence in the Government's ability to deliver in this crucial area. Quite a number of indicators demonstrate the extent to which the Government has neglected this vital constituency. Above all else, this will ultimately be responsible for the Government's demise.

SPEECH.PARA: The high tax regime which has been imposed relates not simply to the inordinately high cost of interest, which in itself is a function of the Government's general economic incompetence. We are all aware that interest rates are not only a function of the demand for money in the country but also a necessity when we are running current account deficits of $14 1/2 billion, when we have a foreign debt in excess of $100 billion and when we desperately need to encourage foreign investors to forsake the risk of further depreciation and devaluation and to invest in this country. As a result, the funds that are available to those seeking to borrow are at extraordinarily high levels. Certainly interest rates in the vicinity of 20 per cent are much too common and, despite the removal of the ceiling in relation to housing loans in March 1986, the fact is that people who want to buy houses are forced to pay those exorbitantly high levels of interest.

There are a number of ways in which one can judge the success or otherwise of housing policies, but perhaps one of the best indicators, given that government has the ability to determine the availability of both private and public housing, is to look firstly at public housing. Nationwide the length of public housing queues is now in excess of 157,000, which compared rather unfavourably, to say the least, with the level of about 100,000 when the Government came to office in March 1983. In addition, some 400,000 people now reside in caravan parks around Australia. They are people who have clearly given up the ghost, who have opted out, who have decided that they simply cannot afford the classic Australian dream any more and who are now reduced to living on the periphery of society. The Department of Housing and Construction estimates that a further 40,000 Australians are homeless. If ever there is an indictment of a society, it is when people are wandering the streets without a roof over their heads. So one can say that on the public housing side the Government's policies have been an unmitigated disaster.

In terms of housing starts, which is where the average Australian really sets out to carve out some security, we find that the trend line has been going down about 20 per cent a year since the Government came to office. The latest estimate is that there will be only about 118,000 new home starts in the current financial year. In April 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised 135,000 new home starts, but successively that figure has been downgraded. The infamous Indicative Planning Council report-which confirmed what we all knew, that there was most unlikely to be any reduction in interest rates-is surely a prime factor behind those successive reductions in housing starts.

The matter is compounded when one looks at the only real alternative-the rental sector-because through a combination of Government decisions that market has almost dried up. Vacancy rates are down to historically low levels. I think less than one per cent of the rental stock in Sydney is currently available for rental. Around Australia the position is not much better. Dwelling rents have risen by something like 20 per cent over the last 12 months or so. No one in his right mind would invest in the residential real estate market as things currently stand. To quote Mr Robert Hunt, the international partner for real estate for the firm of Hillier Parker, residential real estate is hardly worth the bother. This situation is due to a number of reasons. It has a lot to do with the negative gearing proposals and the capital gains tax, which have both made investment in real estate an increasingly unattractive proposition. It is not simply a matter, as the Government probably thought it was, of punishing the large number of investors who were thought to be somehow exploiting the system. It has had the opposite result because quite a number of people have thought that in their retirement they would invest in relatively secure bricks and mortar but they have been actively discouraged as well. The end result is that there is absolutely no incentive at all and that puts a great squeeze on demand.

There will be no further investment in housing during the life of this Government and housing rentals will rise accordingly. As a result pressure is increasingly placed on the public housing system. As we can well understand, people in public housing will want to hold on to what they have despite the fact that their income levels may rise and their economic position may improve slightly. It will be very hard to dig them out. So the public housing answer is certainly the worst alternative but it is about the only one the Government seems to have been able to take seriously because it is the only one directly within its capacity to dish out finance and that is a tragic indictment of its approach. It certainly does not accept the primacy of the private sector. The Government is certainly not interested in providing a climate which would induce investors to return to the market and it certainly does not have at heart the welfare of the many hundreds of thousands of Australians who thought that they would be able to afford to purchase their own homes or rent initially and then purchase their own homes.

Yesterday another indictment of the Government's approach-the home loan affordability index-was released. Some criticism has been made of the organisations responsible for the index. I suppose it is fair to say that, despite the fact that the Government has been releasing the index on a quarterly basis for some years, this is the first time that the Government has seen fit to try to kill the messenger and that is because the figures are an indictment of Government policy. On a national basis the percentage of gross income paid by those with home mortgages has risen to 26.9 per cent when we know that historically 25 per cent has been about the limit of affordability. The explanation the Government gives for that obviously unaffordable increase is the abolition of the loan cocktail; the 13 1/2 per cent ceiling that previously applied to the interest rate level has virtually been abolished so that people on all income levels have access to home finance. That has had a limited effect; it has certainly reduced the amount that is payable for those on incomes in excess of average weekly earnings but it has done nothing for those below this figure. It is simplistic in the extreme for the Government to pretend that somehow it can explain away the affordability index on that basis.

Another startling statistic from the Australian Institute of Family Studies is that a one income family with two children needs an income in the vicinity of $42,500 per year to be on a par with a single male in receipt of average weekly earnings of $24,000 per year. Those figures show the sorts of pressures that have been brought to bear on the average family and the way in which the Government's policies have had such a deleterious impact on family life. When one compounds that with the increased mortgage burdens on those who are silly enough to have families under a Labor government, it can be seen that the squeeze is from all angles.

A range of taxes have impacted adversely upon families and they were recently detailed very cogently by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton. For instance, since March of 1983-for the duration of this Government-the amount paid weekly in taxation has risen some $37 for a single family on average weekly earnings. Interest payments have gone up by $26 a week over that period; the cost of basic private health insurance has gone up from $9.60 to $14.30 a week. During that period average weekly earnings have just exceeded the inflation rate. So once again it is clear that families whose incomes have fallen in most instances-this is not simply the income they derive from wages but the income after all of the taxes and burdens that are imposed upon them have been deducted-are at the same time being expected to pay dramatically higher amounts in home repayments. If one looks at the plethora of new taxes that have been imposed one finds that once again they all go in one direction. I forget the number, but probably close to a dozen new taxes have been imposed during the life of this Government. None of them has been of any consolation to families in our society. Families have simply had to bear a greater burden. The average family's rate of tax has gone up from 17 1/2 per cent to 20 1/2 per cent. The marginal rate of tax for the average family has gone up from 30c in the dollar to 40c in the dollar.

I would have thought that it was unarguable that the combination of Government policies has had a disastrous impact upon families and their ability to manage their own incomes and lives. If there is one thing above all else that governments should accept as a responsibility it is the obligation to ensure that middle Australia is able to maintain itself and that there are positive discriminations in favour of the family unit. The cost to government of family breakdowns is very well documented. I do not think anyone in our society could argue that that is not one of the most disastrous social consequences that can flow from mostly financial pressures that are ultimately intolerable. The Government steadfastly refuses to increase the level of family allowances to those who are in real need and to index a range of pensions or at least adjust pension benefits and spouse entitlements for those who really need them. It is clear that in total the combination of these policies severely punishes those people with families. That is probably what will cause the Government to burn at the next election. Mr Howard recently said that interest rates would do more to burn Labor out of office than any other issue. That has to be so. No amount of intellectual obfuscation on the part of the Government can disguise the fact that levels of interest rates in this country are so high by historical standards.

John Marsden, Chief Economist of the National Mutual Royal Bank, said that home mortgage repayments levels were now higher than they had been for 17 years and perhaps since the Second World War. That is another screaming indictment of Government policy. In a whole range of areas the level of interest rates and taxes is putting an inexorable squeeze on families that will be so critical to their future well-being. I do not think anyone can argue for a moment that housing policy has not been one of the disaster areas of this Government. Frank Walker, New South Wales Socialist Left housing Minister, had this to say late last year:
The `unintended consequences'-
that is a fairly key code phrase these days-
of the Federal Government's economic policies are having disastrous effects on housing in NSW.
He went on to say:

I am sure the Federal Government did not intend to exacerbate the housing crisis, but that is what has happened . . . the Federal Government's decision six months ago to deregulate interest rates on new lending for housing has done little to ease the housing shortage.

It is clear that the Government is simply out of control in this area; it is not responsible for its actions. It is certainly acting very irresponsibly. I will give honourable senators a classic example of that irresponsibility. Senator Michael Baume, in one of his earlier lives, was Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee. Early this year that Committee was astute enough to realise that 1987 had been proclaimed as the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. One would have thought that shelter was fairly critical in our society and deserving of government support. Certainly financial support was available but it has not been directed to those in need. An amount of $1.3m has been allocated by the Government for the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. Not one cent has been provided for shelter for homeless Australians. An amount of $226,000 has been spent on promotion and public relations. The Government's policy decision was to refuse to direct any of the funds to the provision of shelter for the homeless as a matter of priority. That is contrary to the United Nations resolution which set up the International Year.

Senator Baume pointed out that, despite the Government's refusal to provide housing funds for those who are obviously in need of them, a whole range of fringe organisations have been provided with funds to pursue their own political agendas. Some of the more exotic include the First Fremantle Housing Collective. That outfit has been given $7,300 to produce a personalised account of the history of the organisation. An amount of $3,500 has been provided for the production of a video of the 1985 National Youth Housing Conference. Once again, it is perhaps a passing coincidence that that conference happened to take place in the electorate of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West). Finally, the sum of $7,000 has been made available to the Tenants Union for a national conference.

It is an absolute scandal and a public disgrace that the Government should be so cynical in its misuse of public funds that it should allocate in excess of $1m in a very tight financial climate, and that none of that money should go where it belongs. That money, if the Government is to provide any at all, should have gone directly to those in need-the 40,000 who are out on the streets. All of those who cannot afford to buy housing may well have benefited from some marginal assistance. But no; what has happened, in the pithy words of the former Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, is that:
This promotional spending is really aimed at making it appear that the Government is doing something positive to fix up its own inadequate or misdirected housing policies
. . . there is no real need to spend one quarter of a million dollars on a promotion and public relations campaign telling itself how to fix up its own policies . . .

Along with those of its fellow travellers in the States. That is probably the high water mark of irresponsibility in the area of housing. It is quite clear that it is a substitution for any real action. It is probably a concession that the Government is unable to control the real level of interest rates-that it has really given up the ghost-and a concession that it is prepared to accept an inflation rate of 10 per cent, which is three or four times that of our major trading partners, and prepared to continue having the sorts of high levels of cost and the whole range of pressures that will impact, and continue to impact, so severely on Australian families.

Unless and until there is a realisation on the part of government that we need correct economic policies, less profligacy in government spending, and much greater attention to correcting our trading imbalance, there is no prospect of interest rates coming down. There is no prospect of the Government being able to do anything other than the sorts of inept public relations exercises that we have seen to date. We will continue to find that housing affordability, home rentals and all the obvious indicators of social dislocation run solidly against the average family. If there is one thing that average families should have learnt over the last period of four years or more of Labor government, it is that Labor governments, despite the rhetoric, are unable to deliver in economic terms and unable to provide an environment in which home owners can realise the great Australian dream. Ultimately, all that they will get are high words and high interest rates for the diminishing duration of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Hawke Government I oppose the matter of public importance which has been proposed this afternoon by Senator Alston, alleging that high interest rates and high taxation are having disastrous effects on home ownership in Australia. Let us look first at Labor's housing record. Let us look at the facts. Let us look beyond the housing myths of the Liberals. In 1986 in Australia, commencements of new dwellings-that is, new housing starts-totalled 121,000. In 1982, when Mr Howard, the present Leader of the Opposition, was the Treasurer of this country, 109,000 new dwellings were started in Australia. So in a period of four years under the Hawke Labor Government housing starts have risen from 109,000 to 121,000-a 10.9 per cent rate of growth. Yet this afternoon Senator Alston, on behalf of the Liberals, has proposed this matter of public importance attacking the Government over its housing policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that, as a result of those housing commencements, 12,000 more Australian families have benefited from improvements in the housing industry. In regard to houses, as distinct from other dwellings such as flats and rental accommodation, in 1982 when Mr Howard was Treasurer, 77,000 houses were started. In 1986, four years later, under a Labor government, 93,000 new houses were started. That is a massive increase and represents a reversal of the disastrous housing period that afflicted this country when Mr Howard was Treasurer.

I refer to the report of the Indicative Planning Council for the housing industry. Senator Alston referred to that this afternoon in his address. He said that there had been a downtrend in housing under the Hawke Labor Government. But what he did not tell this chamber, the electorate or the people listening to the debate, was that the housing situation in Australia was much worse under the Howard Treasury of the Fraser Government. The downtrend occurred in the early 1980s. The fact is that the Indicative Planning Council is forecasting for the 1987-88 financial year some 128,000 housing commencements. That is not a downtrend when compared with the 121,000 commencements in 1986. I defy Senator Alston to say that that is a downtrend. Unless he has an inverted view of the world, it is clearly an increase in housing starts under the Hawke Labor Government. So that is the record and the comparison. Let us nail the Liberal myth about housing in Australia. The fact is that the housing sector is producing more dwellings. There is more work for housing industry employees than when Mr Howard was Treasurer. Yet the Liberals have proposed this matter today. Clearly, it is based on the premise that the Australian public has a short memory. That is the only basis that this matter of public importance can have, because the housing industry was clearly in a much worse position and in a much more parlous situation when Mr Howard was Treasurer.

I simply refer to the letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last week from the Housing Industry Association, a major housing body in Australia, which congratulated Mr Hawke and his Government on their achievements and their records in regard to housing in this country. That is a very important letter from a major housing industry organisation. It can see increased housing starts in this country, increased activity in the industry and increased employment in the industry. I simply refer to the fact that in May 1983 the total number of people in employment in the Australian housing and construction sector was about 420,000. By 1986, total employment had risen by 70,000 to some 490,000. The Housing Industry Association is well aware that there is more activity in the industry, there is more business and there are certainly more jobs for Australian building workers under the policies of the Hawke Labor Government.

Under the Liberals, the housing industry was on its knees. There was excess capacity and there was a shedding of labour. I simply refer to the change in the figure for housing starts under Mr Howard. For example, in 1981-82 the number of new houses commenced-after all, the matter we are debating this afternoon is home ownership, not accommodation in flats or rental accommodation-under Mr Howard totalled 89,700. In 1982-83 that figure fell to 79,000. So over 10,000 fewer new houses were commenced in Australia in that 12-month period under Mr Howard. There was a massive fall in the housing industry and in housing opportunities for many Australians.

This motion possibly has been prompted by the survey by the Real Estate Institute of Australia which was published over the weekend. I suspect that the proposing of this matter of public importance has partly been prompted by that survey, which claimed that in 1986 there was an increase in average home loan repayments of 24 per cent, or an increase of $124 a month in repayments. Of course, the survey is out of date. Old data is involved in the survey. There have not been rises in housing interest rates for over 12 months. I place that fact on the record for a start.

Of course, the main thing that is wrong with the survey, the main fault contained in its analysis of the situation, is that it substantially overstates the increase in cost. It does not take into account the changing complexion of housing loans since the Government's housing package was introduced in April 1986. It does not take into account the fact that Australians now do not have to rely so much on very high interest rate personal loans to provide part of their housing finance as they did over 12 months ago. Nor does it take into account the fact that a higher proportion of housing loans granted by banks, for example, now are at the one interest rate. We do not have a composite of rates on different amounts of lending on different types of security within the one housing loan.

So the survey significantly overstates any change in housing repayments in the last 12 months. It does not take into account the fact that the average rate paid on a range of loans is lower than it was 12 months before as a result of a reduction in the different types of loans being used by people to make up the total cost of a new home purchase. This position was exposed this morning. I do not have to say that I have calculated these figures. The Australian Bankers Association is on record this morning as saying that the survey overstates the figures. Clearly, Senator Messner has not read that. He has not been keeping up with the fact that the Australian Bankers Association has exposed, as we have exposed in this place, the weakness in the survey of the Real Estate Institute of Australia, which the Liberals have cited parrot fashion this afternoon, both during Question Time and in this matter of public importance.

I refer the Opposition to the latest monthly summary of statistics issued by the Australian Treasury, the department officially in charge of regulating the Australian economy. The summary shows that there have been significant increases in the amount of funds lent for housing in the period up to February 1987. So we are not talking about 1986, as was the Real Estate Institute survey. We are talking about here and now-1987. The Treasury document shows that more funds had been lent for housing up to February 1987.

Like all other Government members, I am concerned about the effect of interest rates on home loans. I know what interest rates mean in terms of the disposable incomes of Australian families. The Government is aware of the concerns of the electorate and the home-buying public about the impact of interest rates on loans. Let us have no fiction-as the Liberals would have the electorate believe-that interest rates just come out of the blue to stop people buying homes. That is the simple message being retailed around the electorates at the moment. The fact is that interest rates are high because of the country's balance of payments problems. People overseas are not paying high prices for our products. We are using interest rates to supplement our balance of payments policy.

The Liberals do not want to hear about that. But the fact is that if the Australian dollar were to fall significantly in value as a result of there not being a capital flow to manage the dollar, the first effect would be an increase in inflation and the second effect would be an increase in interest rates because one of the key determinants of the level of interest rates in Australia is the rate of inflation. Those people who go around the community pretending that there is no balance of payments problem, saying `Let us have the easy solutions and not take the tough options', are really prescribing a recipe for higher inflation. That is basically what it is all about and the corollary of that is higher interest rates.

This Government is taking action to set the foundations for interest rate cuts. On two occasions so far-and this will happen again tomorrow-the Government has examined the level of government spending in the community. We did that in 1983 and 1985-we will do it again this year-to reduce the prospective deficit of $9,600m that we inherited from the previous Liberal Government in 1983-84. That deficit is very well documented and was referred to in the excellent book by Mr Paul Kelly entitled The Hawke Ascendancy. In this episode of Australian political history, Mr Kelly shows how the $9.6 billion deficit emerged. I must say that it is one of the most gripping books I have read on politics. It certainly surpassed Gorky Park, which was the most exciting book I had previously read. Mr Kelly verified and in great detail showed the evolution of the $9,600m deficit under the Liberals.

This Government, through expenditure cuts, has reduced that deficit to the order of $3,000m to $4,000m and this will have an impact in reducing pressures on interest rates. That is a very important factor to bear in mind. The Government is acting to reduce the rate of inflation. We are cutting cost of living rises. As I pointed out, interest rates importantly reflect the level of inflation in the community. One of the reasons that we had extraordinarily high interest rates in 1982-83 when Mr Howard was Treasurer-a number of commercial interest rates were above 20 per cent per annum-was that we had an extraordinarily high rate of inflation at that time. Mr Howard, as Treasurer, left double-digit inflation to be cleaned up by the Hawke Government. Inflation, which was running at 11.5 per cent per annum, was a very important factor in the high interest rates prevailing in 1982.

Under this Government, the cost of living rise, the rate of inflation, is now running at 9.3 per cent. So the rate is over two percentage points lower than when Mr Howard was Treasurer. Inflation is trending down and that is a good precondition for reducing interest rates. The Australian dollar has become firmer due to the economic policies of the Government. That, in turn, has assisted reductions in interest rates. It is important to note that some of the key interest rates have been falling significantly in the commercial sector. The rates paid by banks as distinct from rates charged by banks-to borrow money for on-lending to consumers have been falling significantly. On 15 January, an interest rate of 17.7 per cent applied to 90-day or three-month bank bills. This morning's quotations on the money market show that the rate has fallen to 14.3 per cent. So, there has been a 3.4 percentage points reduction in interest rates on that key security. Interest rates on government bonds are now at their lowest level in over 12 months. Prime overdraft rates are declining.

On Friday of last week, as I was preparing to leave Canberra after the sitting of Parliament, I heard on the radio that one of the lending institutions in this city-and I am sure that Senator Reid is aware of this-is reducing its home loan interest rates. I believe that a lending institution in New South Wales is now in the process of reducing its home lending rates. The commercial rates paid by institutions to borrow money which they on-lend have been falling. It seems that those reductions are now flowing over into the prime areas. As I pointed out, under the Labor Government there has been a rise in the number of new housing commencements compared with when Mr Howard was Treasurer. Importantly, that has been due to the introduction by this Government of the first home owners scheme. That scheme is income tested and helps middle and lower income Australians to overcome the rental trap and buy their own homes. They can receive lump sum assistance or payments over a five-year period.

It is important to note that under this Hawke Government policy, over 200,000 Australians have been assisted and over $1,000m has been spent to boost home ownership. A very tangible sum of money-over $1,000m-has been spent by the Hawke Labor Government to boost home ownership. That is what we have done for home ownership. Over $1,000m has been spent under the first home owners scheme. Yet, the Liberals castigate this Government over housing when $1 billion has been allocated to housing under one scheme alone. From March this year we have relaxed the income test so that more potential home owners can take advantage of that scheme. It is estimated that that relaxation of the scheme will enable another 13,000 Australian families to purchase their own homes. So they are some of our housing achievements and some of the initiatives that we have taken to boost home ownership in Australia. The Government has relaxed the prudential requirements made of saving banks in Australia. Instead of having to keep 15 per cent of deposits in liquid form, the Government is now allowing banks to keep 13 per cent in that form. That will enable the banks to allocate more money for housing and should result in significant increases in housing allocations by the banks.

Senator Alston referred this afternoon to public housing. I simply mention that under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, which is an arrangement by which the Federal Government of Australia makes grants and payments to the States and Territories for housing, there has been a substantial lift in funds. It is important to note that, in 1982-83 when Mr Howard was Treasurer, the total allocation of funds for housing under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement was $333m. Dear Prime Minister,
The Australian Democrats urge your Government to accept the recommendations of the Australian Housing Industry Association that Superannuation Funds be required to provide housing loan assistance.
The Australian Democrats have advocated such action for over 12 months.
Set out below is an outline of proposals which would immediately inject desperately needed funds into the housing industry through the provision of loans at or below 13.5%.
1. Superannuation Fund Housing Investment
Superannuation funds are a potential source of significant low cost housing finance.

They presently hold assets worth in excess of $35 billion, and it was estimated in early 1986 that they had annual contributions in 1986 of $3 billion, a figure which may double as superannuation coverage spreads throughout the workforce.

Superannuation Funds should be required to invest a percentage of new contributions in the provision of affordable housing loans. As demonstrated below this would not interfere with the Funds' primary responsibility to contributors.

Superannuation Fund investments are diversified in order to spread their risks. A significant amount of their present investments are in assets which return below the level of the Bank home loan interest rate ceiling (i.e. 13.5%).
The Commonwealth's Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) for instance, holds 29.3% of its assets in Long Term Fixed Interest Investments which returned an average of 12.8% in 1985-86.

A requirement therefore that SFIT exchange its long-term fixed interest investment portfolio (worth almost $1 billion) for housing loans at the ceiling rate of 13.5% would have led to an increase in Fund income.
The proposal does not however require changes to existing investment portfolio. The requirement would be for a percentage, say 30% of new contributions to be invested in housing loans.
This would release immediately $1 billion of new housing funds onto the market (at the present ceiling rate of 13.5%).
All income from the housing loans would in turn be reinvested in further housing loans.
Because Superannuation Funds pay no tax on earnings, an interest rate of 13.5% is equivalent to a markedly higher interest rate received by an institution subject to tax, such as Savings Banks.
If one were to compound $1 billion at 13.5%, free of tax, it would grow to approximately $39 billion after 30 years.
It can be seen therefore that a requirement that Superfunds invest in housing would not jeopardize their ability to provide adequate returns to contributors.
2. Retirement Savings Account
Broad Outline

The proposal is to establish a new category of Savings Account, available to retired persons not covered by Superannuation. The account would pay a rate of interest set by reference to housing interest rates, and all deposits held in these accounts would be provided for housing finance at an interest level set by the Government. All interest paid on the Account to depositors would be tax free. There would be a requirement for an ``income stream'' to be withdrawn from the account by the account holder. The account would attract funds presently held in investments which provide limited or no assistance to housing.
Discussion

Persons who have retired without superannuation-the majority of the workforce-but with some savings generally invest their retirement savings in Bank Accounts and various forms of securities on which interest is paid. If the interest exceeds $1,000 per annum provisional tax must be paid on the income.

The combined effect of taxation plus inflation can erode the real value of the savings. For instance, an interest rate of 12 per cent is equivalent to an after tax rate of just over 9 per cent (tax at 24c in dollar). If inflation is running at over 9 per cent therefore, the real value of savings invested at 12 per cent would fall.

As a consequence retired persons with savings are forced to invest in high interest bearing deposits or securities. If these deposits are a source of funding for housing construction the interest rate on the housing loans sourced from these deposits will of necessity be high, certainly well above the protected ceiling of 13.5 per cent. In many other cases-such as unit trusts and cash management trusts-the rate of return is high precisely because the investment is not in housing construction, but in other assets such as shares, or commercial property development.

Those retired persons who are primarily interested in the soundness of their deposits will invest in Government issued securities, which are not targeted to the provision of housing finance, and Savings Banks accounts at levels of interest which frequently do not equal, after provision for tax, the rate of inflation.
In summary the investment choices are
(1) high interest bearing deposits or securities which do not provide housing finance, or which provide only expensive housing finance;
(2) low interest bearing deposits or securities which may provide affordable housing finance (e.g. Savings bank accounts), but at cost to retired persons of their savings being eroded by inflation.
The Retirement Savings Account would address both of these problems-it would provide affordable housing finance whilst still paying retired persons interest above the level of inflation.
How would the Retirement Savings Account work?

The RSA would pay a rate of interest set by reference to the protected ceiling on Bank housing loans. If the ceiling was the present 13.5 per cent the interest on the RSA could be, say 12 per cent, on the assumption that 1.5 per cent would be a sufficient margin to allow banks to recover their administration costs. There is some room for negotiation over the bank margin as the figures below illustrate.

The RSAs would have a condition attaching to them equivalent to that governing Immediate Annuities, namely that an income stream would have to be withdrawn from the Account. The Retirement Savings Account scheme would be a significant source of new affordable housing finance. It would also contribute to the equitable treatment of retirees who through no fault of their own are forced to rely on savings, rather than superannuation or tax sheltered annuities.
3. Interest on Housing Loan Repayments to be tax deductible
Both the USA and the UK tax systems permit interest on purchase of home to be tax deductible.

An equitable system of deductibility should be introduced in Australia. Such a system would, at the very least, provide a rebate for low and middle income earners paying high rates of housing interest.
The revenue cost of such a scheme could be more than offset by removing or limiting the tax deductibility of interest on moneys borrowed from overseas to finance negatively geared takeovers.

The social and economic benefits of tax deductibility for housing are, I would have thought, clearly greater than allowing the Bell Group, Bond Corporation or Elders IXL to derive tax free gains from their essentially non-productive takeover activity.

While the average home buyer is paying average tax on earnings of around 30 per cent, Bell Group paid under 17 per cent in 1985-86, Elders paid just over 10 per cent and Bond Corporation 14 per cent. While this continues average families paying in excess of these amounts have every right to be angry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter actually covered three major areas that the Government should consider with regard to making housing more affordable. It considered the question of superannuation fund housing investment, the issue of setting up special retirement savings accounts, and, finally the issue, of the tax deductibility of interest on housing loan repayments, either in toto or in part. As far as the former was concerned, we made the point in the letter to the Prime Minister that superannuation funds are a potential source of significant low cost housing finance. These funds presently hold assets in excess of $35 billion, and it was estimated some 12 months or so ago that they had annual contributions at that time of about $3 billion, a figure which may double as superannuation coverage spreads throughout the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: It seemed not only to us but also to a number of other people concerned about this area that those superannuation funds could well be required to invest a percentage of new contributions at least in the provision of affordable housing loans. They currently have amounts of money put aside in areas that bring in varying amounts of interest, and since the housing interest market is running at between 13 1/2 and 15 1/2 per cent, it is easily calculated that they will not be significantly damaged by this.

What makes it more important that superannuation and life funds pay some attention to their responsibilities with regard to investment in the housing market is that they are currently very significant off-shore investors. Those funds enjoy tax free, tax concession status. To allow them to take significant amounts of money outside Australia for investment-essentially to speculate on the Australian dollar, and in doing so depleting domestic lending resources and pushing up interest rates as a consequence-is something that we should not continue to permit, at least not while allowing them tax free status at the same time. That is something that this Government could well be considering. Certainly it can allow the life and superannuation funds to retain tax free or tax concessional status, but only while they invest on-shore. Let them invest off-shore if they like, but do not allow them to retain that concessional status. They should not be entitled to have it both ways.

The retirement savings account scheme, of which we gave the Prime Minister a broad outline in the letter of 13 March, was a proposal to establish a new category of savings account available to retired persons not covered by superannuation. The account would pay a rate of interest set by reference to housing interest rates and all deposits held in those accounts would be provided for housing finance at an interest level set by the Government. All interest paid on the account to the depositors would be tax free. This is a variation on a piece of legislation that we introduced some five or six years ago which would have allowed tax exemption of the first $1,000 in interest earned by a depositor who had put money, at a rate of 10 per cent or less, into a bank or building society which lent for home building or home buying purposes; that is, the interest would be earned on money in an account paying 10 per cent or less at such institutions.

The final point that we put to the Prime Minister concerned the tax deductibility of interest on housing loan repayments. Australia is one of the few countries that do not allow at least partial tax deductibility of those repayments. Both the United States of America and the United Kingdom tax systems permit interest on the purchase of a home to be a tax deduction. We have not done that in this country for quite a long time, so that housing loan borrowers paying 13 1/2, 14 1/2 or 15 1/2 per cent are forced to pay out all of that while watching business borrowers, who certainly borrow at the higher rates of 17, 18 or 19 per cent, claim interest as a tax deduction. In doing so they pay, effectively, almost half that amount-that is, 8 1/2, 9 or 9 1/2 per cent. The inequity there is a fairly obvious one. It is made worse because while the average home buyer is paying average tax on earnings of around 30 per cent, the Bell Group Ltd and other extremely wealthy corporations are in a position to pay half that because of the tax concessions that they receive.

I find it rather extraordinary, and I have said so in this place on a number of occasions, that somebody like John Elliott, mooted to be the best leader that the Liberal Party has had in decades, is threatening to take his company off-shore because he claims that companies pay too much tax in Australia, when all published figures-which he has not to my knowledge challenged-indicate that his company is paying something less than 11c in the dollar in tax. There is not an Australian family I know, even on average weekly earnings or less, who can get their tax payment down to that figure.

What is helping these companies to achieve this rate of tax is that the interest paid on moneys that they borrow is a tax deduction and, as I have said, therefore their tax is effectively halved. What is worse is that by being halved this rate of tax has become taxpayer subsidised. So ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers are subsidising the frequently unproductive takeover bids and share raids of some of the wealthiest individuals and companies in this country and allowing them to pull their tax payable down to around 11c, 12c, 13c or perhaps as high as 15c in the dollar. Lack of tax deductibility of home loan interest repayments furthers the inequity that exists between average Australians and their families and these very wealthy companies and individuals. So these families have every reason and every right to be angry about the predicament in which they find themselves. To make matters worse, we have people like John Elliott and the New Right representative organisations recommending further cutbacks, further attacks on Australian families and less well off individuals. Cuts to health expenditure, cuts to education funding and cuts to welfare and housing grants are among the suggestions of certain right wing think tanks-groups in the community who believe, and probably quite rightly, that they have the ear of the official Opposition, in however many parts that may be at any given time.

I think it is extraordinary that, with home ownership already under threat, people such as Professor Porter and his cronies could recommend the abolition of the first home owners scheme, and presumably cuts to grants to the States from which they provide public housing. While that sort of inequity continues, while the two groups in Australia-those on average weekly earnings or less and those on significantly high incomes-are treated so differently by governments, this chamber will go on debating on a quarterly basis the housing problems faced by Australian families.
