If it is fair enough for the Opposition to have a go at the Government-and I accept that it is-it is fair enough and pertinent for us to ask the Opposition what it would do in these circumstances. The reply to that on taxation policy is a deafening silence. The Opposition has not brought forward its policy and, until it does, its approach in handling these matters cannot be judged effectively by anyone. Thus, it must be condemned.

I said that Senator Alston was in double jeopardy. The second problem he confronted in bringing forward this matter of public importance was what the Liberal Party's housing policy is. That is, indeed, a fascinating read for anyone who takes an interest in what an opposition that is never likely to be in government is proposing, in the depths of its own internal divisions, to be a housing policy. The housing policy it is proposing has been taken over by the cost cutters in the Liberal Party because it seeks to abolish what in fact is the jewel in the crown for welfare housing in Australia, the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. That has disappeared into the maw of the cost cutting machine, as the ultra dries regain control of the front bench of the Liberal Party. In reality, that cut would mean that the people on whose behalf the Opposition has been talking as the self-appointed spokesmen, the welfare home aspirants, would be placed in the worst imaginable circumstances ever, because a cut in welfare housing funds would result in the possibility of their obtaining housing going straight out the window. A cut in welfare housing funds would put massive pressure on rental accommodation and push up rents beyond the level which those on welfare can pay. That is the Opposition's policy, yet it criticises us this afternoon for having an organised approach to resolving Australia's housing difficulties. Further than that, its policy proposes a gutting of the first home owners scheme, a scheme that has been very effective in producing a massive number of new housing commencements in Australia since it was introduced by this Government.

Part of this debate today revolves around the subject of interest rates. It must be said that no one in the Australian Labor Party takes comfort from the level of interest rates that are commonly available in the market today. We would all like to see them lower. The question, though, is: What is the best way to reduce them? At the moment one can see that the macroeconomic policy of the Hawke Government is having an effect on bringing interest rates down. Since mid-February the official yields have been reduced by 3 per cent for shorter maturities; they are coming down. The 10-year bonds have fallen by 1 1/2 per cent. The major bank prime rates are down by up to three-quarters of one per cent, to about 17 1/2 per cent-and some banks are lower. Indeed, the Civic Advance Bank Ltd has announced lower rates. The following report appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 9 May:
The first signs of an easing in home mortgage rates became apparent yesterday when Citibank cut its rates from 16.5 per cent to 15.75 per cent.

Mortgage rates are teetering on the brink of reductions as the general commercial rates available in the market fall. They fall because of the major economic settings that this Government has put in place. When we came to office we inherited a projected Budget deficit in excess of $9 billion. In the 1986 Budget we reduced that deficit to $3.5 billion, a reduction in that Budget of $2.5 billion. The May economic statement, which is due tomorrow, will reduce that deficit even further, thus taking pressure off the money market.

We are now looking at an improving trend in the balance of payments results, and our wages policy has meant that wages are not the factor that they were when the Fraser Government was in power. The Hawke Government is committed to, and will deliver, a reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement as well. If one follows the tabulation and the fortunes of the Australian dollar one can see that it is holding reasonably well at present. All those things together mean that, as the market is showing in the commercial field, we can expect an imminent reduction in home loan interest rates. That outcome will take hold throughout the rest of this year. People holding home mortgages will benefit considerably because the economic policy of the Government is beginning to work through the system and produce the results that are necessary to get the economy back to the level for which we aim. In that area I believe there can be no real criticism of the Government's policies which are producing the results. Those results are slow in coming-slower than we would like-but one would say that, in the face of a $900m turnaround in our terms of trade over the last year, because we inherited the old policies of the Fraser Government, it has been what the market regards as a good performance.

However, it is important to put that record alongside of the record of the current Opposition. When we gained office the housing industry was in bad shape. There were only 105,000 commencements in 1982-83. By 1984-85 we had got that up to 152,700-a 45 per cent increase on 1982-83 and the highest number of commencements since 1973-74. Since then, in the face of the strong macroeconomic framework about which I have been talking, there has been a fall-off. In 1985-86 there were 136,000 commencements, still 30 per cent more than in 1982-83, the last comparable period of the Liberal Government. The Indicative Planning Council for the housing industry, headed by Professor Fred Gruen, is predicting 118,000 commencements Australia-wide in 1986-87 and an upturn of 124,000 to 128,000 in 1987-88. Those predictions by the Indicative Planning Council show that the track that we are following is right. In March this year we brought down a new housing package which broadened the eligibility for the first home owners scheme and has provided for strong funding for public housing. Employment in housing and construction has significantly increased since we came to office. In August 1986, 491,000 people were employed in housing and construction industries-70,000 more than in May 1983, the comparable period under the Liberal Government.

The Labor Government's record in home lending is much better than the record of the Opposition. In the last three years of government by this Opposition there were 735,000 home loans from major lenders, compared with 914,000 for the three years under Labor since 1983. On average there were 305,000 home loans per year in the first three years of Labor Government compared with an average of 245,000 per year in the last three years of the Liberal Government. Under Labor the value of home loans has been $21.1 billion for the last three years; under the Liberals it was $11.7 billion.

In terms of the comparison of performance, which is the basic benchmark that one must go by, ours has been much more impressive because, under our economic leadership, the economy has come back and we are getting our balance of payments under control. Since the March 1987 package which set out, as I said, to lift the peg on interest rates and abolish the subsidy to the banks, interest rates have remained at around 15.5 per cent and, as I have said, they are tipped to go down. As well, we caused $900m to go into bank loan funds by changing the bank assets reserve requirements. Also, we have broadened the eligibility for the first home ownership scheme. Lending now is strong. The market reports that building activity is good. If there is any question in terms of what the industry thinks about our policies and how the industry regards those doomsayers on the other side as to the future of housing, let me quote what the Australian Financial Review of 11 May had to say about the Real Estate Institute of Australia survey on the affordability index for housing. It said:
However, the survey's conclusions have been challenged by the Housing Industry Association and Australian Bankers' Association.
It continued:

Dr Ron Silberberg, the national executive director of the Housing Industry Association, said: `If anything, housing should have become more affordable over the last 12 months. Interest rates have come down-although they are still too high; house prices are flat; incomes have been growing and tax cuts will soon be made. This has brought repayments down to a level the average family can afford.'
The article runs on:
Dr Silberberg pointed out that the `affordability index' used by the Real Estate Institute . . . did not take account of the changing structure of housing finance.

The Australian Bankers Association went on to give a similar eulogy to the current state of the market. On the basis of that and what the Housing Industry Association said in its letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) praising this Government for its role in the housing area, one can only draw the conclusion that, in the absence of any policies at all from the Opposition, it does not have a clue that our sober management of the economy, achieving reasonable goals and turning around the economy, is bringing about the dream of home ownership for most Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous effects of Labor's high tax and high interest rate policy on home ownership by Australian families.

The two Australian Labor Party senators who have spoken in this debate-Senator Maguire and Senator Cook-have confirmed that that statement is absolutely accurate. All they have been able to say is that it has not really been the Labor Government's fault. How much longer are we going to hear this nonsense that nothing that happens is its fault; it is all someone else's fault?

TALK.START.PARA: —You did it for seven years.

—The Labor Government has been in power for more than four years and it is about time it started getting its act together and stopped trying to pass the buck. The blame is the Government's and the Government's alone. Senator Cook's final words about the dream of home ownership are what this Government has reduced home ownership to for many Australians-a dream, not a reality.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at housing we have to look at four different aspects of it. First, there is the question of the costs of new loans to acquire houses and the ability of the average Australian home seeker to afford those loans. Secondly, there is the question of what happens to people who have existing loans. Thirdly, there is the question of what happens to welfare housing. By the way, Senator Cook grossly misrepresented Liberal Party policy on this matter. Finally, there is the question of the availability of rental accommodation. Let me look at each of these matters in turn.

I turn firstly to acquiring a new loan for a house. For a typical loan of about $46,000 at an interest rate of 15 1/2 per cent, monthly repayments are $620, which comes out of after-tax income. How many families can really afford that much? And that is for a cheap house. It is very difficult to find houses in Melbourne for $45,000 or $46,000. That is what the result of the policies of this Government has inflicted on the Australian community. Of course the $620 is for a loan at an interest rate of 15 1/2 per cent. A person would be very lucky to get a loan at 15 1/2 per cent. Most borrowers would be paying substantially more.

I turn to existing loans. For a typical existing loan from a bank under the cocktail arrangement of, say, $38,000 at 13 1/2 per cent and $8,000 at 19 per cent-that would be a typical arrangement-monthly repayments are $605. Home loan interest costs have gone up 25 per cent in the last two years. Since the Hawke Government came to power average home loan repayments have increased by $280 a month. The average Australian home buyer is paying $280 a month more now than he was when this disorderly Hawke Government came to power.

We have heard some disputes over figures about the relationship of average home loans to median family income. If anyone examines them, he will see that they are quibbles about detail, not dispute about the thrust of the facts. In 1983 repayment of the average home loan took 19.2 per cent of median family income; in December 1984 it took 20.3 per cent. In December 1986 26.9 per cent of median family income went to pay off the average home loan and this is well beyond the means of many Australian families. Remember that this is paid out of after-tax income. It is not surprising, therefore, that in the second half of 1986 81 per cent more home loans were in arrears than was the case during the second half of the year before.

The third point I raise is the question of welfare housing. I would first like to say in answer to Senator Cook that our policy is not to abolish welfare housing or to stop support for it; our policy is to stop the confusion that exists with the Commonwealth and State governments both being in the same field. We are aiming to transfer this responsibility to where it rightly belongs-on the State governments-because the present system is not working at all well. In June 1983, soon after the Hawke Government came to power, 124,000 people were on the public housing waiting lists. In June last year-that is, after three years of Hawke Government misrule-the number had increased from 124,000 to 157,000. Thirty-three thousand more people were on the public housing waiting lists after three years of Hawke rule than there were before. It sounds like the hospital queues, does it not?

The fourth aspect is the availability of rental accommodation. Rental vacancies are at the lowest level ever. In Melbourne at the end of February this year the rate was 1.9 per cent, and it has been steadily declining. Demand is very high but listings are very difficult to obtain and, of course, prices are going up. This is the direct result of government policy, in particular its tax changes to eliminate negative gearing for rental properties.

There was some talk by Senator Cook and others about the required rate of construction of new houses. I think it is fairly well accepted that with our present population level we need about 135,000 new houses a year. Last year there were 144,000 and this year the number looks like sinking to about 110,000, well below our needs to meet the requirements of the community. The reason for this is the gross mismanagement of the economy by this Government. What we have been locked into, by the almost unbelievable mismanagement of the economy by this Government, is a situation in which we have high tax and high inflation-our inflation rate is five times that of our trading partners-and as a consequence of high inflation and our trading problems we have high interest rates. We will not be able to get our interest rates down until we improve our balance of payments, and we will not get the investment necessary to improve our balance of payments until we get interest rates down. This incompetent Government has locked us into a very dangerous economic situation.

I mentioned interest rates because they are critical both to housing and to investment in manufacturing industry, which is the key to our recovery. Look at the figures. In March 1987 prime interest rates in Australia were 18.5 per cent; in Japan, 5.2 per cent; in West Germany, 8.45 per cent; in France, 9.6 per cent; in the United Kingdom, 11 per cent; and in the United States, 7.5 per cent-and in Australia, 18.5 per cent. Senator Cook said, quite correctly, that our interest rates had come down since then but, quite incorrectly, he said that this was because of the effective workings of the Government's economic policies. In fact it has been a world-wide trend and interest rates in all of the other countries I mentioned have come down more than ours. To say that this small drop in interest rates is the result of successful Government policies is absolute nonsense.

I was interested to read some comments by the Federal Government's Business Regulation Review Unit. It had some interesting comments to make about why the Australian economy has not achieved growth. It stated-and it is the Government's own unit:
National savings have been low, largely due to the taxation regime discouraging savings and investment.
It also stated:
There is excessive intervention by the Government through economic and social regulation.
The wage determination and other labour market processes are inflexible.

They surely are. We have now got ourselves into a situation from which our way out will be very difficult. I do not know what the Government will announce tomorrow but I do know that what it will announce will be too little too late. Every month the Government delays taking these actions makes recovery slower and more difficult. The great crime of this Government is that it has tried to conceal from the Australian people the reality of the economic situation. It has failed to take action in a timely fashion and has failed to make the Australian people realise the united effort that is necessary in both investment and work practices for us to trade our way out of our difficulties. The Government has tried to con the Australian people and, listening to some Government senators, it appears to have ended up conning itself.

If we are to tackle this tax problem which is highlighted by the Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit, we must reduce expenditure. If we do not reduce expenditure at the same time as we cut taxes, all we will do is increase inflation and interest rates which will harm sections of the economy such as housing. Government expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product has risen over the years from 22.3 per cent in 1960 to 23.7 per cent in 1970 and 30.1 per cent last year. Even with the developing economic crisis, the Hawke Government introduced $816m worth of new programs this financial year. Yet now it is talking about cuts. Those cuts should have been made last year or the year before. If the Government share of GDP were reduced to that of 1970 or to the pre-Whitlam rate of 23.7 per cent, $12 billion a year would be saved on government expenditure, even after allowing for the present unemployment rate. This would allow for a 40 per cent cut in income tax.

The second matter which we must tackle because it directly affects interest rates, and therefore directly affects housing, is inflation. Our inflation rate is five times that of our trading partners and the effect of this is that we are constantly pricing ourselves out of markets. Our fundamental internal problem is that our spending power is grossly beyond what it should be. It is in excess of what we earn from our exports and what we generate in our internal economy. For a country such as ours to be granting itself wage increases must appear insane to outsiders. Singapore, with a much less serious problem, gave itself a 16 per cent wage cut, yet we are gaily granting ourselves wage increases which are increasing our spending power, our inflation and our interest rates, and harming all of us. Of course our terms of trade have turned against us. We must get new investment in manufacturing industry and, to a lesser extent, tourism. We must overcome all the appalling restrictive practices that mean Australian workmen, using identical equipment, produce very much less than our foreign competitors. The really alarming aspect of our present economic crisis is that the new investment in plant and equipment which should have resulted from the rapid fall in the dollar under this Hawke Government has not yet started. Our recovery will not begin until we see a sharp rise in investment in new plant and equipment so that we can overcome the pressure on the Australian dollar which in turn affects interest rates which in turn affects housing. All these things are interlinked and must be tackled as a whole.

This incompetent Government does not seem able to see these matters as a whole. People who can see clearly the way we must go are assailed by snake oil salesmen on either hand. On one hand they have the Hawke Government saying that the J-curve is just around the corner-that J-curve is a very long time coming-and that we must stick to the accord because that will get us out of our trouble. But the accord is the fundamental problem that we must face because we are linking ourselves to increased wages we are not earning. On the other hand they have people saying that all we need to solve our problems are tax cuts and a small amount of union bashing. Merely cutting taxes and doing nothing else would increase our spending power and make our present serious situation disastrous. We must have an organised and co-ordinated effort to tackle this problem, to get new investment in plant and equipment in manufacturing. We must overcome all the restrictive work practices that make our production much more expensive and less adequate than that of other countries. When we get our economy right, our interest rates will fall and then we will be able to provide the Australian people with the conditions and accommodation that they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition must be congratulated for raising the question of housing-the need to build more houses and the need to provide houses for people without them. However, once we have congratulated Opposition members for raising these matters we really cannot go ahead and congratulate them for providing any answers to these problems. Indeed, they produced no answers to the problems, with the exception of the last speaker, Senator Hamer, a very experienced senator and a very skilled debater. It is interesting to look at his solutions to the problems. He said that there are all sorts of problems for Australia, yet we allow ourselves wage increases. He went on to say that Singapore workers had taken a 16 per cent wage cut. From that I take it that he means there should be a wage cut for Australian workers.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter of public importance was brought before the Senate by the Opposition which says, quite correctly, that we should do as much as we can for those people without houses. The one positive suggestion that has been put forward by inference is that there should be a 16 per cent wage cut so that a person who is on $400 a week will get $64 less before he or she pays tax. How can the Australian dream be attained-that is, how can a person obtain a house-when it appears that the Opposition's policy is, first of all, to cut wages by 16 per cent? How will that help somebody to buy a house? Secondly, it has been said that something should be done for housing. We say that of course something should be done. But what is the Opposition going to do about it? The question that has been properly raised is: What about taxation policy? We are still waiting for the Opposition's taxation policy. It is clear from what the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has said that there will be great cuts in the taxes that are presently imposed upon the Australian people. The fringe benefits tax will go, the deductibility of entertainment expenses will be reallowed and the capital gains tax will go. These changes will cost $18 billion-$18 billion worth of promises. The only way they can be paid for and the only thing we can surmise, given the fact that nothing definite has been stated, is that a consumption tax will be imposed upon the Australian people. So far the Opposition's program has taken $64 a week from the person on a wage of $400 a week-to overcome the fact that it apparently thinks that the people of this country are being paid too much-and having done that it will then impose a consumption tax. This tax will, no doubt, be placed on everything that is needed to build a house-the timber, the nails, the windows, et cetera.

The proposition put so far is that we reduce wages and we increase the price of houses by imposing a consumption tax. Apparently that is the policy that has been put forward by the Opposition. That sort of approach, that attitude, that climate which would be created, probably indicates why, under the previous coalition Government, only 105,000 homes were commenced in 1982-83. When this Government came to power this figure was increased to 152,700 in 1984-85. I do not want to avoid the next figure, which shows that in 1985-86 only 136,000 homes were commenced in Australia. That is the figure that Senator Boswell cited. He said that there was a decrease between the 1984-85 period and the 1985-86 period. That is quite correct. But the interesting thing is that the Opposition, in putting the argument, in order to show a fall, had to refer to periods during this Government's time in office. It was unable to compare periods during the previous Government's time in office. When that is done, it indicates there has been a massive increase in the number of homes built. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was able to say, in answer to a question yesterday, that there has been a 42 per cent real increase in public housing funds since the Government came to office. He was able to say that by June this year we will have enabled the best part of a quarter of a million home owners to be assisted into home ownership by the first home owners scheme.

The Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr West, referred yesterday to the March housing package that he produced. Of course, that was not dealt with by the Opposition in this debate. Nevertheless, in that package the 13.5 per cent ceiling on loans made before April 1986 was preserved. The bank reserve asset ratio requirement was reduced from 15 to 13 per cent. As I understand it, more money-about $900m-will be released to the banks and will be available for housing finance, if the banks so choose. Does the Opposition object to that? Does it object to this Government releasing an amount of $900m to the banks so that they can direct it to home loans if they so desire? This Government has increased the income limits for the first home owners scheme. The Government has made a commitment to provide $700m a year for housing finance over the next three years by way of grants through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

Those are some positive things that this Government has done, and that it will do in the future. I contrast that with the policy put forward today of reducing real incomes of people and adding to the burdens of building a home by increasing consumption tax. That is the proposition that has been put forward today. Indeed, that was the approach that was taken from the start. Senator Alston, who opened this debate, said during his speech that interest rates will burn this Government out of office. It seems, therefore, that this debate was not aimed so much at showing concern for home owners; it was a matter of trumpeting prematurely a hoped for victory at the polls. That is a political approach that people might take.

It may seem that the concern that Senator Alston was showing for home owners does not, as it were, go beyond-and in fact carries less weight in his mind than-the fact that he is keen to see this Government thrown out of office, and that any way in which it can be thrown out, through interest rates or what have you, is a good thing. We on this side of the chamber take a different view. Our concern is for the people who are without homes, those people whom Senator Boswell described, those people who-and it is a scandal for the nation-do not have homes and who must live in caravan parks and in cars. The fact is that these people who are without homes or who have sub-standard housing are placed under stress and strain that leads to the break-up of marriages and all sorts of problems with children. We on this side are concerned about that. We do not seek to make political points as did Senator Alston with his trumpeting call that interest rates will burn the Government out of office. That was his triumphal cry. We do not make that cry. We take the point that there is a need for housing and we are doing something about it.

The other point I want to make about Senator Alston's speech is this: He begrudged the $7,000 given to the Tenants Union so that it could hold a national conference. On the one hand he criticises this Government for not doing enough about housing, for not showing enough compassion and for not trying to help people who are in need of homes; yet, on the other hand, when $7,000 is allotted to the Tenants Union so that it can hold a national conference to see what can be done about this problem, he criticises the Government in the most trenchant terms. Where is the Opposition's heart when it takes that approach to this very serious problem? Indeed, it is one of the great problems faced by this nation.

Senator Hamer said: `Of course, when one takes an approach on the question of housing, one must look at it in terms of general macro- economic policies'. That is correct. That is the way in which it should be approached at a particular level. There should not only be concern to see that money is put into housing, but also the situation should be arranged so that people can afford to buy their own homes, so that they can achieve that great dream which is in all of our hearts, so that that happy state is achieved in which everybody is able to buy a house. Of course, that should be done and that is what this Government is doing in terms of its economic policies. It has reduced taxes. The coalition was not able to achieve that. It has brought down the rate of tax at the top marginal level from 60c to 49c. People earning $12,600 and below will have to pay only 24c in the dollar. It has reduced the rate of tax. At a time when billions of dollars have been cut from the amount of money coming to this country, it has succeeded in bringing some equity to the adjustments that have been needed in the community.

Much of this debate has arisen because of a matter that was raised yesterday by the Real Estate Institute of Australia. It berated, by inference, the Government for the housing situation. That position was met by people who are independent of this Government. It is worth quoting some of the things they said, as set out in an article on page 5 of the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 11 May. The article reads:
The Australian Bankers Association executive director Mr Alan Cullen said many of the State increases were due to higher housing prices, not higher home loan interest.

Of course, the Government cannot do anything about the price of houses; the private sector looks after that matter. It is very much at the heart of the Opposition's policies. It believes that free market forces should operate. What does it say if the price of houses goes up? Does it say that they should or should not go up? That, of course, was not answered by Opposition senators today. The article continues:
The banks have not been witnessing any shortage of housing funds or home loan customers.
It is worth repeating that statement: The banks have not been witnessing any shortage of housing funds or home loan customers. It continues:
And while Mr Howard's-
the Leader of the Opposition's-

statement yesterday used data compiled by the Housing Loan Insurance Corporation which showed 81 per cent in home loans in arrears in the second half of 1986 compared with the same period in 1985, Mr Cullen-
I remind listeners that Mr Cullen is the Australian Bankers Association executive director-
said few people were defaulting on home loans, or asking their banks to reschedule their home-loan repayments.

In referring to that article in the Australian Financial Review, I do not want to belittle the real problems, the heartbreaks and the concerns of many because of the fact that housing of adequate quality is not available to them. If we are to look at this question of housing, let us look at it in a realistic fashion. Let us look at it in terms of the correct figures, and let us look at it with compassion, not in a political, point-scoring way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston has submitted that the Senate consider:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous effects of Labor's high tax and high interest rate policy on home ownership by Australian families.

This Government was re-elected on a promise of tax and social reforms which would stimulate the economy and provide employment, abolish poverty traps and provide shelter and housing for all Australians. Its promises are like the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. They have not materialised and will not materialise. We all know how the Government lost its nerve at the National Taxation Summit. We have all seen the downturn in the economy which we have suffered since then. By now we all recognise that this is a Government pre-occupied with corporate welfare rather than with social and individual welfare for all Australians.

In an attempt to maintain apparent buoyancy in the economy and to keep money flowing into Australia, the Government has adopted a policy of appeasement towards outside financial and media powers. It is using high interest rates to attract foreign investment funds into Australia. It is turning a blind eye to the disastrous effects that these high interest rates are having on the Australian internal economy, particularly on our balance of external trade, and on housing moneys. The result of the large capital inflows is a rise in the value of the Australian dollar. This makes our exports uncompetitive with those of other export competing nations. It also encourages imports rather than allowing the natural market forces to stimulate local production.

The Government's imported nightmare of high interest and low productivity, coupled with the rapacious tax regime that the Government applies to individuals rather than to companies, means the death of the great Australian dream-a home of our own. High interest rates send small businesses and farming enterprises over the brink into bankruptcy and desperation. High interest rates mean that unemployment once again is soaring and takeovers are reaching a record level, while home building is depressed. High interest rates divert savings away from productive investments and housing into speculative ventures on financial and property deals and on the share market. It is not necessary for internal interest rates to mirror the external interest rates which are applied in Australia.

High unemployment and high housing costs have pushed government expenditure to record levels. This is being paid for by those still working, by increasingly harsh taxation which is falling more and more on lower income earners. The Government has also failed to come to grips with tax reform. For country people, the problem is even greater. Some of them are even losing their family homes under the current regime. The first home, however large, is free from capital gains tax yet the option of even owning a small place is denied to young Australians starting up in the work force because of high interest rates and impossible loan repayments. In fact, the Government has failed in the principles of good business management-of the conservation of resources and assets, of minimising costs and of providing proper incentives for the people in Australia incorporated. The Government is not providing enough money for people to live well, own a house and raise a family. This dream-the dream of a home of your own-will disappear into the distance like the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement relating to the tourism industry, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion relating to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
I rise today to make a ministerial statement on a matter of major importance not only to members in this Parliament but to all Australians who have an interest in the future of their country.
I refer of course to the tourism industry. I guess in some ways this is an analysis of the Hawke Government's five year stewardship of this industry.

It is difficult to overstate the importance of tourism to the national economy. This year alone tourism will contribute $24,000m to our gross domestic product, making it our largest industry in turnover terms.
Tourism will also contribute almost three thousand million dollars in foreign currency income to Australia.
The tourism industry is now growing at a spectacular rate and currently employs more than 405,000 Australians in a huge variety of occupations scattered over the whole country.
This of course makes it the largest individual employer in the nation.

However, this bright picture of tourism is in stark contrast to the dismal shambles we inherited when coming to office in March 1983. For the whole of the Fraser Administration, tourism had been neglected and the industry was expected to struggle along by itself.

The Department of Tourism having, been set up by Frank Stewart in the Whitlam Government from 1972 to 1975, had been dismantled and tourism was conducted in the Fraser years by a handful of people working virtually out of a cupboard in the Department of Industry and Commerce. Thus the potential that Australia had in tourism was neglected. In my three years as a shadow Minister in the Labor Opposition prior to coming into office in 1983 I realised the extraordinary potential that Australia had in the tourism industry and set about producing a document `The Future of Tourism in Australia' which eventually became the Labor policy for tourism for the 1983 election.

This paper set out a series of moves dedicated to turning what was then a fragmented enterprise into a major integrated industry. In hindsight the decisions that we took in opposition were correct, because what has happened since we implemented this blueprint for the industry is that tourism is now the biggest industry in Australia. Not only has the Commonwealth Government become active in the promotion of tourism but the State governments, which were as moribund as the Federal Government in that period prior to 1983, have now also become very actively involved as well.

The document that we put together pointed to four main areas that needed attention if Australia were to become a tourism force. They were (1) promotion, (2) incentives for development, (3) incentives for overseas investment and (4) staff training. There were other related changes which were also included in that document. All of which have been implemented and all of which have become integral parts of the sophistication of this hugely successful industry.

I would like to draw the attention of the House to the moves we made in these four main areas and how these threads, having been drawn together gave this industry the opportunity to develop into the major concern it has now become. First of all, promotion.

The Australian Tourist Commission formed in the late 1960s had achieved some recognition in the time of the Whitlam Government. However under the Fraser Government it was almost wiped out. Denied funding staff and resources.

The need to promote Australia overseas is of course fairly obvious. Australia was the best kept secret in the world and with all we had to offer we really needed to promote Australia as a holiday destination.

Funds for the tourist commission under this Government have been trebled from ten million to thirty million dollars and of course this enabled us to fund the very successful Paul Hogan series of commercials which have revolutionised the promotion of Australia overseas, particularly in the United States.

Prior to 1983 the number of international tourists visiting Australia was 950,000 per year with 1.4 million Australians travelling overseas every year in desperation because of the lack of proper facilities in Australia. In 1987 we will have 1.7 million visitors to Australia, and in 1988 2.2 million which is a huge increase over the 950,000 which I mentioned was our figure for international tourism in 1983. Replacing the old kangaroo-koala duumvirate with a new human face for Australia has obviously been a master stroke.
On the reverse side of the coin more Australians than ever are choosing to stay at home.

The need for the building of infrastructure was fairly obvious. In the Budget of 1983, the Government decided to increase the depreciation rate on buildings for the tourist industry from two and a half to four per cent. The stimulative effect of this initiative is now very clear. The face of tourism infrastructure in Australia has been revolutionised. In those four years from 1983 to 1987 one only has to look at cities like Sydney or Melbourne, or particularly the tourism areas of Queensland from the Gold Coast north to see exactly the effect this has had. At the present time we have almost eight thousand million dollars worth of infrastructure being built for the tourism industry in Australia.

These changes mean that we can now bring international tourists to Australia confident that the infrastructure they will find in terms of hotels, motels, resorts, and restaurants is the envy of the world and of course this has had a marked effect on getting Australians to holiday at home. They no longer have to travel to Fiji, Hawaii, Bali or other places offshore in order to find the splendid array of facilities that are now here on their own shores.

Prior to 1983 there were very strong disincentives for overseas investment in Australia but this Government in its wisdom has eased the guidelines and now we are allowing foreign investment in Australia to 100% equity in the provision of tourism infrastructure. The effect of this has been quite miraculous with particularly the Japanese being heavily involved in investment in tourism. The benefit of having the Japanese of course is once they build facilities here they spend a great deal of their own time and energy in attracting Japanese to come here and use them.

On the fourth issue of course, it was useless developing a tourism industry of some size in Australia unless we could staff the facilities. Prior to 1983 it was very difficult to convince bright young Australians who had completed their schooling that tourism was a proper career for them. There was mistaken belief that to be in the service industry in Australia one had to be at least obsequious and probably servile. I am pleased to note that these attitudes have changed and now we have in Australia a marvellous reservoir of very well trained, well equipped young Australians entering this glamorous industry.

Education authorities all around Australia have responded to the change and we now have emerging a splendid array of hospitality schools either in the TAFEs, the CAEs, the universities, and even in the schools where young people now have an opportunity to be trained to the highest level for the very skilled and glamorous jobs that exist in this industry.

So those four main areas-promotion, incentive for development, incentive for overseas investment and training have all been put into place. The success that we are having with tourism in Australia at the minute is not necessarily the result of a decreased value of the dollar or the success of the Paul Hogan campaign. The product we are selling has not altered dramatically since 1983. The beaches are no more beautiful now than they were. The wonderful climate is the same. The blue skies are the same. The free and easy life style is the same. The friendliness of Australians is still the same. But what has happened is that this industry is at long last recognised for what it is-a great contributor to the Australian economy as a result of government leadership.

To examine our commitments and achievements in detail it is necessary to look first at the changes that have occurred since March 1983. A number of important measures have taken place in line with our promotional commitments. The first of these was to increase the budget for the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) by 200%. This was a major step in inspiring confidence in the minds of investors and developers and also led to the phenomenally successful Paul Hogan television commercials, which I mentioned earlier. I think it is fair to say that Hogan has made Australia the flavour of the decade in the United States. And now Crocodile Dundee has reinforced this image right around the world. Australia now has an international profile that we could not have dreamed of prior to 1983. The Hogan campaigns (scoffed at by allegedly sophisticated critics at their inception) are now universally recognised as the most successful tourism marketing exercise the world has seen.

The Government also introduced the tourism overseas promotional scheme (TOPS) to assist the industry in its international product marketing efforts. This has encouraged private operators to build on the great promotional efforts of the ATC with financial rebates for advertising and other marketing expenses incurred overseas promoting the Australian product.

As a further innovative step, I introduced an annual program for national tourism awards. These awards encourage excellence within the industry and also make a major contribution to heightening public awareness of the importance of tourism as a whole.
A number of subsidiary measures were also introduced. For example:
Sales tax on certain cruise vessels was removed (backdated to the implementation date of August 1981), to provide a boost to the tourism and boat-building industries.
We have provided a special subsidy towards the cost of diesel fuel used for power generation by off-shore tourist resorts within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park region.
We have approved international or charter flights where it has been shown that they will promote a genuinely ``new'' market.

We have agreed to a program for the accelerated development of visitor facilities and infrastructure in Kakadu National Park and, as a part of its management objective for the Uluru National Park, helped to facilitate the development of the Yulara tourist resort on the perimeter of the park.
We have introduced lower air fares for domestic travel.
We have provided $26 million for the purchase and modification of a replacement Bass Strait ferry of doubled capacity and for associated terminal upgradings.

The Australian land transport program was introduced on 1 July 1985, providing to date almost $1.5 billion for construction and maintenance of roads, mainline railway upgrading, road safety and research.
Standard registration of travel agents.
Duty free shopping for return passengers.

In the area of training this Government has addressed the long term needs of the industry. Without trained staff, the viability of tourism as a major earner for foreign exchange would be jeopardised. We need to have in this country a system whereby young people can look forward to rewarding careers in the tourism industry. Accordingly we have commissioned and now released for public discussion the Sprokkreeff report. This most valuable document clearly identifies the problem areas in tourism training needs and makes constructive suggestions as to how we should go about remedying these deficiencies. This report is also being considered by my colleague the Minister for Education. I might add that even without the benefit of the Sprokkreeff Report, there has been a huge upsurge in the number of jobs available to young Australians who are looking for a career in the tourism industry.

In the short term, the Government has actively used the Community Employment Program, administered by my colleague, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to boost tourism projects and also to increase job opportunities in this most rewarding area.

Up until 1983 the development of hotels, resorts and casinos was haphazard and occurred in a climate of government disinterest. The turnaround since that time has been truly remarkable. This Government, for the past four years has done everything in its power to foster and encourage the development of tourism across the entire nation. Rather than sit on our laurels, as outstanding as they may be, we have embarked on a marketing strategy to expand the variety of experience holidays available in Australia. Sport, culture, excitement, heritage, wilderness, are just some of the headings that spring to mind.

Our vision for the future includes an awareness program highlighting our museums, art galleries and theatres and a vast variety of extremely high quality resorts with a uniquely Australian flavour. Every week I hear of new and exciting proposals that are about to get under way that will offer visitors to Australia holidays far more luxurious and exciting than they can get anywhere else in the world. This is obviously the way forward for this country.

What we will seek to do in an environmentally sensitive way is to give international visitors, and our own domestic tourists, greater access to the beautiful and remote parts of the continent. Our aim is to provide facilities that will give people access to these areas but we will do this in a way which will not harm the sometimes fragile environment or detract from it in any way. We have learned well that tourism and environmental protection can be harmonised with sensitive development.
We are also examining the requirements for visa entry to Australia, and it is my personal hope that we might be able to ease the current restrictions.

While the Government can look at its record with pride, the Opposition must be truly embarrassed by the total absence of policy development which has occurred during the past four years. All that the Opposition can offer the industry is a demand for greater private sector investment. It would appear from this that the Opposition has learnt nothing from the Government's highly successful multi-layered approach to the development of the industry.

A continuing narrow-minded theme in the Opposition statement on tourism is an attack on industrial relations. It is worth putting on public record the fact that in the last four years there has not been a single strike within the tourism industry itself, though industrial action has indirectly hurt the trade. Furthermore the bogey of penalty rates has not stopped the huge upsurge in tourism development, and it is acknowledged that the quality and costs of service in Australia compare favourably with most other countries. In fact despite what appear to be generous hourly rates of pay many tourists are delighted to return to Australia because we do not have the insidious system of obligatory tipping.

I have said on several occasions that Australia is now the tourism success story of the Western world. The most recent OECD report confirms this view. Released in Paris on the 9th of March, this report states that Australia has recorded easily the world's strongest growth in international visitor numbers for 1985-86-up 23 per cent, against an OECD average of a mere 1 per cent.
While most other industrialised countries have remained stagnant Australia is surging ahead, and the best is yet to come.

Interestingly, according to the OECD figures the next most successful country after Australia is Canada. The OECD report indicates that the staging of Expo '86 in Vancouver played a major part in boosting visitor numbers to that country. This is very welcome news for Australia in general and Brisbane in particular. Expo '88 will be a major international drawcard, along with many other facets of our bicentennial celebrations.

All the statistics indicate tourism will continue to grow and benefit the whole economy. Many members might not be aware of the number of overseas visitor arrivals. Before the Hawke Government came to power, Australia had never received one million visitors during a calendar year. But thanks to the policies of this government, growth has been spectacular:
I am confident that we will easily eclipse our target of 2 million visitors next year.

It is estimated that each adult visitor spends on average around $1,440 in Australia, meaning that in the current year overseas tourists will spend over $2,300 million while here. This estimate excludes the earnings of Qantas and expenditure of foreign airlines, which amount to a further $1,200 million.

New Zealand remains our largest market (24% of total short-term visitors), followed by the USA (18%), the UK (12%) and Japan (11%). However, the Japanese market is growing so quickly they will soon be in third place.

As impressive as these figures are, it is important not to lose sight of the fact that 85% of the industry is composed of domestic travel and holidays. That is, Australians. Deciding to take their holidays in their own country. This part of tourism has also grown under this Government at about 3% per annum. Australians travelling within Australia will spend over 250 million nights away from home in 1986-87 involving a total expenditure of around $15 billion. A further 100 million day trips will account for an extra $3.4 billion of domestic tourism expenditure.

As well as assisting our balance of payments, the tourism industry has also given a major boost to employment. The Hawke government is immensely proud of having created 3/4 of a million new jobs since 1983. Some 70,000 of these have been in the tourism industry-a huge contribution. As more overseas visitors come here, and as more Australians holiday in their own country, so more jobs are created.

There is a misconception, however, that tourism will lead Australia towards an army of unskilled and semi-skilled people, with no future prospects. The truth of the matter is that tourism is providing real career paths for young school leavers who are voting with their feet into the industry. There is also a growing awareness and understanding that work and career in service industries, ought not to be regarded as servile in nature.

Let me give you an example. The Ryde College of Catering in Sydney reported a `football grand final' scramble for places in management courses for the hotel and tourist industries. People had started camping out the night before enrolments began; and while 400 young people were admitted to courses, another 800 were turned away.
Similarly the William Angliss College in Melbourne had more than 500 applicants for its diploma of hospitality and catering but only 96 students could be accommodated.

The picture is similar all over Australia. Young people have recognised the wide scope for a long term career in tourism, and are prepared to train for 3-4 years to seek positions in hotel and catering management, travel agencies, theme park management, and the airline industry, to name just a few of the avenues opening up to them.

As I mentioned earlier, a report has now been completed into staff training needs within the tourism industry. Undertaken by Mr Willem Sprokkreeff, Vice President Australia South Pacific, Hilton International, this report contains extremely valuable recommendations on how best to respond to these demands for trained staff by the burgeoning industry with international visitor arrivals increasing at around 20% annually, and major investment in new world class establishments, attention is focusing on the industry's ability to cope. This growth rate means each year up to 10,000 new jobs will be created each year from international tourism alone. As a nation we need to meet this challenge, to keep apace with the promotional activities being undertaken by other countries to capture the leisure and tourist dollar and the work of the Sprokkreeff committee will help the Government and industry do just that.

I should add that the problems associated with tourism tend to be ones of too much success rather than too little. Examples include too many passengers arriving early in the morning at Sydney airport. The design and outlay of our baggage collection and customs areas, too many people seeking accommodation, and an excess of organisations wanting to hold conventions in Australia. I can add other deficencies, such as a shortage of staff who speak Japanese, and a shortage of signs in the same language. These are all difficulties which the government is working to overcome.

Tourism's ascendancy has been obvious in many subtle and not so subtle ways. For example, I am reminded of early attempts by the media to denigrate the value of tourism by relegating tourism stories to the social pages or in flashy advertising supplements.

It is also immensely satisfying to see the beginnings of media debate on the subject. Are we doing enough for tourism? How can we provide incentives for tourism development? How can we best marry the needs and wants of environmental groups and tourism investors? There is now a clear recognition that tourism is this country's major industry. It is certainly the fastest growing and the more sophisticated media it now gets reflects this. Even political and economics writers are reporting on tourism related subjects.
A far cry indeed from longstanding media indifference and the `She'll be right mate attitude' that unfortunately confronted the industry and its commentators.

Analysis of data provided to my department by Cordell Building Publications indicates there were nearly two billion dollars worth of tourism projects commenced in the period April 1984 to September 1986. These constructions alone will provide around 12,000 part and full time jobs when completed and 54,000 man years of work during the construction phase.

In addition there are six billion dollars worth of tourism projects in varying stages of planning, with the potential to generate a further 40,000 part and fulltime jobs once operational, and some 130,000 man years of construction work.

Tourism is bricks and mortar, small business, electricity and power generation. Tourism relies on an enormous range of feeder industries and it is this multiplier effect that gives tourism a special place in well balanced economic planning.
Tourism represents a real future-we are not waiting for major structural adjustments to the economy, we are creating them.

I am not here to state that it is this government alone which has been responsible for the rise in tourism. I pay tribute to my State colleagues and their tourism authorities whose professionalism had done much to increase tourism to their regions.

However, it is the private sector which has really taken up the tourism challenge, in a climate created by the Hawke Government. The industry can be justifiably proud at its achievements, without handouts, protection or over-regulation.

Every overseas tourist who has spent a dollar here has assisted this country in reducing our foreign indebtedness. Also all Australians who have decided to take advantage of the development of our tourism industry-the better roads, better flight facilities, better developed hotels and motels are also assisting the maintenance of a strong Australian economy.
More importantly I believe the findings of the Australian Government inquiry into tourism-the Kennedy report-will become the blueprint for the future direction of Australian tourism.
The inquiry, which I commissioned in January last year, has produced a wide ranging report over the full gamut of issues which will affect Australia's tourism competitiveness in the years to come.

As a result of all the factors I have outlined I believe that the Hawke Government has set the stage so that Australia can truly aspire to be the tourism capital of the world. Certainly the pre-conditions are there-friendly people, a stable government, a great climate, wonderful scenery, and world class accommodation and catering. No other country can compete with us.
We are now taking ourselves, and the industry seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the tabling of the ministerial statement entitled `Tourism-Under Labor' by Senator Button on behalf of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown. This statement was tabled in the House of Representatives last Thursday and we welcome its presentation here today. The Opposition joins the Government in emphasising the importance of the tourism industry to Australia and the great need for us to do all that we can to develop that industry over the years ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: We live in a world in which many of our traditional exports and other areas of economic activity are suffering increasing cost and price pressures and many of those pressures will continue. Many people on the Government side, the Opposition side, in industry and in the community see the tourism industry as one of the real potential growth industries for this country-an industry that we will need increasingly to rely on for investment and employment and, in particular, for the correction of our horrendous balance of payments problem. So I stress at the outset our pleasure that a statement on this industry has been presented.

Having said that, however, I question very seriously the motivation of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism in making this statement. The statement first of all was to have been tabled and debated yesterday in this chamber. It was listed for yesterday's debate under the heading `Government Papers'. This would have meant that each speaker would have had no more than five minutes to talk to the statement and that in total the debate could not have exceeded half an hour. That is a pretty fair indication of what the Government thinks of this statement. Well might it not think much of it, because this statement is nothing more than a misguided attempt by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism to rehabilitate himself after a long period during which his reputation and standing as a Minister of the Hawke Government have fallen abysmally.

One has only to look at Mr Brown's record over recent months to see the parlous state into which his political standing has fallen. The litany of mistakes and errors that this Minister has been found out on is almost endless. In his portfolio he has fallen down on a number of vital questions, some of which I will come back to later in my remarks. He has fallen down on the vital question of penalty rates in the tourism industry. He has presided over a great expansion of his own bureaucracy and administration which has gobbled up funds which should have been going to much more productive uses in the areas for which his portfolio is responsible. He had an absolute disaster with his choice of the Director of the Australian Institute of Sport, which now fortunately has been rectified. He is suffering very severe problems regarding financial support for his much lauded tourism overseas promotional scheme. And, of course, on the personal front it has been brought home to the Australian public just what an enormous amount of money this Minister has cost the Australian taxpayer.

Since John Brown's appointment as tourism Minister, he has visited Athens twice, Bangkok, Budapest, Frankfurt, Hong Kong, London three times, Los Angeles twice, Milan, Moscow, New York twice, Rome three times, Paris, San Francisco twice, Tokyo twice-and it looks like a third visit is coming up in the next few months-and he has been to Vienna. The cost to the Australian taxpayer for that travel by a junior Minister of this Government is astronomical. For example, between March 1983 and June 1986 the Minister enjoyed three extended overseas trips over 93 days which cost the taxpayer $178,379. That works out to an average of $1,658 a day. On Mr John Brown's trip his accommodation and meals averaged $592 per day and his bill for car hire was $15,853, which included being at the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, I recall, when he hired a couple of Mercedes at a time and did not even turn up at half the official functions for which he had been sent to Los Angeles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now, now-steady.

—Senator Button knows that that is correct, and it is a very sad statement. More recently we saw the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism caught out on changing domestic air tickets when his wife cashed in a first class air ticket to allow his son to travel at government expense to the grand prix in Adelaide last year. Subsequently he repaid the amount-it was not a large amount-of $230. The Minister allowed his son to travel at government expense deliberately and knowing that it was in contravention of Remuneration Tribunal guidelines. Of course, in more recent days there have been other statements which I would regard as being of a quite unedifying nature in relation to Mr Brown-so much so that he has had desperately bad editorial treatment and coverage in the media over recent weeks. SPEECH.PARA: Can we really expect [Mr Brown] to promote anything except the uncultivated ocker-the very image we have been trying so hard to dispel?

I might add that the Minister says that it has been revolutionised because three years ago the Hawke Government built on the Fraser Government's allowance for depreciation of buildings and put the figure up from 2 1/2 per cent to 4 per cent. The next point the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has made that I wish to comment on is that more and more Australians than ever are choosing to stay at home, and that is one of the essential reasons why the tourism figures are looking good. Eighty-five per cent of the total tourism industry in Australia is concerned with domestic travel and accommodation. I welcome the increasing tendency of Australians to see more of their own country as well as travelling overseas, but to say that Australians are staying at home because of the policies of this Government is right for only one reason, and that is that the policies of this Government have changed the cost structures of overseas travel to such an extraordinary extent that it now costs an enormous sum to travel overseas.
—But your Leader agrees with that.
—That it is an enormous cost to travel overseas?
—No; he agrees with the changes which were made that have led to that. You know that, and you ought to. It is simply that you cannot get your act together over there.

—If the honourable senator is suggesting that the enormous fall in the exchange rate for the Australian dollar, coupled with the record high interest rates and record high inflation, both records relative to the rest of the world--
—They are not records relative to your government; they are nothing like it.

—If the Minister is saying that that is a credit to him and that a good reason for more Australians staying home is that they cannot afford to travel overseas, I will allow the Australian public to make a judgment on that matter.
—You had better make a judgment about you and John Howard. You are saying separate things again.

—The reason why there has been a growth of tourism and inward visitors to Australia is, very importantly, that change in the Australian dollar value which has made it so expensive for Australians to travel overseas. I am not suggesting for one moment that the exchange rate is all good or all bad, but it is an extraordinary omission by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism to fail to acknowledge that exchange rate changes rather than the bloated fine words with which he has come out have been the essential catalyst for the change that has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other things one could say about the statement; other speakers will no doubt pick some of those up. There are three aspects that I wish to comment on very quickly. The first relates to the tourism overseas promotional scheme, known as TOPS, which the Government introduced a couple of years ago. In the 1986-87 Budget $5m was allocated for that scheme. It has the general support of the Opposition, but what has happened now is that, because of a variety of things, including administrative incompetence on the Minister's part, there is, so I am advised, presently with his Department a huge backlog of applications for grants under this scheme which, if approved, would require $8m to $15m in 1987-88 even if no new applications are received during that period. That scheme is in a great mess. The Minister is aware of that. He has failed to give any lead at the moment as to how he is going to get out of that mess, and I think it is incumbent on the Minister, and I call on him to do so, to make an announcement at the earliest possible time on whether or not applications for TOPS grants now in the pipeline will get through. If he cannot give an answer on that, obviously a great deal of uncertainty will be created in the industry.

The other matter I wanted to touch on was the move of the headquarters of the Australian Tourist Commission from Melbourne to Sydney. This move has been imposed on the Commission by the Government, and it has been very strongly opposed by the Commission itself. The Commission put to the Kennedy inquiry into the tourism industry recently that its headquarters should not be moved to Sydney. The Government has chosen to ignore the Commission's wishes in that regard. The fact is that 70 to 80 per cent of the members of the Australian Tourist Commission head office in Melbourne have refused to make the move to Sydney. The dislocation costs, therefore, will be enormous. There has not been any firm indication of how much this move will cost when all those figures are totted up, but it will certainly run into many millions of dollars. The Minister himself has put a bottom line figure on it of over $3m, and that excludes any of the redundancy and other relocation costs. The Minister has not told us where that money will come from; nor has he told us what other programs of a worthwhile nature in the tourism industry will go by the board simply to meet the whim of that move.

Finally, I want to draw attention to the opportunities that are going begging for the further development of tourism in Australia through the failure of the Government and airlines to take advantage of the enormous potential in the area containing countries such as Korea and Taiwan, the failure to have direct air links between those countries and Australia and because of the great difficulties in both these countries in the processing of visa applications. I was in Taiwan recently and was given statistics which indicated that the loss of tourist income to Australia alone from Taiwan could amount to up to $400m each year. This loss is due to the lack of any direct air links between our two countries and the fact that visa applications cannot be processed in Taiwan; they have to be sent to Hong Kong, which causes great delays. This is therefore a major deterrent to the growth of tourism between our two countries.

The Minister's statement is, as I said at the start, a flamboyant attempt to rehabilitate himself in the eyes of his clientele. We welcome the fact that there is at last a statement on tourism to debate in this chamber, but we are very greatly concerned about and highly critical of the content of it.
