TALK.START.PARA: —When I was considerably younger than I am now and I got to skiting a bit, my parents would always bring me back into line by saying that self-praise is no recommendation. I had not thought of that for a long time until I read the statement that has been incorporated in the record of this chamber and was given earlier in the House of Representatives by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Hon. J. J. Brown. Nonetheless, this statement provides a good chance for the Parliament to look at the tourism industry and have a debate on it. The Minister has given some excellent statistics. None of us would deny that. For instance: Tourism will contribute $24 billion to the gross domestic product this year; the tourism industry currently employs 405,000 people; international visitors in 1986 numbered 1,418,000; the estimate for 1987 is 1,666,000; and currently $8 billion worth of infrastructure is under construction. It is estimated that each tourist spends $1,440 in Australia. So, for the current year, that gives us an income of $2.3 billion. That figure excludes the income from Qantas Airways Ltd and expenditure by foreign airlines which amounts to an extra $1.2 billion. There is no doubt that they are excellent statistics. On top of all that 85 per cent of the industry income is still derived from domestic travel and holidays.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's statement said that nothing was done by the Federal or State governments up until 1983. Then, hey presto, along came the Hon. J. J. Brown and the Australian Labor Party Government and the whole scene changed. Indeed, he even had the audacity to say that the States were moribund until then. I would just like to mention that, in my State, the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation was formed in 1979 under the quite exceptional and outstanding chairmanship of Sir Francis Moore, a good friend of mine. Quite interestingly, this Government has used the Deputy Chairman of the QTTC, Jim Kennedy, to write a report for it. So it seems that the Queensland tourism industry does have some standing. Also, I am sure that my colleagues from Tasmania, which State has relied on tourism for many years, would take great exception to their State-no matter under which government-being called moribund, because for many years Tasmania has been a tourist oriented destination for people from all around Australia as well as for international visitors. Nonetheless, according to this statement, hey presto, along came the Hon. J. J. Brown and the ALP Government and the whole scene was changed.

I admit that since 1983 the scene has changed. I must admit also that it has changed because of ALP policy. But it has changed because of its economic policy and not because of its tourism policy. Any victory that the Government claims is really a pyrrhic victory. The change is due to the J-curve, not because of the J. J. cure for our supposed tourism ills. It is all about the devaluation of the dollar. Indeed, I think that half way through the report the Hon. J. J. Brown did mention that the devaluation of the dollar has had an effect on the tourism industry. The tourism industry has taken the utmost advantage of the devaluation of the dollar. In other words, it is cheaper to come to Australia now than to go to many other destinations.

On top of that, there was the other aspect, particularly last year, of terrorism in Europe. Indeed, when I was part of a delegation that went to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Poland last year I spent some time in Great Britain, particularly London. It was quite noticeable that in the middle of Britain's tourist season there were very few-almost none-of the traditional tourists from the United States who are expected at that time of the year. Indeed, wherever one went it was commented on.

TALK.START.PARA: —And wasn't it nice?

—I must confess, it was. One could get in to see things that one wanted to see without having to get into those inevitable queues which I hate even in Australia. Nonetheless, two things contributed to the upturn of tourism in Australia and they had nothing to do with the so-called exploits of the Hon. J. J. Brown. Of course, the converse of that is the fact that Australian tourists-and my colleague Senator Short mentioned this-can no longer afford to go overseas; so they are stopping at home. It is no wonder that 85 per cent of Australia's tourist industry income comes about through domestic travel and accommodation. The one and only instance that the J-curve has really worked is in respect of the tourist industry. Thank heaven it has.

SPEECH.PARA: Concurrently with the dollar devaluation we saw an education process-a very necessary process that took a long time. It started to take effect among our tourist operators. In the first instance, they did not even try to understand that nobody else in the world has the same working conditions as the Australian worker, particularly when it comes to annual leave. Four or five weeks annual leave and 13 weeks long service leave are unheard of in other countries. Our tourist operators thought that, with a little bit of advertising, the world would beat a path to our door, and it took them a long time to learn what package deals were all about. They thought that an international airport at their front door would automatically bring tourists flocking in, and that did not work either. Australia probably has more international airports per head of population than any other country in the world-in some instances because of pork barrelling and in other instances because of the demographic situation that obtains in Australia. Nonetheless, at long last the operators started to learn from a hard educational experience the necessity of package deals. In other words, tourists will come in only with deals arranged by operators and by international airlines. They generally want to come in at one airport, stay in that area a couple of days, travel around and fly out from another airport.

That brings me to the subject of airports, which did not rate much of a mention at all in this tourism policy. It is no wonder that it did not rate a mention when one considers the inability of successive New South Wales governments to bite the bullet concerning the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and to take the necessary hard decisions in that regard. If that airport wants to remain one of the main entry and exit ports for tourists in Australia, it must face the absolute necessity right now for a second runway paralleling runway 16/34, albeit one that is shorter, to take domestic and commuter traffic. If construction of that runway began today, it would already be too late, yet the New South Wales Government has not been prepared to bite that bullet.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will build the second runway, will it? Is that clear? Do I get you right?

—If it were left to me, the second runway would be there now. That would be of absolute benefit to Sydney itself. As a Queenslander, I have often said that the best thing Queensland tourism has going for it is the Australian Labor Party Government in New South Wales, because when our airport is completed, Queenslanders will have another good alternative and will start dodging Sydney. In fact, they are doing that now and going to Melbourne, which Senator Ray would welcome. So we have that problem. We also have $20m being spent on the international terminal. Admittedly, the extension will enable more passengers to be handled, but they will not allow for one extra parking space for an international aircraft on the apron. Brisbane has a similar situation: A magnificent new airport is being opened there, but the international terminal will not be upgraded in the near future, so we will have an increasing log-jam at one of our major tourist destinations and exit points. That will not help the situation at all.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of that there is the curfew at Kingsford-Smith Airport. Talking with some of the international pilots, I find that when they come in late on runway 34, flying over Botany Bay, there is never any complaint; but if somebody mentions that an aircraft is to come in late at night for some reason, complaints are received. There is a generally accepted procedure for coming in-that pilots come in over Botany Bay, use runway 34, and do not use reverse thrust. That way, nobody is any the wiser. The sooner the Government bites the bullet on curfews and grasps the fact that modern aircraft with high bypass turbo-fans are considerably quieter than some of the turbo-prop aircraft that are allowed to operate out of curfew, the sooner our airports will be used to better advantage.

It has already been said that the new Brisbane Airport should be curfew free, and indeed it should. It has been built further towards the river mouth, towards Moreton Bay, and it cannot be built out. Any government that allows the old Brisbane Airport to be used for anything other than industrial use is not right in the head. The new airport should be curfew free.

The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) in the other place has already said that a curfew should be imposed. This airport was built specifically to be curfew free and, with the newer generation of aircraft operating, there is no need for a curfew to be put in place. Curfews result in underutilisation of resources and equipment, and it is not possible to keep air fares down when there is underutilisation of resources and equipment.

While on the subject of airports, I mention the matter of Customs inspection. I raise the question: Is it absolutely necessary? Is the Customs section at airports necessary at all? It has nothing to do with narcotics or anything like that. Narcotics law enforcement is entirely different. A major blockage is caused by the Customs inspection of things that one may be bringing in in one's luggage-gifts for friends or relatives and things for oneself. If a cost-benefit analysis were undertaken on the cost of maintaining Customs officers in those Customs halls in relation to the amount of revenue that is derived from them, I imagine that it would point up that we could well do without them. The Government should look immediately into the necessity for them as they are another major cause of hold-ups. Getting rid of them could indeed be another cost saving measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you did without them, would not the behaviour change?
—I do not think so; not at all-not from the information I have received. You are talking about narcotics.
—No, I am talking about the ordinary things that people bring into the country.

—I do not think so, for the simple reason that one has to be a pretty shrewd buyer today to do much better overseas than one can do in Australia. If one is in the market for a hi-fi or a camera for one's own use and knows what one is about, one can do a reasonable deal, but those who think tourists can do what they did 10 or 15 years ago by going overseas and buying a lot cheaper than in Australia are sadly mistaken. I really think that the Customs exercise is not worth the effort.

SPEECH.PARA: In his statement the Minister also mentions overseas investment. I welcome the Government's attitude towards overseas investment. Indeed, the Minister singles out Japanese investment for special laudatory comment. I find that quite strange. I remember taking part in debates in this chamber to defend the Iwasaki project outside my home town of Rockhampton. The condemnation at that time was quite trenchant; yet now the Minister is rightly welcoming overseas investment, particularly Japanese investment. As a matter of fact, the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has even played golf on the Iwasaki course. As against that, the Minister never mentions the Government impost on resorts-the fringe benefits tax, for instance, particularly when people who work on resorts have to have their accommodation supplied. He never mentions the sales tax on oils and lubricants, particularly when people are running their own boats and generating their own power. We had the excise on diesel fuel in relation to which the Government suddenly had to back off and provide a special subsidy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you abolish that, Senator?
—Fringe benefits tax? Sure.
—No, excise. Come on; tell us.

—We would certainly be reviewing the excise in the constraints of the mess that we will take over from the Government. We will be trying to get sales tax exemptions on oils and lubricants for all primary producers and tourist operators. The Minister, quite rightly, talked about the courses being offered at colleges of technical and further education and colleges of advanced education. I can only commend that. Already, as most of us know, the TAFE institutions have courses on catering and tourism. Indeed, some of us in our careers have probably had meals at some of those establishments which offer catering courses. The Capricornia Institute of Advanced Education, in my home city of Rockhampton, wants to offer a bachelor of arts course majoring in tourism, with external courses to be offered at both Mackay and Gladstone. The sooner those courses can be accredited the better. The Institute wants the course to relate particularly to policy and management. Heron Island is just off Gladstone; Rockhampton has the Great Keppel Island and Iwasaki resorts; and Mackay is one of the major gateways to the Whitsunday resorts.

SPEECH.PARA: For some unknown reason in this attempt to gather unto himself all that he can, the Minister mentioned the Uluru National Park. I do not know why he did that. The Opposition was, and still is, quite critical of the handing over of the Uluru National Park. If it is a national park, we believe that it belongs to all Australians. In this instance, it has been handed over to an organisation, not to a clan that has a right to it. There are restrictions on entry because of that. The Minister also mentioned that for some time there have not been any strikes in the tourist industry. What is the airline industry if it is not a major contributor to our tourist policy? Last week anybody who wanted to travel by Ansett Airlines of Australia was affected by strikes and disruptions. I understand that on Anzac Day, which was a Saturday, refuellers would not refuel aircraft in Brisbane for the simple reason that they were not going to get an extra public holiday because Anzac Day did not fall on a weekday. They had one anyhow. Such is the mentality of some of the people-I say, advisedly, some-in the trade union movement. It rings a bit hollow when the Minister lauds the fact that there have been no strikes in the tourist industry.

I can only commend the Minister for his comments on tipping, which is one of the most degrading aspects of the tourism industry-particularly accommodation and restaurants-when one goes overseas. We know that tipping was brought in overseas for the simple reason that wages were quite low. Now a service charge is added, whether or not one has had good service. I think such a practice is degrading. I tell my friends from overseas not to tip at any place here because they think they should automatically do so. If people get good service they can go ahead and tip, but they should not think that they have to do so automatically. It is a degrading habit. For a long period most people working in the accommodation and restaurant areas have been paid an adequate wage.

Ironically, the Minister mentioned Expo 88. I do not blame him for doing that. We will have a great Expo in Brisbane, but the Labor States have not yet indicated whether they wish to take part. I am the chairman of a committee that will be conducting an air race around Australia next year. As well as 1988 being our Bicentenary, it is the diamond jubilee of Hinkler's flight from London to Darwin, Kingsford-Smith's flight across the Pacific Ocean and the founding of the Royal Flying Doctor Service. We wish to commemorate all those events and at the same time raise money for the Royal Flying Doctor Service. The race will finish in Brisbane over Expo the day after Expo opens. It will be a tremendous race.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be working as a shadow Minister instead of running that sort of thing. We have a lot to do.

—We are trying to talk the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), who is now a pilot, into taking part, and indeed he is attracted to it. The Hogan advertisements and Crocodile Dundee came out at about the time of the devaluation. I have written to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) about the education of our tour operators and incoming tourists in respect of crocodiles. We have had unnecessary tragedies, and we will have more. The Australian newspaper on, I think, Easter Saturday contained a photograph of a tour operator encouraging crocodiles in the wild to jump to take meat off a stick beside a tourist boat. That is terrible. One can imagine what would happen if crocodiles in that estuary or inlet were in the vicinity of a family member in a 12-foot aluminium boat who was pulling in a fish. I do not need to say what could be the result. That conduct by the tourist operator concerned is most reprehensible. We should educate our tour operators and incoming tourists on how to treat these reptiles in the wild. They are territorial and predatory animals. The female, particularly at nesting time, has very strong maternal instincts. All of this adds up to operators and tourists becoming targets in accidents that should never happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I wrote to the Minister on 1 April-I have not yet received a reply-indicating that something should be done. I even nominated a person who would be prepared to help. That person is certainly the Australian, if not the world, expert on crocodiles. He is Mr John Lever who runs a crocodile farm near Rockhampton. His expertise, together with that of National Parks and Wildlife Service officers in the States and Territories, should be used to put together a tourist package so that operators and tourists are educated as to the lifestyle and the habits of these prehistoric reptiles. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of that letter which I sent to the Minister. I have sought permission from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) who is at the table.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
1 April 1987
Hon. Barry Cohen, MP,
Minister for Arts, Heritage
and Environment,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
My dear Minister,

I would like to commend your action in suggesting that there should be a campaign to engender more public awareness as to the dangers of entering crocodile infested areas and that there should be penalties imposed on persons ignoring safety signs to this effect.

In addition to your proposed measures, I would suggest that tour operators be involved in a ``Never smile at a crocodile'' campaign. This could involve an education package to include a video presentation on the habits and habitats of crocodiles and the dangers of becoming too ``friendly'' with them or intruding into their territory. It has become evident that tour operators need to be actively discouraged from attracting these dangerous reptiles for tourist viewing by constantly feeding them or trailing meat over the side of the boats. The package could act as a deterrent to tourists if shown to them in a simplified form with associated written briefing material prior to their embarking on excursions.

Such a program should be developed in conjunction with the National Parks and Wildlife Service, drawing on the experience of those officers from the States or Territory with crocodile populations who have knowledge of the habits of these animals. I suggest that Mr John Lever be invited to participate in the team formulating this package as he is the most recognised authority in Australia-if not the world-on crocodiles and their characteristics. As you probably know, Mr Lever is the owner/developer of the Koorana Crocodile farm at Cawarral near Rockhampton and obviously has many years' expertise in all aspects of crocodile behaviour. In fact, I understand that he has already produced such a video for the use of tour operators.

If these operators, as well as tourists, are made acutely aware of the dangers of flirting with crocodiles, perhaps we could reduce the incidence of serious accidents and fatalities such as those reported recently. Eight deaths in the short space of two years is not a statistic to be taken lightly. As reported on the ABC's ``AM'', these attacks are not the fault of crocodiles-they are just doing what comes naturally.
I would be happy to discuss this matter with you further.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I take this opportunity to clarify an answer and correct what was perhaps a misleading impression that I may have given in Question Time today on a subject that is only faintly related to tourism, one about which I hoped I would never have to speak again, and that is flights over Tasmania. SPEECH.PARA: All the information that is available to me from the offices of the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment leads me to categorically deny it. I am happy to do that.

I have been told by the office of the Minister for Defence that two RAAF HS748 aircraft from Sale overflew the Lemonthyme area on routine navigational training flights which had been planned for a long time. TALK.START.PARA: —It is part of Australia and you can fly over it.

—It is part of Australia and such flights fly over all parts of the country, particularly interesting parts of the country, at all sorts of times. SPEECH.PARA: I do not think the Senate has been misled in any relevant respect and certainly I had no intention whatsoever to do so. Lest anyone should think there is any ground for concern about what I said, I hope I have put the record straight once and for all. I repeat the categorical denial that any RAAF plane was requested or tasked for the purposes of observation related to the current Lemonthyme and Southern Forests inquiry. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am an expert on tourism because I am a tourist who came to Australia and stayed here. I probably have a different outlook from many on tourism because I appreciate Australia for what it is. I was attracted to Australia, as are many people in America, by the natural Australia, not the built environment. America has tall buildings. If I had wanted to see tall buildings I could have stayed in Los Angeles. Tall buildings did not attract me. Basically it was the Australian environment which attracted me and which attracts most tourists to Australia. I do not think the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism and the officials in general appreciate this fact.

SPEECH.PARA: In Hobart, Robin Gray our Premier is now pushing a large hotel development right on the waterfront. He went into a glass-sided building in Japan and he was very impressed with it-he is a small town boy from Victoria who has made good in Tasmania-so he decided that Tasmania needed one of those buildings on its waterfront. He steamrolled this idea over the heads of members of the Legislative Council, over all of the local planning appeals boards and he came up with a ghastly design. It was considered too much even in Tasmania so he had to pull in his horns. He then created a lesser monstrosity-it is still a monstrosity-which he hopes will attract international tourists. It will not-it is a mistake. What Australia and Tasmania have to offer is the natural environment and yet the Gray Government, which ostensibly is trying to attract tourists, is cutting down all our trees. It is allowing trees to be cut down by the woodchip industry and the loggers in Tasmania.

Tourists are not coming back and tourist operators are saying that they are losing business because of the woodchipping. Not only are the forests disappearing, which is bad enough, but the tourists are in great jeopardy through the logging operations. Every year numbers of tourists are killed by log trucks. Log trucks are being driven by people who were promised great returns from the logging industry when they contracted to buy their trucks but now they are struggling to make a buck. They are working 18 hours a day and they hit tourists and Tasmanians head on. Of course the resulting confrontation is generally lethal for the tourists or motorists. Roads are also being broken down by the log trucks and tourist operators, the people who are trying to promote tourism in Tasmania, are concerned.

At the moment the mining industry in Australia is pushing a major campaign to have access to national parks. As a person from America, I find it absolutely incongruous that Australia can create a national park such as the Kakadu National Park which has a mining industry incorporated in it, namely, the Ranger mine. The mining industry wants more; it wants access to all land in Australia even though it has access to about 95 per cent of it. Honourable senators should look at what mining has created as a tourist attraction in Tasmania-Queenstown. The Queenstown people call Queenstown the technicolour hills because the hills are completely devoid of any vegetation-this is as a result of the mining industry-and they think it is a tourist attraction.

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred years ago it was a smelter.

—Senator Newman says that that was 100 years ago. What about what is flowing down the Queen River right now? It is pollution; thousands and thousands of tonnes of mine waste are going down that river along with sewage. Attitudes in Tasmania-as they are expressed by Senator Newman-have not changed in 100 years. People there do not want tourists in Tasmania. Even now if a mainland tourist with a beard and wearing a check shirt went to Queenstown he would be in danger of getting his teeth knocked down his throat. If mainland tourists said that they did not think the damming of the Franklin was a good idea, they would be scathed in Tasmania. This is a legacy of the Gray hate campaign which continues today. This campaign dates back to the time when the Hydro Electric Commission tried to remove a prime tourist attraction in Tasmania-the Franklin River. It tried to dam the Franklin River to remove it as a tourist attraction.

SPEECH.PARA: At present the Tasmanian Government-the Gray Government-is seriously saying that there should be tourist hotels on the Gordon River, at Port Davey and in other parts of Tasmania. The Gray Government is also pushing for commercial huts in national parks such as the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park, along the overland track. Commercial huts have no place in the environment and it once again brings out my point that the governments of Australia-I include State governments-do not appreciate our natural environment. However, things are starting to change and it is not because of governmental attitudes; it is because of the tourist operators. Queensland found that all the publicity over its loss of rainforests-it is still going on-has created a curiosity overseas. People want to see the rainforests, the beautiful remnants of what once covered the world, species that were alive when dinosaurs lived on this earth.

I went to Innisfail, which is in Queensland near Cairns, where a beautiful stand of rainforest called Downey Creek was threatened by logging and is now being logged. The local residents in Innisfail knew that if they logged the rainforest the logging industry would get a few jobs out of it, a few years worth of timber, but the tourist attraction would be gone forever. The local residents were against it-they realised that the sugar mills were closing down and they were looking to tourism. If honourable senators go to that area they will find that operators are capitalising on the rainforests. They are renaming their tours `Rainforest Tours' and their hotels and motels `Rainforest Motel'. This is what people want to see. The basic difficulty is that politicians and bureaucrats alike are locals in the eyes of the world and in reality. They are so accustomed to what exists in Australia that they do not see it as an attraction. Therefore in Tasmania we have tourist officials advocating things such as fibreglass dinosaur parks and those sorts of things to try to attract tourists. Tourists can see that sort of thing anywhere. They really want to see the natural environment.

In Tasmania the Gray Government is fond of saying: `Bushwalkers do not bring anything into the State but a shirt and a $10 bill and during their stay in the State they change neither'. That is absolutely false. The people who come to see the Tasmanian wilderness bring millions of dollars a year and they happily spend this money, yet the Government does not want to accommodate them in Tasmania especially the greenies. The official Government policy towards promoting the wilderness is slowly changing. The Government is starting to recognise its value but it still does not welcome it. The State Government's policy is still to penalise anyone in the tourist industry who was opposed to the construction of the dam. For example, Morrison Brothers, who run tours on the Gordon River, have had great difficulty in getting their brochures carried by the Tasmanian Tourist Bureau, whereas their opposition, which did support the dam, has no trouble at all getting its brochures carried. If one rings up the Tasmanian Tourist Bureau it will often say that there is only one cruise down the Gordon River, and that is the opposition's. The Bureau will not tell the public about the Morrison Brothers, who have laboured so long and hard to save the Franklin. They have been in business in Strahan for years, first as wood gatherers and later as tourist operators. They knew that a dam would ruin tourism in Strahan, and in fact it would have done so. Now Strahan is a thriving tourist venue in spite of the operations of the Gray Government.

I will tell the Senate what brought these matters home to me. I was beginning to get accustomed to Tasmania. During my previous incarnation as a member of the Tasmanian State Parliament, I was having lunch with the parliamentary librarian, Tom Pickering, who played as an accompanist to the famous singer Eartha Kitt when she was visiting Tasmania. She came to have lunch with Tom Pickering, who played in the Pearce-Pickering Jazz Band, and I invited myself along. Eartha Kitt said: `Gee it's dull at Wrest Point. What a plastic place; it's a kind of poor imitation of Las Vegas. I'm tired of playing squash and I don't drink'. She asked me whether there were any trails up Mount Wellington, which she could see out the window. I told her there were, and that I would show them to her. So at 7 o'clock the next morning I appeared in my old Datsun ute at Wrest Point and Eartha Kitt came out in a tracksuit. We hiked up Mount Wellington and she asked me: `Why don't they promote this?'. I might add that she was a very fit woman; I had trouble keeping up with her. When she got to the top of the mountain she looked around and said: `This is magnificent, this is what you should be promoting'. I asked her whether she would like too see more of Tasmania. She agreed. So for the next week when she was not working I took her flying over the south-west, which she thought was wonderful. I took her to Lake Gordon, which is part of the Hydro Electric Commission scheme, and which has dead trees sticking out of it. She asked me what had happened to the lake and why. I said: `Because the Government does not recognise the value of the local area for tourists'. And so it goes.

There is a growing trend around the world for tourism to take the form of people travelling at low cost through the community. People do not just want to go to another Holiday Inn like the one they just left in Dallas. They used to like that sort of travel because they were insecure but now people want to see the sights and talk to local people. Australia is falling down in this respect. We are not catering to this trend. Although these people do not want to spend a lot of money, they will lash out and spend if they have to. They have the money but they do not want to be ripped off. This country is not catering to that growing market. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) says on page 5 of his statement:

These changes mean that we can now bring international tourists to Australia confident that the infrastructure they will find in terms of hotels, motels, resorts and restaurants is the envy of the world and of course this has had a marked effect on getting Australians to holiday at home.
It may keep Australians at home but I do not think that tourists come here because of big hotels and lavish restaurants. The Minister goes on:

Prior to 1983 there were very strong disincentives for overseas investment in Australia but this Government, in its wisdom, has eased the guidelines and now we are allowing foreign investment in Australia to 100 per cent equity in the provision of tourism infrastructure. The effect of this had been quite miraculous with particularly the Japanese being heavily involved in investment in tourism. The benefit of having the Japanese of course is once they build facilities here they spend a great deal of their own time and energy in attracting Japanese to come here and use them.

Unfortunately, this tends to create Japanese ghettos. The Japanese stay in these Japanese developments and the profits go back to Japan. It is quite dangerous to allow any nationality to set up tourist developments here and attract tourists from the home country solely to that development. That is dangerous and it does not really benefit Australia all that much.
On page 9 the Minister pats himself on the back, as Senator Collard said. He probably has tennis elbow from doing so. He says:
We have introduced lower air fares for domestic travel.

The Government may or may not have done that. I have not noticed the air fares being much lower. If the Government is really interested in tourism it should bite the bullet and bring about the deregulation of the airline system. It should abandon forthwith and posthaste the two-airline system and allow competition on the scene so that we can have lower air fares and attract tourists. As it exists, the system is a club between the two airlines. It was almost a club between the three airlines, but East-West Airlines Ltd has recently changed its policy. It wanted a three-airline policy but now it is calling for deregulation. The sooner the Government deregulates the airline system the better for both tourists and people who live in this country.

We have talked briefly about Expo 88. I think it is a wonderful idea. The Minister for Tourism almost dropped the ball on that one. He was ready to grant a very lucrative contract to an American firm to run an audio-visual display at Expo 88. A person who was supposed to be advising the Minister turned around and, with confidential information, bid on the system. He almost got the contract but there was a public outcry and now I am happy to say-and I think this is known-that an Australian firm has got this $3m contract for the audio-visual display at Expo 88. I think it will do an excellent job.

Tourism is an important industry, not only from the economic view but also environmentally. Wisely used, tourism can co-exist happily with the conservation of the environment. However, it cannot exist happily if we have as open slather an idea about it as we do about resource development. It may be possible to have tourism in some areas but others may be too sensitive. I know that I will be accused of locking things up if I urge that tourists be kept out but this is necessary. In the United States there are wilderness areas where one has to book years ahead if one wants to go in. The number of people who can go into such areas is limited. That has to be so because we can love an area to death as well as destroy it by mining, woodchipping and flooding. Tourism is a valuable adjunct to our economy. It could be even more important to Australia if the Government truly appreciated and promoted the natural assets of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —First I must say that I have an interest in tourism, having been a developer of colonial accommodation in Tasmania. I would not want to speak on this matter without that being clearly understood. It is interesting to hear Senator Sanders, another Tasmanian, speak on this subject. My State is very dependent on the tourist industry and obviously there will be a number of attitudes and views as to how we can best develop it. Tourism is very important throughout the country but particularly so in a State such as ours which is heavily dependent on tourism and which is very beautiful. We have different approaches to this topic and there is value in that. Nobody is all right about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very pleased to see that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) was prepared to put down a substantial statement on the tourism industry but in many ways I regard it as inadequate and misleading. Obviously this Government has succeeded very effectively in the promotion of Australia overseas. Obviously promotion runs in the Minister's family. Under his leadership the Government has done well promoting this country and I give it credit for that. The Minister said that there were four areas which needed attention if Australia were to become a tourism force. These were promotion, incentives for development, incentives for overseas investment and staff training.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was discussing the statement put down by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism on the current situation in the tourism industry in Australia. I think it is generally agreed by all parties that this is an extremely important industry for our nation, particularly because of its heavy involvement in employment for the young. The Minister in his statement said that there were four main areas which needed attention in order for Australia to be a tourism force: First, promotion; secondly, incentives for development; thirdly, incentives for overseas investment; and, fourthly, staff training. I said that I thought that the tourism situation in Australia at present is a very rosy one, and I hope and pray that it will continue to be rosy. But I must say that the Government's record on tourism is not as unflawed as we would be led to believe by the Minister's statement. I hope that I can demonstrate that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also to say that I think the Government has been very lucky. It was lucky in that it took office when the drought broke and overseas conditions changed so that Australia's economy was on the up. It has been a lucky government in the tourism field in particular. The Minister said that in 1987 we will have 1.7 million visitors to Australia, which is almost double the figure for 1983. Why is the Government so lucky? Why are there so many tourists flocking to our shores? We have been very lucky in the sense that we are benefiting from the terrorism which has been so rife overseas. Australia looks to be a very safe tourist destination. We are also lucky in the sense that our dollar is down. In the tourism sense we are lucky, firstly, because it is a cheap place for tourists to visit and, secondly, because it is very expensive for our own people to holiday overseas. So in a tourism sense we are doing well. The Government is lucky in that respect to take the credit, but I do not think it can take all of the credit.

Why are more Australians than ever choosing to stay at home for their holidays? What sort of holidays are they having? We know that because of the current economic situation in Australia-the high interest rates, the lack of spending power by Mr and Mrs Average Australian-people are forced to take their holidays in Australia and are not having the sort of holidays to which they may have been accustomed. I draw the Senate's attention to a report in the Launceston Examiner of 2 May, only last week, following a statement by the Tasmanian Visitor Corporation's General Manager, Mr David Phillips. The article stated:

. . . the number of budget tours visiting Tasmania was rising while the number on package holidays had fallen by 25 per cent in some areas. He said that the average downturn in visitor numbers to Tasmania was caused by the depression in the Australian economy coupled with aggressive marketing by mainland states.

Let us not forget that the overall downturn in visitor numbers to my State, caused by the depression in the Australian economy, has resulted in an increase in the number of budget tourists. They are still perhaps having their holidays, but they are not having the sort of holidays they used to have. In an article in the Advocate of Tuesday, 28 April, Mr Glenn Cocking, the Commonwealth Deputy Statistician, was reported as having stated:
. . . caravan parks had a slight increase in site occupancy rates for the December quarter last year . . . from the December quarter in 1985 . . .

People are having their holidays, but instead of the more glamorous ones, they are now taking the caravan option. That is what this Government has done to the tourism industry; that is what it has done to the Australian people. It has forced them to cut their cloth very tight indeed.

The Minister stated that the face of tourism infrastructure in Australia has been revolutionised. I agree that in many ways it has. But one of the things that concern me when we look at the face of tourism infrastructure and how it has been revolutionised is the great emphasis that has been placed on luxury beds in Australia. Over the last few years billions of dollars have been spent on high-rise luxury accommodation in the main capital cities of this country. The National Australia Bank, in its Monthly Summary of November last year, pointed to a recent study of the tourism industry which revealed that the lower end of the market is badly underserviced. It stated that most tourist promotions in Australia emphasised classy, high cost accommodation, which is usually priced out of the range of the local spender of tourist dollars. It stated that while the number of overseas tourists visiting Australia has grown at a faster rate than the number of local tourists travelling internally, Australian residents travelling internally still make up the bulk of tourists.

When we talk about tourism, it is all very well to concentrate on our `shrimp on the barbie' overseas image. But let us not forget that not too many Australians can afford those shrimps because the `barbie', as it is set out for the overseas tourist, is in a very classy, expensive, international hotel. There has not been the incentive for small business operators in this country to put their money into the sort of accommodation which is needed by Mr and Mrs Average Australian who are taking their children on a holiday. Increasingly, their pay packets are so diminished that it will be a caravan holiday. They are not getting the opportunities to stay in good, moderately priced accommodation because the small business people in Australia are afraid to invest. With interest rates at the level they are, what small businessman would dare to go into a major investment now-which must represent a minimum of a million dollars, probably nearer to two-in order to set up some sort of motel or moderately priced accommodation of a viable size? Businessmen will have to spend that sort of money in order to establish a new motel, and they will spend most of their waking hours working for the bank. It is just not on. Any government that really understood the way small business thinks would realise that there is just no hope of getting that sort of investment while the economy is in its present state.

It is all very well, as I said, to concentrate on the glossy, glamorous end of the industry. But the fact remains that it is catering for the major international companies. The Australian investor in small business cannot afford to invest under this Government's regime. We are paying the price in this far too great emphasis on the luxury beds and insufficient coverage of the small operator and the small Australian family which goes on holiday.

The Minister stated that at present we have almost $8 billion worth of infrastructure being built for the tourism industry in Australia. Infrastructure, of course, also extends to such matters as airline terminals. I was interested to note in the course of the Minister's statement that he referred to the problems at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. He stated:

. . . too many passengers arriving early in the morning at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, the design and outlay of our baggage collection and Customs areas, too many people seeking accommodation, and an excess of organisations wanting to hold conventions in Australia.

He pointed to these examples of too much success rather than of too little. I think it is also an example of the failure by this Government and by the statutory authorities that work under it. It is very clear that the emphasis should be on overseas visitors changing their point of entry to this country. Most overseas visitors think of Sydney when they think of Australia. Until we have better reception facilities at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, it is up to the Australian Tourist Commission actively to direct tourists in and out by other gateways. Until such time as we can do something about the curfew in Sydney, and the simultaneous arrival of so many large aircraft into Sydney, with people having to face Customs and immigration officials at 6 o'clock in the morning in long queues that go on and on, I believe that the Australian Tourist Commission should actively encourage people, as I said, to arrive and depart by other gateways.

It is interesting to recall the figures relating to overseas visitors who visit other parts of Australia. Unfortunately, I could not find them for the debate tonight, but I recall very clearly that only 3 per cent of overseas visitors actually make it to my home state of Tasmania. I also recall that well under 15 per cent get to Queensland. We think of those two States as being two of our main tourist destinations. Yet the figures for New South Wales were extremely high by comparison. There must be more emphasis on spreading visitors throughout the country. I draw the attention of the Senate to a report in the Age newspaper on 11 July last year which said:

The detailed economic management report focusing on Australian holiday patterns, released by Mintel Australia, also showed that local and international visitors spent most money in NSW (including the Australian Capital Territory). A total of $3818 million went to NSW and the ACT. A total of $2689.3 million was spent in Victoria.

There is a very heavy imbalance when we look at the figures for the country as a whole. I am concerned that we should be looking to do more about that. If the Commonwealth is to be involved in bringing international visitors to this country, it should take an active role in suggesting routes around it.

The Minister went on to say that prior to 1983 there were very strong disincentives for overseas investment in Australia but that his Government had eased the guidelines and was now allowing foreign investment 100 per cent equity in respect of the provision of the tourism infrastructure. He naively said that the effect of this has been quite miraculous. I do not find it miraculous at all. If one's currency is as low as ours and if one has a high inflation rate, one will be attractive to foreign investors. It is just an accidental result of the Government's mismanagement of the economy that occasionally there has to be a plus. The attraction of so much tourist investment into this country has turned out to be a plus. But the Government should not be crowing and taking credit for this. Mismanagement of our economy is a serious matter and the Government should not skite about something that happens along the way and over which it has had very little control.

The Minister also said that we now have a marvellous reservoir of well-trained, well-equipped young Australians entering this glamorous industry. If we have such a marvellous reservoir, the reservoir has a leak. The figures for February 1986 show that 229,800 people were employed in the hotel, restaurant and clubs industry while the figures just out for February 1987 show that now only 200,500 people are employed. Nearly 30,000 people have left that industry. So it is not good enough for the Minister to claim that this is such a marvellous avenue for jobs for Australians-the figures prove otherwise. People are leaving this industry. Although some people may still be employed in the glossy end of the industry, I have to tell this Government that restaurants all around this nation are closing down.

One has only to read the Age newspaper's epicure guide week after week to see how many high quality restaurants have reluctantly shut their doors. They may not have all gone into bankruptcy but they have seen the writing on the wall and when they start to go into the red they shut their doors. There is no getting away from it. The figures for the hotels, restaurants and clubs show that employment has dropped by 30,000 people in the last 12 months. So much for such a marvellous reservoir of well-trained and well-equipped young Australians entering the glamorous industry-obviously they are also leaving it.

I was also interested to see that the Minister is claiming that the Government had done a wonderful job in training these young people. I tried to do a bit of research on how much training they were actually getting. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is constantly showering members of parliament with news releases, across the top of which is his distinctive green logo. I ran into a bit of trouble when I tried to find out how many of these traineeships under the Priority One scheme had been handed out for the tourist industry. I found back on 19 December that 17 leading Perth restaurants were to offer young people food and beverage service traineeships in Western Australia. I could not find anything about it afterwards. On 21 October last year 11 young Canberra men and women were to get traineeships under the scheme. I understand that later there were a further 15-but I could not find a Press release for that. It was announced in September last year that 12 young Aboriginals in the Australian Capital Territory were to get on-the-job work experience and formal off-the-job training in the tourism industry. Back in September last year it was announced in Queensland that hospitality traineeships would soon be announced-but I could not find a follow-up Press release.

The Parliamentary Library has been chasing this information for me. However so far, this is the only information it has been able to come up with. So it looks as though there has not been great involvement by the tourist industry working with the Government on these traineeships. I wonder whether this is because people in the industry are struggling to survive themselves and they do not really have the time or the faith in the future to take on trainees, as the Government was hoping they would. The Minister himself pointed out what I feel is a very weak area in respect of young people in this industry. He described in graphic detail-if any- body is interested in reading the statement-the fact that of the 1,200 young people who tried to get into the Ryde hospitality school 800 were refused. Five hundred people tried to get into the William Angliss school in Victoria and 400 were refused.

This Government is not prepared to allow young Australians to get the education they want. The Government allows people from other countries to get the education they want because they are prepared to pay for it. However, Australians are not even allowed to try to pay for it. The Government cannot make facilities available. It is not providing sufficient places or any options, which my party has clearly stated it will do. Let it be understood: This is not an area in which the Government can claim any virtue.

The Minister also talked about the tourism overseas promotional scheme, the TOPS scheme, which is designed to assist the industry in its international product marketing efforts. If I were in the Government, I do not think I would be doing too much skiting about this. Only a month or so ago, the Australian Hotels Association drew attention to the fact that of 33 organisations using that scheme, which were contacted by the International Tourism Organisation of Australia, 30 were experiencing problems with delays in approval, delays in payments or both. I asked the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism a question about that during an Estimates committee hearing. Officers agreed that they were having trouble and that the administrative situation was in some sort of chaos. They said that they were getting too many applications to be able to cope and that the Minister was in consultation with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) on the question of forward commitment for future approvals. I understand that they are now somewhere between $8m and $15m in arrears on this matter. The Australian Tourism Industry Association has commissioned Peat Marwick to examine the scheme from the tourism industry's point of view. I have to make sure that the Government understands that the industry is not happy with this scheme which is most inefficient and which needs thorough and hearty reworking. The idea is good but the Government cannot skite about it yet because it is not working too well. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism went on to say:

There seems to be a feeling abroad that international tourism is the only thing that we should be pushing. It seems to be forgotten that 85 per cent of the tourism industry in Australia is generated within Australia.

I referred to that fact earlier. One of the things that the local and international tourism industry depends on most is the road system in this country. It should be remembered, and remembered very well, that the real level of road funding in this country in 1983-84 was $1.359 billion, and the Budget estimate for this past year dropped to $1.152 billion-a drop of $200m. I will be very interested to see what happens to those road funds in the mini-Budget when it is brought down tomorrow. That will really test what sort of a commitment the Government has to tourism because roads are a major part of tourism infrastructure and are of great importance to the economy and commercial life of the country. We will see tomorrow what the Government will do about roads. The Minister also spoke about strikes and, interestingly enough, he said:
. . . in the last four years there has not been a single strike within the tourist industry although some industrial problems in the airline industry have, at times, indirectly hurt the trade.

First, I dispute the Minister's statement and, secondly, to say that the industrial problems in the airline industry have at times indirectly hurt the trade makes one wonder whether the Minister has been away overseas all the time. Anyone who knows anything about the tourist industry has to say that the merest threat of an airline strike sends chaos and cold winds throughout the tourist industry. Bookings are cancelled right around the country, arrangements are changed and many bookings are never replaced. It is a very great problem in the industry and to say that it indirectly hurts the trade betrays incredible ignorance, and the mind boggles. The Minister also talked about the bogy of penalty rates and said:
Furthermore, the bogy of penalty rates . . . has not stopped the upsurge in tourism development . . . in Australia.

I have news for the Minister. If he thinks that he has done well in the tourist industry, I would like him to try a moratorium for a couple of years. Let us have no penalty rates for two years and see what it does for the industry. If there was not a dramatic growth in tourism, the Minister could always reintroduce them. I think that there is no way that the Minister can accurately say that is a bogy and that penalty rates have not stopped an upsurge in tourism development. The upsurge in tourism development-the services that could be provided to our overseas visitors, to our own internal tourists-I think would be amazing to see if employers were able to have their employees work any five days during the week without penalty rates. The National Australia Bank, which I mentioned earlier, in its survey in November last year said:

. . . many Australian businesses have reduced their out-of-hours services, maintained skeleton staffing at weekends, and eliminated most services on public holidays. A solution is to develop more flexible wage-fixing principles that are industry specific.

Of course, visitors from overseas also expect to be able to shop at all sorts of times, and they find it incomprehensible when they cannot spend their money-especially the Japanese tourists, who are very keen to buy gifts for their families back home. That is an integral part of a holiday for Japanese visitors when they are in other countries. They like to take back gifts to their families, as do we all, of course, but they cannot do it because they have limited time and the shops are shut. The shops are shut on Sundays and restaurants are shut on Sundays and Mondays only because of cost limitations on them on public holidays as a result of penalty rates. Until we have an opportunity in the tourist industry to demonstrate their stifling effect, it will be very difficult to get through to the union movement and to this union dominated Government just what they are doing to the industry which holds so much future and promise for us all.

I do not want to take any more of the Senate's time. I am glad to see that a committee headed by Mr John Haddad has been set up by the Tourist Advisory Council to negotiate with the unions for a better regime for industrial relations. I wish the Committee well but, until there is a change of government, I think it is not too likely that it will have much success. I say to the Government: It is all very well to promote tourism effectively overseas-and I acknowledged earlier on that I believe the Government is doing that-and it is all very well to get the spin-offs from its economic mismanagement by having the dollar drop and money flood in, but what this country desperately needs is to get the economy back on an even keel and get interest rates down so that people can invest. The Government should get rid of the capital gains tax so that people who are prepared to work long hours in this industry, which it demands, will be rewarded by receiving some sort of capital gain when they decide to get out. We should be training young people-that is not happening at the moment-giving them places in tertiary education, and giving them more traineeships, if that can be organised. The Government should not hold out the young but should let them start at a lower rate of pay so that they can be taught to do their jobs properly. Teaching them on the job takes time and costs employers money. Let us get rid of the penalty rates which are holding back the industry. If we could do all these things, we might really be able to talk about what a wonderfully promising industry we have. I think the Government has taken action, in some ways, at the beginning of the race; but the race is a marathon and there is a long way to go yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement on tourism is indeed an important recognition of the role of the tourist industry as an export earner and as a possible provider of stimulating jobs for Australians. However, the statement by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) in places shows the tendency for the Minister to exaggerate and overpromote himself regardless of the facts. The statement makes one think of the Minister as a contortionist trying to pat himself on the back at all times, if honourable senators can imagine that. However, it is quite correct that the Hawke Government has seen the tourism potential and has taken many potentially good steps in that direction. Our previous notion of tourism as some sort of last resort into which unskilled people went has now been swept away. There is an understanding that we need to harness skills in young Australians, and also in not so young Australians, to be able to offer services to people who come from all parts of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The rapid growth in the Japanese market highlights the need to tailor what we have to offer to the requirements of those people who want to travel here. Japanese tourists come here in groups far more often than tourists from other countries and they like to see many more regions while they are here than do most other people. There is plenty of room for a specialised segment of the tourist industry to devote itself to servicing the needs of the Japanese tourist market. We could provide that service ourselves rather than sitting back like the Government and expecting the Japanese to buy our resorts and to `ghettoise' their tourist activities. However, this requires a completely new and important approach to both language and cultural skills within Australia. We need to have people with a knowledge of Japanese culture, and we also need people with a knowledge of cultures of other nations whose people may come to Australia. This must link in with the development of a national language policy and must take account of our trading links and our position within the Pacific region. It is extremely important that we recognise that we are part of a Pacific economic community in terms of our tourism because we can offer a very broad range of services to tourists by actually being part of an operation which brings people into New Zealand, the islands and Australia as part of linked tours.

It is also very important to look at shift work and to try to get a sensible approach to the labour problem. This has been mentioned by other speakers, so I will not dwell on it for very long. Basically we need to maximise the convenience for tourists. The industry has to provide a service which is of recognised and acceptable quality and standard, and we have to move away from a lot of the inflexibility of the previous era which is still dominating the managers in many hotels and resort areas.

It is important that we make a start with the development of specialised training associated with schools such as the William Angliss College and the Ryde College School of Catering and that we should also give some of these people the right language skills and the right cultural knowledge of what people will expect and want from a good tourist service. As this professionalism increases, so will the opportunities for our industry, and we will be able to re-assess how we can use the young people who have entered into this area and offer a lot more skills and earn a lot more money-many more foreign tourist dollars.

It is very important for our appeal as a tourist destination that we maintain the range and diversity of our natural environment. Senator Sanders has spent some time on this. If we allow our natural environment to be raped and pillaged in our role as a quarry for overseas investors who are seeking a quick return, we are only cutting our own throats. The spectacular growth in the number of overseas tourists who come to Australia shows that we can generate an enormous amount of foreign exchange from people who appreciate our natural beauty, and we have to promote harmony between our tourism and our environment. This is possible. It sometimes requires rejection of proposals that are going to despoil nature. The putting up of very large urban complexes such as those that are spoiling the Gold Coast of Queensland detracts from the beauty of the place. Maybe we can earn more dollars by actually making more selective use of our natural beauty, which is unique in the world. It is very important that we re-establish a reputation for actually watching our environment, and we can have a large number of concerned people coming to Australia to look at things like our rainforests, our desert coastlines and so on. They are not necessarily just people who will come along with a back pack and not spend any money here. That can be part of what they are coming along to see. In Thomas Hardy's novels at the turn of the century it was suggested that one of the major tourist venues of the world would be our wilderness areas, and this is coming true today. People with reasonable amounts of money are willing to come and spend it to get professional viewings of parts of our wilderness.

Last year I briefly visited some of the Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, and at Uluru, which has been fairly commercialised, the local Aborigines have been employed in a very positive way, as rangers to look after their traditional land around Ayers Rock. The community was very proud of its role in restoring an area of major significance and being able to express its traditions and culture to people from all parts of the world. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service officers were indeed sympathetic to the Aboriginal culture and to the needs of the environment, and worked painstakingly to improve conditions. As well as that we have a full-scale luxury hotel in that area which is charging sufficient to enable it to get a pretty good return on its money.

I believe it will be a major advance if we start to examine how we can reap the potential from areas of spectacular beauty and at the same time retain the awareness and care that is necessary to nurture the natural environment. We need to promote Australia first and not get caught in an all-States favouritism game of picking winners. Each region has its potential and there are in those regions many small business entrepreneurs able to seize opportunities in each of those parts of Australia. However, those people need proper marketing and transport infrastructure to help them. We need to offer the facility of a deregulated airline system which does not cost the earth. It costs more to travel in Australia than to get here. We need competitive bus and rail travel and we need to sort out more deregulated arrangements such as those for interstate buses. We need to recognise as well that there is an upper end to the tourist market and provide facilities for people who want to come here and spend large amounts of money, maybe on some of our specialised jewellery products such as opals. We need to collect statistics on all of this and know what types of facilities we have to provide. Last May the Secretary of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr MacDonald, wrote to me in these terms:

Accurate, timely and reliable information is of course of vital importance to enable the development of policies sensitive to the needs of the tourism industry and more informed decision making by Government.
Mr MacDonald pointed out that his Department was trying to expand data coverage and improve the types of surveys carried out. He added:

A source of considerable concern to the Department has nevertheless been lengthy delays involved in the release of certain important tourism statistics such as ABS visitor arrivals data. In this area the Department has been in close consultation with the relevant authorities and has endeavoured to ensure that data handling systems are established which lead to more timely data availability.

I recommend to Mr Brown and the Government that they make certain not only that we help tourists to appreciate Australia and promote it overseas, but also that we know where we are succeeding and where we are failing. That is where proper statistics and data on the tourism industry are necessary. I recommend this approach to the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting debate, and coming from the tourist industry, in which I have participated to some degree for about 28 or 30 years, I feel it could be said that fools rush in where angels fear to tread. The tourist industry is not all about big government and what the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) is doing or is not doing, and what we politicians think the tourist industry should be. The fact remains that the tourist industry is a most interesting one. It employs, as the Minister had said, many Australians through all walks of life.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take the Minister to task only to a degree, because obviously he is a Minister who is very enthusiastic about his responsibilities to the tourist industry of Australia. But I think he should also realise that the tourist industry did not commence in 1983. Perhaps he feels that to quite a degree it did, but we have to give credit where credit should be given. When one looks back over our tourist industry, one sees that over many years a tremendous number of people-little people; big people too, but mainly little people-have developed it. The Minister should not look back over previous governments and cast aspersions on them, because it does not do them justice and because, at the same time, it makes him a little foolish.

I will reminisce for a little while. I look back to the days of Sir Phillip Lynch, which was also about the period of former Senator Bob Cotton, who became the Australian Ambassador to the United States of America. He was the Ambassador for both the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government. In respect of Sir Phillip Lynch, I suppose with the pressure and pace of the way in which parliaments go on, we tend to forget those who were with us and who gave so much of their time. They disappear and we think nothing more of them. Sir Phillip Lynch gave much of his body, soul and heart-the lot-to small business and to tourism. He did this in the period that he held very senior positions in the Fraser Government. He gave his whole body and soul and eventually died of cancer, under very difficult circumstances, I might say. He was a man who, within the parliamentary scene, did much. Bob Cotton is still alive these days and as hearty as ever. He was recognised by both governments as having done well for Australia. I remember when I first came into the Senate how he was particularly interested in tourism and could see the future of it. He gave much to that industry, as has Mr Brown, the present Minister.

Looking back over my brief few years in a role within the tourist industry, there are so many people who should be recognised, whether one sees them as big citizens of Australia or just minor ones. I refer to people who have made the tourist industry so significant. I guess one would be Sir Reginald Ansett, who started off as a surveyor's assistant in Katherine in the Northern Territory. He battled his way up. He, of so many Australians, added so much to the tourist industry. He started off as a single person, bought a light aircraft and built himself up to be the head of Ansett Airlines of Australia. Of course, there is also Sid Williams, who commenced Bush Airlines in Queensland. He is another battler who has done much for the tourist industry. One could go on. One could refer to Eddie Connellan who, in the outback, was a most significant person. In 1939 he developed airways through the outback. It is incredible to think of it now, but he serviced some 128 landing points throughout the outback-in northern South Australia, Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland. His contribution to travel and to the tourist industry was significant. He was a most incredible person.

We can look in so many directions. There are the people of some 30, 40 or 50 years ago who brought about the beginnings of tourism. Tourism does not just grow overnight. It did not grow just in 1983. It did not grow just in 1940, 1950 or 1960. It had humble beginnings, as did the mining industry and the pastoral industry. I have been in touch with so many of the small people. Such small people still exist these days. I can remember Bertie Bond. He introduced coaches to the outback. Perhaps I should have a grey beard, but I remember him in 1930. There was Stan Cawood. Ayers Rock was hardly on the map in the days just after the war. Very few people went there. Stan Cawood still lives. It was he and Jack Cotterill who pioneered travelling to the Rock and that area of tourism. One could go further afield and look at Queensland to see what the Hayles of Mackay have done with tourism in the Whitsunday Passage. This is only a minute selection of those people through the outback and the whole of Australia who have contributed to tourism.

Looking at this particular statement, my first impression-I do not want to be too hard on the Minister-leads me to say that self-aggrandisement tends to diminish the stature and credibility of the speaker and I must say that I would have thought that the Minister would have taken just a little more time to remember to recognise and congratulate the people who have made the Australian tourist industry. The Australian tourist industry has grown from strength to strength through the years and through governments and it will continue to grow, because it has a tremendous future. It is not the Federal Government, a State government or anything like that that is at the helm. They are there to assist and, wherever possible, guide these small people of Australia in endeavouring to make a good living for themselves, their friends and their families. It is not the Federal Government that leads them along by the nose in the general direction in which they are going. Indeed, it is the small people who have established these directions; sometimes government has assisted them and sometimes it has not. Mr Brown is to be congratulated to some degree for what he is doing. But before he announces to all far and wide all those things that he has done to assist the tourist industry-as he did continually through his statement-I would ask him to halt just a little and recognise the problems of the people in the tourist industry today. There are immense problems.

I was looking at an article in the Australian Financial Review of 12 May. The headline said: `Personal bankruptcies hit a record high'. By nature I am an optimist. But when I see so many small businesses going bankrupt, I do not blame it on the Government. I am not as silly as that. I think that some of its policies could have contributed a bit, but they are not responsible for the situation that exists now in which personal bankruptcies have hit a record high. Also, it is no good saying in this statement that everything is so glossy and good within the tourist industry that we are all living on a high. We are not. We have a record number of small people going bankrupt, and I can assure honourable senators that within the tourist industry and small business there are very many people who are in desperate straits. So let us have less flag waving and let us be realists. Let us look at the situation in Australia and the people that we represent and do something for them. We will not do anything for them by waving the flags and saying how wonderful we are, how wonderful the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism is, or how wonderful the Government is. We have more responsibilities than that to those people. I seek leave to have this article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Personal bankruptcies hit a record high
By Julie Power
High interest rates and the availability of plastic credit cards have led to a record number of personal bankruptcies.
The South Australian Small Business Corporation has carried out a survey of financiers and found steep rises in personal bankruptcies in all States, and says the worst may be yet to come.

The Corporation says that in the nine months to March 30 the number of bankruptcies had risen by 60 per cent in Queensland, 50 per cent in South Australia, 49 per cent in WA, 44 per cent in Victoria, 35 per cent in the Northern Territory, 33 per cent in NSW and 30 per cent in Tasmania.
It called on the Federal Government to help reduce the taxation burden on the private sector to help counter the ``rising trend of personal and business failure''.
Last week Australian Guarantee Corporation noted in its interim report a 40 per cent increase in bankruptcies. AGC said South Australia was the worst affected State, with a 58 per cent increase.

According to the SA Small Business Corporation, the ``dramatic increase in personal bankruptcies'' resulted in a decrease from 33 per cent to 24 per cent in the direct proportion of bankruptcies directly attributable to business failure.
But it said that business could take a little comfort from this statistic because the absolute number of businesses failing had also increased above the trend line.
Mr Ron Flavel, the SA Small Business Corporation's general manager, said not only had household income declined, most people were stretching their credit lines to the limit.
He also said that the stigma attached to bankruptcy had declined as evidenced by a recent pamphlet from the SA Department for Community Welfare.
The pamphlet in question mentions social disgrace as one of the drawbacks of bankruptcy and says: ``You should consider how you feel about this and how your friends are going to react.''

A spokesman for the department, Mr Brian Walker, said that there were 6,594 bankruptcies throughout Australia last year and there was ``evidence to suggest'' that personal bankruptcies would increase by more than 33 per cent this year.
The department, he said, had become aware of the need for easy-to-understand literature on the subject.
Credit companies contacted yesterday confirmed a noticeable increase in the number of bad debts and bills in arrears.
The State Bank of SA said there had been a ``concerning increase in Bankcard debt''.
Beneficial Credit assistant company secretary, Mr Trevor Waller, said the number of bills in arrears for 30 days and over had certainly taken off.
To manage the increase, the company had increased its staffing in the collection of arrears by more than 20 per cent.

But Mr Michael Mount, a spokesman for the Insolvency Practitioners' Association of Australia and a partner in Michael Mount and Co, of Adelaide, said the number of business bankruptcies had increased only slightly.
He said that the increase in personal bankruptcy was associated with the ``overselling of credit cards, and the increased cost of interest on these kinds of services''.
``The burden of interest rates between 18 per cent to 20 per cent was catching up with the little people who are relying on credit increasingly,'' he added.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I shall not spend too much time on the Minister's statement, but one matter that concerns me considerably is that he talked of the wonderful things that are being done for young Australians in the tourist industry. That is true enough. There is a golden opportunity for young people within the industry, but there are problems.
