The Minister talked about the education of young people, promotion and other matters, and referred to schools and that kind of thing. I remind him of a situation that has been hurtful to a group of young people who wished to gain experience of the tourist and hospitality industry by going to a college to see whether that was to be their life's work. Those young people coming out of school, aged 14, 15 and 16 years, were not too sure what they wanted to do. If they had been, they would have been exceptions. This group wanted to find whether their future lay in the tourist and hospitality industry. These young people were encouraged to take up youth traineeships, but the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia said to them, `You cannot participate in this school or enter this traineeship unless you join the Miscellaneous Workers Union'.

SPEECH.PARA: I take exception to the fact that unionism can encroach on the lives of young people-people aged 14, 15 and 16 years-and deny them the opportunity, without joining a union, of trying their luck at training with the possibility of a job in the hospitality industry. A few days ago I drew up a question on this aspect for the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who represents the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). I now put it to him. I draw the Minister's attention to the problems currently being experienced by employers in the tourism and hospitality industry in the Northern Territory, where youth traineeship opportunities are being thwarted by the demands of the Miscellaneous Workers Union that young trainees join the union. This compulsory unionism being forced on potential trainees has led to 12 trainees not being given traineeship opportunities in 1987. The figure was 12; it could have been 100. Can the Minister say whether his Government believes that young people-in this case, in the Northern Territory-are entitled to gain work experience through traineeship schemes without being forced to join a union before undertaking that necessary work experience as the foundation of their careers? Further, what is the Federal Government prepared to do to ensure that union belligerence does not deprive other young Australians of traineeship opportunities?
The Minister also talked about the efforts of his Government to bring about better facilities for tourism. I note that he said:
We have provided a special subsidy towards the cost of diesel fuel used for power generation by off-shore tourist resorts within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park region.

That is tremendous, and I am not envious. In such situations the subsidy should be provided, but I wonder whether the Minister has been to the outback where people are building up their little private enterprise tourist industry. They may be 100 or 200 miles off the road and have to drag their fuel and supplies from the nearest centre. They live in extremely poor conditions and are doing their own thing in encouraging people to go to the outback; yet despite all the Minister's hoo-ha about assisting tourism, I cannot see a damned thing being done for the little Australian in the outback, and I have lived there most of my life. What is the Federal Government doing for people who live out there in the dust? To me, the paper that has been presented is extremely lacking.

The Minister said that he has done much to provide facilities for overseas visitors. That is all very well, but, when one gets down to it, it is really private enterprise that is doing it. The international terminals were not built by the Minister's Government; they were built a few years ago. I have said again and again, and I will continue to say, that I am bitter about the Federal Government's lack of responsibility concerning the gateway to the north, the Darwin Airport. I am bitter about it because, while many facilities in major cities are perhaps being encouraged, it is still private enterprise that is doing the work. The Government speaks of international visitors to Australia. Those who come through the Darwin Airport have to go through an old hangar that was shot up and bombed during the Second World War. That hangar is still the terminal at Darwin Airport and that is a very poor introduction to Australia, particularly for people who have come through such places as Singapore. A new airport was to be built but when the Minister's Government came to office it cancelled the work that was in train. Some $19m or $20m had already been spent, but nothing further has been done.

A leading Darwin businessman has again written to the Prime Minister on behalf of a group of private businessmen who are prepared to take over a piece of ground on the airport and build a terminal. I seek leave to have a document dealing with this matter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Prime Minister asked to intervene in Darwin Airport crisis

Leading Darwin businessman and endorsed C.L.P. candidate for the Federal House of Representatives, Mr Peter Paroulakis has again written to the Prime Minister Mr Hawke on behalf of a large group of investors to personally intervene and resolve the present crisis relating to Darwin airport.

Mr Paroulakis said that in the past two years since the north side project was halted on April 4, 1985, despite numerous requests of the Minister, not only by the N.T. Government but by a wide range of industry and community organisations and members of the public Mr Morris has given no indication of when a new terminal will be constructed. A press release of August 20 1986 referring to the ``detailed planning of a new passenger terminal'' in the totally inappropriate south west corner of the Airport, in the existing R.A.A.F. area, is the last advice we have received from the Minister.
We now learn that the Federal Labor Government's Expenditure Review Committee is considering the possibility of selling the terminal.

Mr Paroulakis said he was gravely disturbed at the constant changing of proposals and conflicting concepts which indicate a gross lack of competence and good will and the total disregard for the people of Darwin shown by the Minister.

Mr Paroulakis intends to again try and put a private funding proposal to the Prime Minister and Mr Morris during his proposed visit to Canberra at the end of May to try and resolve the crisis but also to seek some firm and clear commitment for the construction of the much needed passenger terminal.

The people of Darwin are fed up with being treated as second class citizens by Federal Labor Ministers who continually call us ``parasites and bludgers with a cargo cult mentality living off the efforts of other Australians''.

Mr Paroulakis said ``Territorians want to decrease their dependence on Commonwealth funding but we must be given the opportunity to develop our economy. Tourism is a major growth area which will provide a massive stimulus to the local economy. Uncertainty over the future of our airport is helping to wreck this industry in its infancy.
Overseas and local investors have injected hundreds of millions of dollars of their own risk capital which will contribute to the N.T. being a self reliant economy.

The present airport terminal and its totally substandard recent additions which only increase the chronic congestion stands as a landmark to the deliberate and unrelenting policy of the Federal Labor Party in its efforts to stifle the growth and development of the Northern Territory''.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could go on and on about this statement, but it is not my intention to do so. The Minister may see himself as the leading light for tourism in Australia, but in the eyes of many people he is lacking. He is lacking because he tends to build himself up as the accomplisher, but that is not the case. He believes that he has brought in overseas people in large numbers. I assure him once again-this goes back to what I was saying at the beginning of my speech-that tourism started many years ago. It is the battler, the businessman, who has gradually built up the private enterprise tourist system and promoted Australia overseas. These people have built up the figures.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the tourist industry in Europe now is very much in the doldrums. There are many reasons for this, one of which is the exchange rate. If we asked people from overseas why they came to Australia, I would not be surprised if, more often than not, they said: `Gaddafi sent us'. So many people now refuse to go to Europe, including England and Ireland, because of the terrorist campaigns. They see Australia as a safe country and let us hope we can keep it that way. Only a little while ago Americans particularly would not come to Australia in large numbers because of the exchange rate. Their dollar did not go very far in Australia. Now it is extremely advantageous for overseas visitors, particularly Americans, to come to Australia because their dollar goes a long way.

In closing, it is interesting to note the Minister's statement. Some of the facts and figures that he has put forward indicate that the tourist industry of Australia is in a very strong condition. It has been growing in strength over the years. The only criticism that I have to make regarding his statement is that he fails to recognise the pioneers and the present workers in the tourist industry. I am not too sure where they fit in, in his mind. They are the tourist industry. While Mr Brown remains, in the Federal sphere at least, the Minister responsible for tourism, I think many people within the tourist industry of Australia would look to him for more assistance and more sympathy. But he is waving the flag as though he is the achiever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make eight or nine comments with respect to the ministerial statement of the Hon. John Brown, Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, entitled `Tourism-under Labor'. Honourable senators who have spoken before me have indicated that their view of this statement is that it is yet another example of the Minister blowing his own bags and failing to accept the contributions that other people have made to tourism in Australia. That is the theme that I would like to pick up and develop. This paper says a lot more about what has been done or what the Minister thinks has been done by this Government rather than what this Government will do.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point at which I would take issue with the Minister is on page 2 of the ministerial statement. There he says:

Not only has the Commonwealth Government become active in the promotion of tourism but the State governments, which were as moribund as the Federal Government in that period prior to 1983, have now also become very actively involved as well.

What the Minister forgets, what has escaped his mind or what he has deliberately excluded, is the role of the South Australian Government in tourism development, under the Tonkin Government, from 1979 to 1982. The Minister has obviously forgotten that during the time of that Government the tourism budget was increased twofold-a claim that I note the Minister has made in the paper with respect to certain aspects of the tourism budget. He fails to acknowledge that the South Australian Liberal Government reorganised its department-a reorganisation which was long overdue. Further, he fails to acknowledge that the South Australian Liberal Government developed a five-year plan for tourism, which has now been upgraded by the current Labor Government. I say that to indicate that the need for a five-year plan was accepted by the Labor Government. That is why it was upgraded. The Labor Government is continuing to handle tourism on the basis that it needs some planning and that it is not a day to day business. I am informed-reliably, I believe-that that was the first coherent, long term tourism plan developed by any State or Federal government in this country. Therefore, I find offensive the reference by the Minister about the State governments being as moribund as the Federal Government prior to this Labor Government getting in.

The second point that I wish to make relates to some comments made by the Minister on page 4 of his statement. There he seeks to remind us of the increase, in hundreds of thousands, of overseas visitors coming to Australia. He is very pleased with the fact that we have had such a substantial increase and seems to try to take credit for it. However, he does not acknowledge that the falling value of the Australian dollar is making Australia a cheap tourist attraction. I do not deny that some Government initiatives may also be contributing to that increase. However, I venture to say that the major attraction for tourists, especially the Japanese, is the value of the Australian dollar.

As if to compound the Minister's ignorance of this fact, he goes on to say that, on the reverse side of the coin, more Australians than ever are choosing to stay at home. The implication in this statement, put in the context of the whole speech, is that the Minister has found some wonderfully clever way to attract other people here and to keep us home within the domestic tourist industry, thereby increasing the contribution made by the dollar to the economy through local tourism. He has forgotten yet again that the reason that Australians are not travelling overseas as much as they may have in the past is that it is just too expensive to do so. If one goes to any bank here to get a quick exchange of the Australian dollar for the English pound or the Japanese yen, one will soon find out how many McDonald's burgers one will be able to buy with the Australian dollar overseas-many fewer than one can buy here. That is why people are staying at home, not because this Government has come up with some bright idea that will convince people that local tourism is something that they have denied themselves unwittingly in the past and should now take advantage of.

In making those comments, the Minister also ignores one other fact, and that is that a significant proportion of the tourism industry here is involved in outbound tourism. It wants to sell trips to the United Kingdom, Italy, et cetera. That is how it makes its money. The industry is not pleased that more people are staying at home. It is not pleased with the value of the Australian dollar and that people are choosing to stay at home.

The next point on which I would like to take issue with the Minister is one that he has outlined on page 6 of his statement. He refers to the fact that education authorities around Australia have responded to the change and that we now have emerging a splendid array of hospitality schools in the colleges of technical and further education and the colleges of advanced education. It is a small pork barrelling point for me to make, but I would have preferred the Minister at that point to have mentioned the Regency Park School of Catering. That is a TAFE college, I think, in my State which is renowned for its very high standard. The graduates of that school go out into the industry with a very professional approach and are welcomed around Australia.
A further point that I would like to take up with the Minister is on page 8 of his statement. He says:
As a further innovative step-
yet again, of course, blowing his own bags, as Senator Kilgariff has pointed out-
I introduced-
not his Government but that he personally, single-handedly, introduced-
an annual program for national tourism awards.

I would have preferred the Minister to mention that well before this Government came to power, in the very early 1980s in South Australia, the industry, without any government intervention, set up its own tourism awards. As I have said, the regional association in South Australia set up its own scheme of awards, the pinnacle of which are the Harry Dowling awards. I agree with the Minister that the national tourism award have created a greater awareness of the need for professionalism in the tourist industry and to that extent they may facilitate the upgrading of standards. But the Minister should not pretend, either in this paper or in the other place, that he has introduced this program of awards and that it is an innovation. The industry in my State, under a Liberal government and without government intervention, produced its own range of awards. This scheme is nothing new; it is nothing special. If the Minister thinks this scheme of awards is innovative, in my view he has a number of problems in grappling with what is innovative and what is simply repeating something from the States.

A further matter on which I question the Minister is on page 8 of his statement, where he lists what he refers to as a number of subsidiary measures which we also introduced. We are then treated to a page and a bit of star dot points most of which relate to pork barrelling in particular States. For examples, we are informed that sales tax on certain cruise vessels is backdated to the implementation date of August. So what? That is particularly beneficial to Queensland, and I do not deny it. Every State needs assistance.

Senator Kilgariff referred to page 9 of the statement and to the special subsidy towards the cost of diesel fuel used for power generation by off-shore tourist resorts within the Great Barrier Park Marine Park region. As I understood the honourable senator, he said that he does not deny that that is a good idea. Neither do I, but again it is pork barrelling for Queensland; it does not help a whole variety of States.

The statement ignores that in the gulf waters of South Australia is a boat charter industry which is struggling to establish itself; it is struggling to develop and become a part of this tourist boom that the Minister implies he created single-handedly. Yet I do not notice in the statement any reference to assisting these boat charter people. Nor do I notice any reference to the tourist resorts which Senator Kilgariff mentioned, in the inland and remote areas of Australia. For example, there is nothing about Arkaroola and Wilpena in South Australia but if one happens to be in the Great Barrier Reef, a high profile area, a little pork barrelling will go down very well. But if one is an outback tourist operator not yet in the high-flying area of tourism, one can forget about getting any help from this Government.

With the advent of Crocodile Dundee in the United States and other countries from which we get a large number of tourists, I would have thought that the Government would want to give a significant amount of attention to the outback tourist operators. I do not notice anything in this list that will particularly assist them. I notice things for the Northern Territory, Tasmania and a variety of States but I do not notice anything in particular for South Australia, which makes one call into question the South Australian Labor Government's slogan `When Bannon fights, South Australia wins'. It seems apparent from this list that either that statement is untrue or Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, has not been fighting enough on behalf of his State.
A further point I would like to take up is raised by the Minister on page 10 of his statement:
. . . there has been a huge upsurge in the number of jobs available to young Australians who are looking for a career in the tourism industry.

If that is the case I ask the Minister: Why, on seasonally adjusted figures, are more young people in the 15- to 19-year-old age group unemployed than there were when the famous Priority One: Young Australia shonk started? Young people are not getting jobs in the tourism industry. Priority One is an absolute disaster with respect to private enterprise. It has been singled out for its capacity to turn private enterprise off. Something like 95 per cent of the jobs are in the public sector and only 5 per cent are in the private sector. So very few jobs are in the private sector and of those a limited number are in the tourism industry. How the Minister can say that there is a huge upsurge in the number of jobs available in this area to young Australians, given the disastrous performance of the Priority One program, I am not sure.
In relation to the employment of young Australians, I refer also to the community employment program, which is raised by the Minister on page 10 of his statement. He states:
In the short term, the Government has actively used the community employment program . . . to increase job opportunities in this most rewarding area.

I have a particular interest in the community employment program, and there is a reason why the Minister has commenced the paragraph with the words `In the short term'. It is that it was only in 1985-86-I presume that it applies to 1986-87 also-that a category of tourism was introduced into community employment program projects. Prior to that, on my analysis of the 1984-85 projects, there was no such category. So the Minister is quite right in saying `In the short term'. It is something he thought of 18 months or so ago. I do not deny that this is not a good program but the Minister's words `In the short term' are not quite as telling as they ought to be. It was a last minute thought.

While I am on that subject I should raise the point that I have some concerns with the community employment program being used to achieve objectives other than the employment and training of young Australians as its first priority. A certain amount of capital is included in the Commonwealth money that is allocated and local councils are eyeing off that capital as a rich apple they would like. They are developing projects to acquire the capital section and not paying the heed that ought to be paid to the training program which the community employment program trainees will undergo. In other words, some might say, to put this at its harshest, that the community employment program is, in some respects, a scheme to divert capital to various groups rather than to encourage the employment of young Australians.
On page 11 of the statement the Minister states that his Government's vision for the future includes:
. . . an awareness program highlighting our museums, art galleries and theatres and a vast variety of extremely high quality resorts with a uniquely Australian flavour.

I come back to the point I made earlier about little help being given to the tourism industry as it relates to the outback. Surely that is the most uniquely Australian flavour that the tourism industry in Australia could have. The River Murray, which concludes its course in my State, has along its course an enormous range of developments which are suitable for tourism, not the least of which are those in the houseboat industry. I do not notice any reference to this sort of uniquely Australian tourism industry in the Minister's speech.

Another industry which I think ought to be mentioned in the context of being uniquely Australian is the wine industry. I refer to an article in the most recent English Harpers and Queen in which the distinguished wine writer Mr Auberon Waugh wrote an article entitled `Fair Drinkum'. He explains why he came to Australia and in doing so he states:
There are three reasons for my sudden pilgrimage to the wine-producing state of South Australia.
He continues:

The Committee is satisfied, at this stage, with the discount voucher system currently being introduced, but recognises that this system needs to be tested in practice. The Committee is aware of concerns expressed by representative organisations and will keep this matter under review. If the Committee finds that concerns remain once the system is fully operational, then it will examine the operation of the voucher system further.

In relation to the National Biological Standards Laboratory, the Committee is concerned that insufficient and inadequate resources continue to prevent the Laboratory from carrying out its functions effectively. This, together with other information available, has prompted the Committee to embark upon a public inquiry into the National Biological Standards Laboratory. The Committee will also examine the resources available to the National Biological Standards Laboratory.

In conclusion, the Committee would like to express its serious concern on a matter becoming increasingly common in responses to Committee reports. The Committee is particularly concerned that in some instances departments are taking an inordinate amount of time to deal with specific and immediate administrative problems identified by the Committee, particularly when raised previously by the Auditor-General. TALK.START.PARA: —Those 13 instances cover all the various parliaments of the States of the Commonwealth of Australia and incorporate situations where all governments, or majorities in the lower Houses of those parliaments, have agreed to the nomination of persons of different political persuasions, different political organisations and parties in accordance with the convention I have described. Apart from the aberrations that are well known to us flowing from the actions of Premier Lewis of New South Wales and Premier Bjelke-Petersen of Queensland, which necessitated the passage of the 1977 referendum, that well understood convention has in fact been observed from the earliest occasions when a replacement was required. But simply as a result of political skulduggery and point scoring, particularly by the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, that convention has been abandoned in this particular instance. Unfortunately, although one can understand Mr Gray engaging in this constitutional vandalism, some members of the Legislative Council, perhaps not so conscious of the ramifications for this chamber of their actions, have concurred in that frustration of the intention of section 15 of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: I say-and perhaps it is by way of anticipating their defence-that some legislative councillors in particular may have thought, and I think many Tasmanians were also led into this trap, that this would be a media event, a bit of a stunt by the Premier; it would last a couple of weeks, would be exhausted and then Mr Devereux would be appointed. I know Senator Watson took that view on 19 March when he said that this was more or less a piece of political grandstanding by the Premier and that it would not have long term consequences.

There are now no more avenues for waiting for common sense to prevail. We are presented with a situation where we have an indefinite casual vacancy, and whereas it was designed in the initial stages to embarrass the Labor Party in Tasmania and create a political storm down there, in fact it has done quite the opposite. It has had the effect of uniting the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania in a way that it was not united before in its cohesive stand behind Mr John Devereux as the nominated member of the Labor Party. What we are defending is the Labor Party's right-and, indeed, the Liberal Party's right and the right of the Australian Democrats and the National Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —And all factions of the National Party.

—And the National Party, all factions, to nominate their preferred member for parliamentary office. Surely it is a fundamental matter, and all except the Independents in this chamber are here because they are the preferred members of their political party or organisation who have through the normal processes of that party been successfully endorsed for parliamentary office. We are simply insisting that that right of the Tasmanian branch of the Australian Labor Party to endorse its preferred member for parliamentary office be recognised in this instance. The proper normal processes of the Labor Party led to the nomination of John Devereux. He is entitled to fill the vacancy in the team of five senators of Labor Party persuasion which the Tasmanian voters wanted to see here, along with five Liberals, one Australian Democrat and one Independent. That is the composition of the constitutionally assured group of 12 senators which the Tasmanian electorate voted to have come into this chamber in order to join in the deliberations and debates in this chamber and to vote on the passage of legislation and other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to emphasise in this contribution tonight the impact on this chamber of what the Tasmanian Parliament has done, thinking it was acting in an autonomous way, exercising its right. That is what needs to be highlighted. In the Tasmanian Joint Sitting there was not a majority in favour of the view that the convention I am advocating should be observed. As a result of the failure of the Joint Sitting as a whole, a completely distorted representation of the Tasmanian electors' will prevails in this place at this moment. As far as one can tell it will go on through these very crucial weeks of the autumn session.

One might have understood a lapse of a week or so while matters were finalised in Tasmania. The people of Tasmania are being deprived of their constitutionally assured team of 12 senators in this chamber, composed, according to their preference, of five senators from the Australian Labor Party, five from the Liberal Party of Australia, one Australian Democrat and one Independent. The Tasmanian Joint Sitting has deprived this chamber of its democratic and representative character in relation to Tasmania. It is very ironic, is it not, that a Premier who constantly pleads the States, rights argument should undermine the representation of the State of Tasmania in this place. In fact, I wrote a letter to the members of both Houses of the Tasmanian Parliament yesterday. It was delivered to their offices last night I believe, so I am able to quote it today. In it I said:

I am asking you to reconsider the vote which has led to the situation where, in the crucial week of the Autumn session (the May economic statement is delivered on Wednesday), Tasmania is to be under-represented in the Senate Chamber. Specifically, voters are being denied a member of the team as determined by the quota gained by the Australian Labor Party.
I went on:

You will be aware from your parliamentary experience that the granting of a pair of votes is no remedy for the loss of a voice in debates on a wide range of issues. The Senate Committee system also cannot operate effectively without a full panel of Labor back benchers available to sit on them.

In short, whilst the Tasmanian Parliament in its joint sitting may have asserted its role, the democratic and parliamentary processes in the Senate are being put in jeopardy the longer this matter is in stalemate.

I believe that unless that particular letter and the passing of the motion before the Senate-which I anticipate will occur tonight-together with the resolution in like terms passed in the other place earlier this afternoon, has some impact on my Tasmanian parliamentary colleagues, that undesirable situation will continue through these last few weeks of the autumn session, and who knows whether it will be resolved by the time we resume for that crucial Budget session.

I think it is important to point out that what lies behind this particular situation is something of a streak of authoritarianism on the part, in particular, of Mr Gray. If this situation is allowed to continue, then that authoritarian political approach will have been given full reign and endorsement by the Joint Sitting of the Tasmanian Parliament. The nub of the issue, as I see it, if that in this situation there seems to be no feeling for the fact that we live in a democracy where those people who do not share the point of view of the majority of society nevertheless-and this is one of the strong features of the composition of this chamber as compared with the chamber across King's Hall-can have political representation and have their voice heard in debates and counted in votes in the chamber that makes the laws which govern this nation. The fact is that Mr Gray, simply because he has a majority in the House of Assembly and can persuade some members of the Legislative Council to go along with his particular point of view-those numbers in that particular Parliament-does not have the right, surely, to trample on the voice of those electors who wanted a Labor Party representative selected through the Labor Party's democratic processes for the casual vacancy replacement in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows up the legislative councillors for what they are.

—Well, I am saying that the legislative councillors have been led astray in this particular matter and that they should not join Mr Gray who poses as a States' rights advocate but is denying this State representation as its constitutional entitlement-I would have said `assures it' but it is not assured, as matters have turned out. Of course, he also poses as a conservative. But a true conservative would value the way in which our constitutional written document is supplemented by the conventions to which I have alluded. But the Premier is such a confrontationist that the idea of conserving those things which are of true value in our democratic political system does not appeal to him when he can see a short term, immediate political advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that Mr Gray wants us to look upon the replacement senator-no doubt he would want us to look at all senators in this way-as in some way emissaries or ambassadors on behalf of the State government concerned or the State parliament concerned. Of course, they are not. If that were the case, all one would need to do when the Premiers Conference meets in the House of Representatives chamber is to have the Premiers walk across King's Hall into this chamber as legislators. If senators are to be mere ambassadors of State governments, why do not the Premiers, as they do in some other federations, just join together from time to time as the Upper House in the particular federal arrangement? Of course, we know that that is an absurd situation, but that is the effect of the situation to which Mr Gray has brought us.

If there was ever any political gain for Mr Gray in this whole constitutional confrontation, that vandalism that is occurring, I believe that time has long passed. May I say-and I am sure this view is shared by my Tasmanian Senate colleagues-the time has passed when Mr Gray is getting any political advantage in Tasmania out of this whatsoever. Tasmanians are fed up with his posturing. As long ago, in fact, as 10 March the editorial writer in the Launceston Examiner said this:

In the seventies the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, rejected an ALP Senate nomination thereby breaking a sensible civilised convention in favour of the grossest from of political expediency.
It went on to say:
Few Tasmanians would want their State to follow that sordid, miserable and undemocratic path.

I think that just about sums up the actual mood of most Tasmanians, despite the assertions of Mr Gray that he has most Tasmanians behind him. I think they are fed up with his posturing. Indeed, on the very same day, in the Mercury of Tuesday, 10 March, there appeared an editorial to this effect. I will read it because it reinforces my submission. It states:

Likes and dislikes of ideologies are facts of political life; they are, however, irrelevant to the present debate, which should not be about forestry, but which should be about filling casual vacancies in the Senate. The only attitude which really matters in the debate is that of the ALP. It wants Mr Devereux to replace one of its members in the Senate. It arrived at this decision democratically, and its wishes should be paramount. Any serious attempt to bring about a result different from the one sought by the ALP risks destroying the attempts supported in a referendum by the people of Australia to try to strengthen parliamentary stability through the Constitution.

I believe that that particular view is shared increasingly, not only by people in Tasmania but also amongst conservative political circles, even on the mainland, who regard the action by Mr Gray as quite a diversionary and artificial crisis. In fact, it led Mr Ian Sinclair, the Parliamentary Leader of the National Party in this Parliament, to say that Mr Gray's actions amounted to an act of gross political stupidity. Mr Howard, on 8 March-I think it was on the steps of Parliament House-said this:
I believe that the person appointed to fill casual vacancies of this kind ought to be the person nominated by the retiring Senator's political Party.

It is because of that recognition by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, of that convention that the Labor Party has incorporated that particular quotation in the motion that is before the chamber this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said something about `at the end of the day'. The end of the day may be July next year.
—I think it was actually Senator Chaney who, very early in the piece-in fact, on 13 March-endorsed that particular view. Speaking of Mr Devereux, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would, therefore, expect him in due course to be nominated by the Tasmanian Parliament.

There have been stages in this particular saga when those on the other side of the chamber, the more sensible of them and those who are more sensitive to the conventions of the Constitution, thought that good common sense would prevail, given a week or two. We have seen, with Mr Gray in particular, that appeals to common sense and constitutional propriety, and sensitivity to a non-authoritarian, democratic and representative chamber, have no effect whatsoever. The appeal fell on deaf ears and we are confronted with the stalemate with which we are presented today.

I do not believe this is a matter for partisan politics. That is why I was pleased to hear of the passage of a resolution in identical terms in the other place on the voices and without division earlier today. With the passage of the same motion through this chamber, I hope Tasmanian parliamentarians will take stock of the situation and put pressure, if that is the appropriate word, on their Presiding Officers, the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, Mr Cornish, and the President of the Legislative Council, Mr Broadby, to do what the Governor asked them to do. You will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that on 3 April our esteemed President, Senator Kerry W. Sibraa, wrote in the following terms to His Excellency, Sir James Plimsoll:
Your Excellency,

Pursuant to the Provisions of Section 21 of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution, I notify Your Excellency that a vacancy has happened in the representation of the State of Tasmania through the resignation of Senator the Honourable Donald James Grimes on 2 April 1987.
Consequent on receiving that letter, the late Governor wrote to the Speaker in these terms:
Dear Mr Speaker,

I am enclosing a copy of a letter I have received notifying me, pursuant to the Provisions of Section 21 of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution, that a vacancy has happened in the representation of the State of Tasmania, through the resignation of Senator the Honourable Donald James Grimes, which occurred on Thursday, 2 April 1987.
It is the following sentence that I wish to emphasise:
I enclose also a copy of the letter that I have sent to the President of the Legislative Council asking him to arrange with you for the filling of this vacancy.

Clearly, there is a recognition there that it is the Presiding Officers in the Tasmanian Parliament, the Speaker of the Assembly and the President of the Council respectively, who have the very key, crucial and grave roles in this matter. They have effectively been asked by this chamber, through the letter of the President conveyed to the Governor, to make such arrangements as are necessary to fill the vacancy, to assure all Tasmanians that they may have the representation of 12 senators to which they are constitutionally entitled in the proportions, as provided in section 15 of the Constitution and supplemented by the convention to which I have referred, in which voters in Tasmania indicated by their votes cast in the ballot box at the preceding election; namely, five members of the Labor Party, five members of the Liberal Party, one member of the Australian Democrats and one Independent.

It was in regard to that that the Governor asked the Presiding Officers to arrange for the filling of the vacancy. The role of the Presiding Officers becomes very important, and perhaps we can now stand back from the political posturing of Mr Gray and the Government of Tasmania. Senators are not ambassadors or emissaries of the Government or the Parliament of any State, but the role of the Presiding Officers is the important one and they must now play their part in preserving that democratic and representative function of this chamber, following the resignation of former Senator Grimes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said they were emissaries of the State?

—I am saying that Mr Gray, by requiring that a person who is to fill a casual vacancy share the political stance and views of the Government on a crucial issue, is treating that senator as no more than an ambassador, emissary or mouthpiece of the Government in regard to that matter. However, I am confident that the Speaker and the President of the Assembly and the Council in the Tasmanian Parliament will respond to this motion and will take whatever steps are open to them. I know that they do not hold all of the power in this matter. Clearly, the Governor has to be advised by his Executive Council, but those Presiding Officers should take whatever steps are open to them to ensure that a joint sitting is convened to fill the vacancy, as they were requested to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe very strongly that, with the passage of this motion tonight, this chamber will be reaffirming a most important convention of the Constitution, one that has been observed scrupulously by many State parliaments of all political persuasions no less than 13 times since, by way of referendum in 1977, when an overwhelming majority of the electors in Australia said that they wanted an end to the manipulation of the situation that can flow from the resignation or retirement of a senator from this chamber. Unless that convention is observed, we will have the impasse that has had the anti-democratic, unrepresentative consequences to which I have constantly referred as the theme of my contribution. I understand that an amendment to the motion has been circulated but not yet moved. I anticipate by saying that, of course, the Government will not accept the amendment which the Opposition proposes to move.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to pay tribute to the late Sir James Plimsoll, Governor of Tasmania from 1982 until his sudden death on 8 May. Sir James had a career of exemplary public service. He began his education at the Sydney High School and the University of Sydney where he gained an economics degree and a Bachelor of Arts degree. While at the university, Sir James was president of the union, and he made some shrewd and far-sighted purchases of art works which are now a significant asset for the university union. Sir James was, for a time, an economist with the Bank of New South Wales before serving in the Second World War, rising to the rank of major in the Intelligence Corps. After his war service he joined the Australian diplomatic service, then in its infancy. One of his first roles was as a member of the Commission for the Rehabilitation of Korea.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir James Plimsoll had a brilliant and meteoric rise through the diplomatic service. He became High Commissioner to India and then permanent Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs, a post that he held for five years. Subsequently, he was Ambassador to both the United States of America and the Soviet Union, Ambassador to Belgium and the European Communities and High Commissioner to London. He ended his illustrious diplomatic career as Ambassador to Japan. In all his posts he won the confidence and respect of the various foreign statesmen both for his fine intellect and for his unfaulted discretion.

In 1982 it was announced that Sir James Plimsoll would become Governor of Tasmania. Early in his term he made the comment that he intended to meet every Tasmanian. His punishing schedule, sometimes two weeks solid of official dinners, often travelling the length of the State twice in a day, and his concern for people in every field of endeavour, won the affection of all Tasmanians. The Official Secretary at Government House, Hobart said on Saturday that he had asked the post office to withhold some of the hundreds of messages of condolence from people in every walk of life in Tasmania, Australia and around the world, because the staff could not cope with the volume. In November last year the Tasmanian Premier announced that the Queen had approved an extension of a further three years to Sir James's term, until the end of 1990. Many people who know of the calibre of Sir James Plimsoll will appreciate the loss that is being felt by so many people in Tasmania, in the arts world, at the Department of Foreign Affairs and in so many other spheres for a great man and a dedicated public servant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly tonight about a man who has contributed a great deal to the sport of gliding. Unfortunately, Ingo Renner is a name that, though very well known in gliding circles, is not well known to the rest of Australians. Yet, he is a four times world champion glider and 11 times he has been the Australian champion. He is a German-born Australian who has lived in this country for a number of years. I am not sure how it is that some athletic feats are featured but others attract less attention. I learned particularly of Ingo Renner when I visited the Canberra Gliding Club's twenty-fifth anniversary celebrations earlier this year at the Bunyan field near Cooma. I congratulate the Canberra Gliding Club on the success of its celebrations and for having paid for its field in five years. Honourable senators would appreciate that it is quite an extensive tract of land on which the club has placed the appropriate and suitable buildings. It is a memorial, if that is the right word, to the dedication of the members of the club that they have achieved so much.

SPEECH.PARA: This was also the occasion of my first flight in a glider. Mr President, you will be pleased to know that it was not a solo flight; I had a very competent glider behind me. It was on that day that I learned of the dedication and of the feats of Ingo Renner who is so well respected amongst gliders and who has done a great deal to put Australia on the map amongst those in other parts of the world who really appreciate gliding as a sport. An article written about him under the heading `Hero of the open skies' tells more about him than I could do because it is written by someone who knows and understands him and gliding. I ask the Senate to recognise the feat of Ingo Renner, and I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the article to which I have referred.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
HERO OF THE OPEN SKIES
For one who spends most of the time with his head in the clouds, Ingo Renner is a singularly down-to-earth sort of character.
The four times world champion glider pilot is a diffident and private man, which befits the solitary pursuit of which he is champion.
His domain is within the wheeling, plunging forces of the sky. He rides the crests on invisible waves of air and challenges the elements for mastery in the sport of soaring.
On the ground he is quite shy and given to few words. He melded invisibly among the hundreds of gliding aficionados attending the 25th Australian Gliding Championships at Gawler.

But within that fraternity he is something of a hero. He is one of those quiet achievers whose experience and sheer technical artistry inspire awe in others. Eavesdropping at pre-flight briefing sessions, one could hear his name mentioned again and again as his fellow competitors pitted their strategic wits against his steady excellence.
Renner remains politely aloof. He is devoid of the competitive killer instinct. His idea of strategy is to ``take it easy''.
He cares little whether he has a flock of airborne rivals or is in individual pursuit of a new record. It is all ``sport'' to Ingo Renner. The 45-year-old German-born glider ace simply loves flying.

He finds it hard to describe in mere words. The beauty and satisfaction of gliding may only be comprehended by those who have done it. And, he says, none among them has had the sheer poetry required to tell it as it is.

From earliest childhood, Renner has identified with soaring birds such as the albatross, the eagle and the seagull. Funnily enough he has something of the ungainly albatross about him as he goes about the pre-flight routines on the ground.

He is a large man who lumbers slowly around his sturdy little prototype glider. Every motion is a gesture of love. After 29 years of gliding in borrowed aircraft, he now owns one. Call-signed Xray Xray, it is a sleek, German hand-built Discus glider worth $50,000.
Renner squeezes awkwardly into the tiny cockpit in a semi-reclining position, his legs disappearing into the nose, his knees bent between the control sticks.

It is not terribly comfortable and he could have had a glider made to measure, but he prefers it as it is. Once aloft, his physical comfort becomes irrelevant. His mind is fully absorbed with the business of flying and achieving the controlled grace of the soaring birds he so so admires.

His flying outfit consists of slightly baggy jeans, a long-sleeved shirt, comfortable soft shoes, a towelling soaring club hat, sunglasses and a liberal layer of zinc cream on the nose. The sun can be pretty ferocious at ten or twenty thousand feet, he says.

Unlike many of his rivals, he takes with him no refreshments other than water, however long the flight. His most epic flight has kept him in the air for 12 1/2 hours. With a touch of chagrin he explains that gliding is a sport limited to daylight hours. But if there is only so much a pilot can do in a day, Renner has done it. He holds the record of 1095 km for longest straight flight to a nominated goal as well as the speed record of 129 km/h average on a 1000 km triangular course.

He is unafraid in the air. In gliding, he says, pilot error is the only terror. Renner has crash-landed and damaged a sailplane just once. He asserts that gliding is the safest of sports, provided the pilots have astute concentration.
Ingo Renner lives for soaring and soars for a living.

Yet it was not always so. Although his heart has been in the sky since he was a schoolboy making radio-controlled model planes, when he came to Australia from West Germany 28 years ago it was as a shipping clerk. But, as Renner points out, gliding is a great social leveller. Glider pilots come from all walks of life-and they begin flying at all ages.

Renner was already a seasoned pilot when he arrived in Australia. He had begun flying at the age of 15, when he regularly cycled 50 km to the gliding field from his home town of Hude, near the harbour town of Bremen where his father was a merchant sailor.
Once in Australia, he swiftly glided to prominence winning a 1966 regional championship in Queensland's Darling Downs in an unlikely old-model glider.
Since then he has notched up many records. He has won the Australian championships six times in the open glider class, twice in the 15m class and three times in the standard class.

He has competed in the World Championships six times. He came sixth in Yugoslavia in 1972, second in Australia in 1974, first in Finland in 1976, 14th in France in 1978, first in USA in 1983 and first again in Italy last year. He was deeply disappointed when, as an Australian citizen, he was prohibited from competing in the 1981 World Championships in Germany.

``I felt I would have had a good chance, knowing the countryside so well from my youth,'' he explained. ``But there are politics in gliding just as in other sports. The South Africans were competing and therefore we could not go. It was a bit sad for me, but I have made up for it since.''
Renner's philosophy towards life and flying is dominated by his spirit of calmness and positivism. He says he is thankful for what he has had in life. He yearns for nothing.

He is most at home aloft in the whispering ambit of a glider, soaring on thermals, dipping, diving and cruising in the cumulus sky. He is also content amid the clouds of dust at the Adelaide Soaring Club's Gawler aerodrome, surrounded by his peers and their families.
One of the nice things about gliding, he says, is the camaraderie of the competitors.

When glider pilots attend competitions, they take everything including the proverbial kitchen sink. They park their nine-metre sailplane trailers in neat rows and set up camp in tents and caravans nearby.
The championships take a fortnight, so they settle in with children, dogs, televisions, lounge chairs, eskys and all the comforts of home. One family even takes their pet galah.

Assembling the gliders is a team effort. All pilots have a back-up crew of friends or family. Ingo Renner has his Finnish-born wife, Teresa, and needs no-one else. Teresa, 30, is an expert glider pilot in her own right. They met at competitions in Germany and have been married for four years. When Teresa is competing, Renner performs as back-up crew.

``It is really not very romantic,'' declares Teresa. ``We rarely fly together and tend not to compete in the same class at the same time. I don't kiss my husband goodbye before he takes off like some other wives. Quite frankly I'm just too busy. I have my work cut out checking the equipment and keeping the glider clean of dust. At take-off I run with the wing''.
Even in the repetitive and laborious task of keeping the craft free of SA's ochre-coloured dust with a wet chamois, Teresa avows love for the way of life.

Against a mosaic backdrop of criss-cross white sailplane wings, with the wasp-like buzz of the old crop-duster towplanes in the air, she bustles around Xray Xray, ensuring there are enough sweaters tucked around the parachute to keep Ingo comfortable and, finally, affixing to the perspex windscreen ``the best and cheapest gliding instrument,'' a length of red woollen thread which will tell the pilot if he is ``flying cleanly''.

Once her husband is airborne, she returns to their caravan to monitor his progress on the radio while he executes the day's ordained flight route, to bring back photographs of nominated landmarks in the fastest possible time.

The Renners spend six months of the year in Australia, living in New South Wales at Tocumwal on the River Murray. Ingo, with about 14,000 flying hours, works as a full-time gliding instructor, using his leisure time listening to classical music (``preferably any composer whose name begins with B''), swimming in the river or making flying model gliders.

Every March the Renners return to Europe where Ingo continues to instruct in gliding in Germany while multi-lingual Teresa goes back to her old airport job in Sweden, planning aircraft movements on the apron.
``It is a gypsy life,'' admits Teresa. ``I suppose it is a bit unusual. But we are happy with it so far. Of course we can't go on like this forever.''

Renner is of a different mind. He is a non-smoker, a very occasional drinker and a robust man. He is not in a hurry to stop competition flying and he does not intend to retire as a gliding instructor until the regulation retirement age of 65. Even, then, while he wants to specialise in making model gliders, he will not eliminate the possibility of a little pleasure gliding. To Renner, soaring is a way of life.

``I think I was at my peak a few years ago,'' he says. ``A glider pilot's peak is much the same as an astronaut. It depends on a lot of experience while you are still young enough to take the pace and stress of flying.

``Elderly pilots are at a disadvantage because they can no longer concentrate at the required level for long periods of time. But gliding is a sport without age barriers. It is best to start at 15, but many people dream of sailplaning for years and years and do not manage to begin to do it until middle age or later when their children have grown up. It is still not too late.''
But if it is never too late to start learning, according to Renner; equally, it is never possible to finish.
``Even after 30 years I am still learning to read the sky,'' he says.
``I try to understand it and to use it. I try to copy the birds, but they are still the masters. There is always more to know and more to do.''
In Renner's case, it is fair to say the sky is almost unlimited.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I ask that we note, amongst all the other heroes of Australian sport, the name of Ingo Renner and that we watch his career in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the Minister's statement of 22 March 1987 that Maralinga has not been ruled out as a dump for national nuclear waste, how much of that waste is currently within Australia.
(2) What levels of radiation waste are already deposited (a) on the Australian mainland; and (b) at sea off the Australian coast.
(3) How is this waste being contained and disposed of, and what is the annual accumulation rate.
(4) In view of the Minister's reported statement to AAP (23 March 1987) that low level radiation waste is already stored in different Australian cities, will the Minister specify which cities.
(5) In respect to each city will the Minister specify the level of nuclear waste and the specific suburbs, outer areas of each city and indeed the proximity to each street, where the waste is housed.
(6) If Maralinga is ruled out as a suitable site, what are the total options available to the Federal Government.
(7) How acute as of March 1987, is the nuclear waste storage problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Firstly, I should point out that the former Maralinga atomic test site in South Australia is not being actively considered as a waste repository notwithstanding recent media reports suggesting that it is. Aside from a range of other considerations, including the views of the traditional Aboriginal owners of the Maralinga lands the South Australian Government has expressed no interest in hosting a national radioactive waste repository. As to quantity, approximately 1000m3 of radioactive waste which has accumulated over the years from activities involving the medical, industrial and research use of radionuclides is currently held in store in Australia.

(2) (a) and (b) Apart from radioactive waste resulting from the British Atomic Tests in the 1950s and 60s, radioactive wastes that are already deposited (in the sense that they are buried rather than stored) comprise:
bulky low level wastes from mining/processing of radioactive ores at a range of locations including:
mineral sand mining residues at Byron Bay in New South Wales, South East Queensland and Capel, Bunbury and Geraldton in Western Australia
uranium mining wastes at Moline, Rum Jungle, Ranger and Nabarlek in the Northern Territory, Mary Kathleen in Queensland and Radium Hill and Port Pirie in South Australia
medical research and industrial wastes have been deposited at Hunters Hill, Woolwich and Lucas Heights in New South Wales and at Kambalda in Western Australia.

(3) and (4) Because of the large volume of low-activity material involved, tailings and waste rock from mining and milling operations are disposed of on-site. This is done in accordance with the Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Wastes from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores 1982, developed under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978. Where radioactive wastes arising from medical, industrial and research activities contains radionuclides with short half-lives, it is safely disposed of directly to the environment (e.g. through sewer, incineration, or municipal landfill). Where those disposal routes are used it must be in strict accordance with the National Health and Medical Research Council's Code of Practice for the Disposal of Radioactive Wastes by the User (1985). Where wastes contain radionuclides of longer half-life (apart from those items able to be returned to the overseas manufacturer when no longer usable), the practice of each State and Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government has been to store them. They have therefore accumulated in small quantities at numerous locations around Australia including all capital cities. Approximately 1000 cubic metres is currently in store and is increasing at about 50 cubic metres per year.

(5) Detailed information has been published in Hansard describing the type and location of stored radioactive wastes in Australia. See answers to Question without Notice on ``Nuclear Waste Disposal'' (H of R Hansard, 29 March 1984, page 1107), answer to Question on Notice 1232 (H of R Hansard, 23 August 1985, page 527) and Question on Notice 1987 (H of R Hansard, 29 November 1985, page 4193). This information has been updated as a result of the Commonwealth/State examination of the possibility of establishing a nuclear waste repository (see answer to 6 and 7). I propose to make it public once a decision on this matter has been made.

(6) and (7) Continued reliance on present storage arrangements does not present an immediate problem although it obviously cannot continue indefinitely. The Commonwealth is therefore coordinating with State and Territory Governments on an approach to the disposal of radioactive wastes currently in store with the objective of developing a national radioactive waste repository. Based on internationally developed criteria nearly all of these wastes are suitable for shallow-ground burial and a desk review has been completed which shows that large areas of Australia could be technically suitable for the establishment of a repository. Consultations are continuing on this matter with both State and Northern Territory Governments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 28 April 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the Department of Community Services sell the Melville Rehabilitation Centre.
(2) Why was the Centre sold to Murdoch University and not to Mr George Margetts who sought to purchase the Centre for use as a hospital.
(3) (a) How much did Murdoch University pay for the Centre; and (b) what was the amount offered by Mr Margetts.
(4) Is it correct that Murdoch University received Federal Government assistance to purchase the Centre; if so, how much was provided.
(5) Is it correct that Murdoch University is seeking to sell off some of the surplus land at the Centre; if so, what is the estimated value of this land.

(6) Has the Federal Government received a request for assistance from the Western Australian Minister for Health in providing suitable premises for use by the Head Injured Society of WA (Incorporated); if so, what was the nature of this request and what action has the Government taken with respect to this request.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Melville Rehabilitation Centre was sold because it no longer met appropriately the requirements of the social and vocational rehabilitation services provided by the Department. The Melville Rehabilitation Centre was one of seven capital city centres sold in implementing the Government's 1986/87 Budget decision to put delivery of those rehabilitation services on a regional basis. Proceeds from these sales are being used to establish a network of regional units in all States to make services more accessible to clients.

(2) The Melville Rehabilitation Centre was sold to Murdoch University because it submitted an unconditional complying tender for the Centre. Marmac Pty Ltd, of which Mr George Margetts is a director, submitted a conditional non-complying tender.
(3) (a) $2.75 million unconditional (b) $3 million conditional on Marmac Pty Ltd being granted a licence to run a private hospital.

(4) Murdoch University is funding the full purchase price of the Centre. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has undertaken to provide a capital contribution of $1.75 in either 1989 or 1990.

(5) Murdoch University is an autonomous body established under State legislation. The Commonwealth is not involved in the day-to-day administration of the University, and I have no information on this matter.

(6) The Minister for Community Services has received a request for assistance from the Western Australian Minister for Health to provide residential and other services for people with head injuries. The Western Australian Minister for Health did not specifically ask for the service to be used by the Head Injured Society of Western Australia (Incorporated).

The Western Australian Minister for Health suggested joint funding between the Commonwealth and Western Australian Government, of a residential facility perhaps with some nursing home and some hostel beds for younger clients. He proposed that the Western Australian Government would contribute rent and some capital costs and the Commonwealth other recurrent costs.

The Minister for Community Services has written to the Western Australian Minister for Health asking for an offer made by the Commonwealth earlier this month to be considered urgently by Western Australia, viz, a lump sum once only payment of $1.5 million to be made by the Commonwealth before 30 June to the Western Australian Government in exchange for the Western Australian Department of Health providing rehabilitation services for people with head injuries that are now being provided in the Melville Rehabilitation Centre in Perth.

In his letter, the Minister for Community Services has also suggested a working party be established to report to both Ministers by 1 September on the longer term residential and living needs of people with head injuries in Western Australia which might be met jointly by the Commonwealth and the State.
